- Her work includes computer ethics, profession-based education, interactive media, and expanding the involvement of underrepresented groups and women in computing.
- She taught computer science courses and served as a provost fellow and a liaison.
- She co-founded the Missouri Iowa Nebraska Kansas Women in Computing Conference.
- This conference gathers students, faculty, and technology leaders to address the decline of women in the computer science professions and discuss strategies for improving representation in the field.
- She is active in the National Center for Women & Information Technology Academic Alliance.
- She is the recipient of the 2012 Missouri Governor's Award for Excellence in Education and received the Dean's Faculty Award for Service in 2014.
- She has published several articles related to computer science education and ethics.
- She is associated with the Association for Computing Machinery's Council on Women in Computing (ACM-W) and the National Center for Women and Information Technology.
Carroll Morgan (computer scientist):
- Charles Carroll Morgan is an American computer scientist.
- He moved to Australia as a teenager and completed his education there, including a Ph.D. from the University of Sydney.
- During the 1980s and 1990s, he was based at the Oxford University Computing Laboratory in England as a researcher and lecturer in formal methods.
- He authored Programming from Specifications, which combined high-level specification aspects of Z and rigorous computer program derivation methods of Edsger W. Dijkstra.
- Together with Annabelle McIver, he later authored Abstraction, Refinement and Proof for Probabilistic Systems, pursuing the same themes for probabilistic programs.
- Morgan is now a professor and Senior Principal Researcher at Trustworthy Systems at the University of New South Wales, and an Honorary Professor at Macquarie University, all in Australia.
- His main research interests are probabilistic models for computer security and concurrency, and he is a proponent of the refinement calculus approach to program development.
- He is involved with developing international standards in programming and informatics as an active member of several IFIP working groups, including IFIP Working Group 2.1 on Algorithmic Languages and Calculi.
Cecilia Berdichevsky:
- Cecilia Berdichevsky was a pioneering Argentinian computer scientist.
- She was born in Poland in 1925 and emigrated to Argentina as a child.
- She began studying mathematics at the University of Buenos Aires at age 31 and had her first experience programming the Ferranti Mercury computer.
- Berdichevsky studied computing from the visiting English software engineer Cicely Popplewell and returned home as an expert on the workings of the Mercury computer.
- She worked as Head of Practical Works of Numerical Calculus I alongside her mentor, Manuel Sadosky.
- Berdichevsky's work was disrupted by an Argentinian coup d'état that installed a military dictatorship.
- She later became Deputy General Manager of the Argentine savings bank Caja de Ahorro in charge of its computer center.
- Berdichevsky continued to work as a computer consultant and participated in important international projects and organizations.
- She died in 2010 in Avellaneda, Argentina.
- Berdichevsky published a paper in 2006 on the beginning of computer science in Argentina.
Charles Bachman:
- Charles William Bachman III was an American computer scientist
- He spent his entire career as an industrial researcher, developer, and manager rather than in academia
- He was particularly known for his work in the early development of database management systems
- His techniques of layered architecture include his namesake Bachman diagrams
- Bachman was born in Manhattan, Kansas in 1924 and attended Michigan State College, where he graduated in 1948 with a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering
- He joined Dow Chemical in 1950 and became Dow's first data processing manager in 1957
- In 1960, he joined General Electric and developed the Integrated Data Store (IDS), one of the first database management systems using the navigational database model
- In 1983, Bachman founded Bachman Information Systems, which developed a line of computer-aided software engineering products, including the BACHMAN/Data Analyst
- Bachman received the Turing Award from the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) in 1973 and was elected as a Distinguished Fellow of the British Computer Society in 1977
- He was awarded a National Medal of Technology and Innovation in 2012
- Bachman papers from 1951 to 2007 are available from the Charles Babbage Institute at the University of Minnesota
Charles E. Leiserson:
- Charles Eric Leiserson is a computer scientist specializing in parallel and distributed computing.
- He developed the Cilk multithreaded language and the fat-tree interconnection network used in supercomputers.
- He co-authored the standard algorithms textbook "Introduction to Algorithms" with Cormen, Rivest, and Stein.
- He received his BS degree from Yale University and his PhD from Carnegie Mellon University.
- He is a professor at MIT and a principal in the Theory of Computation research group.
- He was Founder and chief technology officer of Cilk Arts, Inc., which was acquired by Intel in 2009.
- He received multiple awards, including the 2014 Taylor L. Booth Education Award and the 2014 ACM-IEEE Computer Society Ken Kennedy Award.
- He is a Fellow of ACM, AAAS, IEEE, and SIAM.
- He received the 2013 ACM Paris Kanellakis Theory and Practice Award.
- He has authored multiple editions of "Introduction to Algorithms" with Cormen, Rivest, and Stein.
Charles Geschke:
-Charles Matthew Geschke was an American businessman and computer scientist
-He co-founded Adobe Inc. with John Warnock in 1982 and co-created the PDF format with Warnock
-Geschke earned an AB in classics and an MS in mathematics from Xavier University, and a PhD in computer science from Carnegie Mellon University
-He worked at Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center before leaving to start Adobe with Warnock
-Geschke served as Adobe's COO and president before retiring as president in 2000
-In 1992, Geschke was kidnapped and held for four days before being released
-He received numerous awards for his contributions to computer science, including the National Medal of Technology and Innovation in 2008
-Geschke was involved in various organizations and served on boards, including the National Leadership Roundtable on Church Management and the San Francisco Symphony
-He was a Catholic and received the St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Award from the National Catholic Educational Association with his wife in 2012
-Geschke died on April 16, 2021, at the age of 81 from cancer.
Charles H. Lindsey:
- Charles Hodgson Lindsey was a British computer scientist.
- He was involved with ALGOL 68, an important programming language.
- He edited the Revised Report on Algol 68 and co-wrote An Informal Introduction to Algol 68.
- Lindsey was responsible for implementing ALGOL 68 on the experimental MU5 computer at Manchester University.
- He wrote the complete History of ALGOL 68.
- Lindsey was involved in developing international standards in programming as a member of IFIP Working Group 2.1.
- He was a member of the Computer Conservation Society and part of the team restoring Douglas Hartree's Differential Analyser at Manchester Museum of Science and Technology.
Charles H. Moore:
- Charles Havice Moore II is an American computer engineer and programmer born in 1938.
- He is best known for inventing the Forth programming language in 1968.
- Moore co-founded FORTH, Inc. with Elizabeth Rather in 1971.
- In the 1980s, Moore designed several stack machine microprocessors and gained several microprocessor-related patents.
- His designs emphasised high performance at low power usage.
- In 2005, Moore co-founded IntellaSys, which develops and markets his chip designs.
- He also developed the colorForth dialect of Forth, a language derived from the scripting language for his custom VLSI CAD system OKAD.
- In 2009, he co-founded GreenArrays, Inc., which is marketing the GA4 and GA144 multi-computer chips.
- Rather, Colburn and Moore's 1996 publication "The Evolution of Forth" is a significant source of information on Forth's development.
- Moore's homepage, GreenArrays, FORTH, Inc., and an interview with Simple-Talk are linked in the article.
Charles P. Thacker:
- Chuck Thacker was an American pioneer computer designer
- He designed the Xerox Alto, the first computer to use a mouse-driven graphical user interface (GUI)
- Thacker received his B.S. in physics from the University of California, Berkeley in 1967
- He worked at Xerox Palo Alto Research Center, where he served as project leader of the Xerox Alto personal computer system, was co-inventor of the Ethernet LAN, and contributed to many other projects, including the first laser printer
- Thacker also worked at Digital Equipment Corporation and Microsoft Research
- He designed the hardware for Microsoft's Tablet PC, based on his experience with the interim Dynabook at PARC, and later the Lectrice, a pen-based hand-held computer at DEC SRC
- Thacker died of complications from esophageal cancer on June 12, 2017
- Thacker received several awards, including the Turing Award in 2010
- Further reading and external links are available for those interested in learning more.
Charles Stark Draper:
- Charles Stark "Doc" Draper was an American scientist and engineer
- He was known as the "father of inertial navigation"
- He founded the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Instrumentation Laboratory, later renamed the Charles Stark Draper Laboratory, which designed the Apollo Guidance Computer for NASA
- Draper attended the University of Missouri, Stanford University, and MIT, earning degrees in psychology, electrochemical engineering, and physics
- He taught and conducted research at MIT until 1970, devoting most of his final decade to completing the Apollo computers and software
- Draper received over 70 honors and awards, including the National Medal of Science and induction into the National Inventors Hall of Fame and National Aviation Hall of Fame
- The Charles Stark Draper Prize, awarded annually and consisting of $500,000 in cash, a gold medallion, and a hand-inscribed certificate, was established in his honor by the National Academy of Engineering
- Draper was a member of various professional associations, including the National Academy of Engineering and the American Physical Society, and served as president of the International Academy of Astronautics.
Charlotte Froese Fischer:
- Charlotte Froese Fischer is an applied mathematician and computer scientist.
- She developed and implemented the Multi-Configurational Hartree-Fock (MCHF) approach to atomic-structure calculations.
- Her research on atomic structure led to the experimental discovery of the negative ion of calcium, the first known anion of a Group 2 element.
- She was elected a Fellow of the American Physical Society in part for her contribution to this discovery.
- Froese Fischer was born in Ukraine to parents of Mennonite descent, who immigrated to Canada when she was a child.
- She obtained her Ph.D. in Applied Mathematics and Computing at Cambridge University in 1957, with coursework in quantum theory under Paul Dirac.
- Froese Fischer spent most of her career at the University of British Columbia and Vanderbilt University.
- She authored over 300 research articles on computational atomic theory.
- One of her largest efforts was the calculation of the complete lower spectra of the beryllium-like to argon-like isoelectronic sequences, covering over 150 ions.
- Her contributions to the field have received numerous accolades, including honors from the American Physical Society, Royal Physiographic Society, and Lithuanian Academy of Sciences.
Chris Lattner:
-Christopher Arthur Lattner is an American software engineer, born in 1978.

-He is the co-founder and CEO at Modular AI, an artificial intelligence platform for developers.

-Lattner studied computer science at the University of Portland, graduating with a Bachelor of Science degree in 2000.

-He has worked at SiFive, Google, Tesla, Inc., and Apple Inc.

-At SiFive, Lattner led the RISC-V Product and Engineering organizations.

-At Google, Lattner served as the Senior Director and Distinguished Engineer, TensorFlow Infrastructure and Technologies.

-Lattner served as the Vice President at Autopilot Software at Tesla, Inc., primarily responsible for creating Swift.

-At Apple Inc., Lattner was the Senior Director and Architect, Developer Tools Department, responsible for the Xcode IDE Instruments performance analysis tool, Apple Java releases, and a variety of internal tools.

-Lattner designed and began implementing LLVM, an innovative infrastructure for optimizing compilers, while working with Vikram Adve at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.

-Lattner also created the Swift programming language.

-Lattner is the co-founder of the MLIR compiler infrastructure.

-He is married to Tanya Lattner, a co-founder, president, and chief operating officer (COO) of the LLVM Foundation since 2015.
Chris McKinstry:
- Kenneth Christopher McKinstry was a Canadian artificial intelligence researcher
- He led the MISTIC project and founded the Mindpixel project
- McKinstry struggled with bipolar disorder and had a history of suicidal thoughts
- He died by suicide in 2006, leaving behind an online suicide note
- McKinstry's work has been published posthumously in Psychological Science
- McKinstry is the subject of a 2010 documentary called The Man Behind the Curtain
- He had a failed online soap opera called CR6, leaving many creditors with unpaid debts
Christopher J. Date:
- Chris Date is an independent author, lecturer, researcher, and consultant.
- He specializes in relational database theory.
- He attended High Wycombe Royal Grammar School and received his BA in Mathematics from Cambridge University in 1962.
- He worked at Leo Computers Ltd. and IBM Hursley as a computer programming instructor and was involved in technical planning and design for IBM products SQL/DS and DB2.
- He left IBM in 1983 and has written extensively on the relational model, in association with Hugh Darwen.
- His book "An Introduction to Database Systems" has sold over 700,000 copies and is used by several hundred colleges and universities worldwide.
- Some of his other works include "Databases, Types, and the Relational Model", "Database in Depth: Relational Theory for Practitioners", and "SQL and Relational Theory".
- He has published articles with Fabian Pascal at Database Debunkings.
Christopher Riche Evans:
- Christopher Riche Evans was a British psychologist, computer scientist, and author.
- He was born in Aberdyfi, Wales and educated at Christ College, Brecon.
- Evans worked as a science journalist and writer before pursuing a B.A. in Psychology at University College London.
- He worked on eye movements at the Physics Laboratory, University of Reading, and later at the Division of Computer Science, National Physical Laboratory, Teddington.
- Evans wrote a book about the oncoming microcomputer revolution, The Mighty Micro: The Impact of the Computer Revolution, and scripted and presented a televised series on the topic.
- He also wrote Cults of Unreason, a study of pseudoscience, and Landscapes of the Night: How and Why We Dream, as well as edited several anthologies and reference books.
- Evans had a significant friendship and collaboration with writer J.G. Ballard.
- He died of cancer in 1979 at the age of 48.
Christopher Strachey:
- Christopher S. Strachey was a British computer scientist who contributed to denotational semantics and programming language design.
- He is credited as possibly being the first developer of a video game, creating a version of draughts.
- Strachey was born into the Strachey family, which was prominent in government, arts, administration, and academia.
- He studied at Cambridge but suffered a nervous breakdown and did not perform well.
- He worked at Standard Telephones and Cables (STC) as a research physicist and later became a schoolteacher before joining the National Physical Laboratory (NPL).
- Strachey developed the concept of time-sharing in computing, filed patents for computer design, and worked on programming language design.
- He later became a computer consultant and worked on various projects for organizations such as NRDC, EMI, and Ferranti.
- Strachey became a distinguished fellow of the British Computer Society in 1971.
- He died of infectious hepatitis in 1975.
- The Department of Computer Science at the University of Oxford has a Christopher Strachey Professorship of Computing and an archive of his papers is held in the Bodleian Library.
Christos Papadimitriou:
- Christos Charilaos Papadimitriou is a Greek theoretical computer scientist.
- He received his Bachelor of Arts degree in electrical engineering from the National Technical University of Athens in 1972.
- Papadimitriou completed his Ph.D. in electrical engineering and computer science from Princeton University in 1976.
- Papadimitriou has taught at several universities and is currently the Donovan Family Professor of Computer Science at Columbia University.
- He co-authored a paper on pancake sorting with Bill Gates when Gates was a Harvard undergraduate.
- Papadimitriou received many honors and awards, including the IEEE John von Neumann Medal, the EATCS Award, the Gödel Prize, and the Knuth Prize.
- His publications include textbooks Computational Complexity and Algorithms, as well as the graphic novel Logicomix.
- Papadimitriou joined a professor-and-graduate-student band called Lady X and The Positive Eigenvalues at UC Berkeley in 2006.
- He has received several honorary doctorate degrees.
- Papadimitriou's name is listed in the 19th position on the CiteSeer search engine academic database and digital library.
Cicely Popplewell:
- Cicely Mary Williams was a British software engineer born in 1920.
- She studied the Mathematical Tripos at the University of Cambridge.
- In 1943, she joined the Women's Engineering Society and became a Technical Assistant at Rolls-Royce Ltd.
- In 1949, she joined Alan Turing in the Computer Machine Learning department at the University of Manchester.
- She worked on the programming of the Manchester Mark 1 and wrote the Programmers Handbook for the Ferranti Mark 1 in 1951.
- She also taught the first ever programming class in Argentina at the University of Buenos Aires in 1961.
- After leaving the University of Manchester Computing Service in the late 1960s, she married George Keith Williams and died in 1995 in Buxton, England.
Claude Sammut:
- Claude Sammut is a professor of computer science and engineering at the University of New South Wales and Head of the Artificial Intelligence Research Group.
- He was the UNSW node Director of the ARC Centre of Excellence for Autonomous Systems (CAS) and a program manager for the Smart Internet Technology CRC.
- His early work on relational learning helped to lay the foundations for the field of inductive logic programming (ILP).
- His current interests include conversational agents and robotics, and he has won RoboCup competitions with UNSW teams.
- He is a member of the editorial boards of the Journal of Machine Learning Research, the Machine Learning journal and New Generation Computing.
- He has been involved in RoboCup since 1999 and was appointed as a Trustee of RoboCup in 2012.
- His research interests include machine learning, robotics, user interfaces, software, and applications.
Cleve Moler:
- Cleve Barry Moler is an American mathematician and computer programmer specializing in numerical analysis.
- Moler co-authored LINPACK and EISPACK, Fortran libraries for numerical computing, in the mid to late 1970s.
- He invented MATLAB, a numerical computing package, to give his students at the University of New Mexico easy access to these libraries without writing Fortran.
- In 1984, he co-founded MathWorks with Jack Little to commercialize this program.
- Moler received his bachelor's degree from California Institute of Technology and a Ph.D. from Stanford University.
- He is a professor of mathematics and computer science for almost 20 years at the University of Michigan, Stanford University, and the University of New Mexico.
- Moler is a member of the Association for Computing Machinery and was president of the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics from 2007 to 2008.
- He has authored four textbooks on numerical methods and has been recognized with honorary degrees and awards for his contributions to numerical analysis and software, including the invention of MATLAB.
- Moler was elected a member of the National Academy of Engineering on February 14, 1997.
- In April 2017, he was made a Fellow of the Computer History Museum.
- Publications include "Computer methods for mathematical computations" and "Numerical Computing with MATLAB".
Cliff Jones (computer scientist):
- Clifford "Cliff" B. Jones is a British computer scientist.
- He specializes in research into formal methods.
- He proposed an extension to Hoare logic for handling concurrent programs, rely/guarantee, in his DPhil thesis at Oxford University Computing Laboratory.
- He worked for IBM, where he contributed to the development of the Vienna Development Method (VDM).
- He was a professor at the Victoria University of Manchester.
- He also worked in the industry at Harlequin for a period and is now a Professor of Computing Science at Newcastle University.
- He has been the editor-in-chief of the Formal Aspects of Computing journal.
- He has authored and edited many books, including Understanding Programming Languages, VDM: Une methode rigoureuse pour le development du logiciel, and Systematic Software Development using VDM.
- Jones is also interested in interdisciplinary aspects of computer science and the history of computer science.
Cliff Shaw:
- John Clifford Shaw was a systems programmer at the RAND Corporation.
- He coauthored the first artificial intelligence program, the Logic Theorist.
- He helped develop General Problem Solver and Information Processing Language.
- Shaw is considered the true "father" of the JOSS language.
- He worked with Allen Newell and Herbert A. Simon on the concept of list processing.
- Shaw invented the linked list, which is fundamental in modern computing technology.
Colette Rolland:
- Colette Rolland is a French computer scientist and a Professor of Computer Science at the University of Paris 1 Pantheon-Sorbonne.
- She is a leading researcher in the area of information and knowledge systems, with a focus on meta-modeling, goal modeling, and situational method engineering.
- Rolland studied applied mathematics at the University of Nancy and received her PhD in 1971.
- In 1973, she was appointed Professor at the University of Nancy, Department of Computer Science, and in 1979, she became Professor at the University of Paris 1 Pantheon-Sorbonne, Department of Mathematics and Informatics.
- She has been involved in many European research and cooperative projects with companies.
- Rolland is on the editorial board of several journals and the French representative in IFIP TC8 on Information Systems.
- She has been awarded several prizes, including the IFIP Silver Core, IFIP service award, and the European prize of ‘Information Systems’.
- Rolland's research interests include information modeling, databases, temporal data modeling, object-oriented analysis and design, requirements engineering, and change engineering, among others.
- She has co-authored seven textbooks and authored or co-authored over 280 papers and edited 25 proceedings.
Cornelis H. A. Koster:
- Cornelis Hermanus Antonius Koster was a Dutch computer scientist and professor.
- He was born in Haarlem and moved to Jakarta after the war, but returned to the Netherlands at the age of 11.
- Koster worked at the Mathematisch Centrum in Amsterdam under Adriaan van Wijngaarden and was one of the editors of the original Report on the Algorithmic Language ALGOL 68.
- He became involved in developing international standards in programming and informatics as a member of IFIP Working Group 2.1 on Algorithmic Languages and Calculi.
- Koster created the original Compiler Description Language (CDL) and affix grammars, a variant of Van Wijngaarden grammars.
- He initiated an informatics course at the Technical University of Berlin in 1972 and became the first Professor of Informatics at Radboud University Nijmegen in 1977.
- Koster died in a motorcycle accident in 2013.
Corrado B\u00f6hm:
- Corrado Böhm was a Professor Emeritus at the University of Rome "La Sapienza" and a computer scientist.
- He made contributions to the theory of structured programming, constructive mathematics, combinatory logic, lambda calculus, and functional programming languages.
- In his PhD dissertation, he described a full meta-circular compiler for the first time.
- He co-authored the structured program theorem with Giuseppe Jacopini in 1966.
- He demonstrated the Böhm-Berarducci encoding which established an isomorphism between strictly-positive algebraic data types and polymorphic lambda-terms.
- He established Böhm's theorem, which is an important separation theorem between normal forms in the lambda calculus.
- He received the 2001 EATCS Award for a distinguished career in theoretical computer science.
- He published a number of influential articles, including "Functional Programming and Combinatory algebras".
D. R. Fulkerson:
- Delbert Ray Fulkerson was an American mathematician.
- He co-developed the Ford-Fulkerson algorithm in 1956 with L.R. Ford Jr.
- This algorithm is used to solve the maximum flow problem in networks.
- Fulkerson was born in Tamms, Illinois and studied at Southern Illinois University.
- He served in World War II before returning to complete his degree and later obtaining a Ph.D. in mathematics at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.
- Fulkerson worked at the RAND Corporation and later at Cornell University as the Maxwell Upson Professor of Engineering.
- He was diagnosed with Crohn's disease and committed suicide in 1976.
- The Fulkerson Prize for outstanding papers in discrete mathematics was established in 1979 in his honor.
- Fulkerson also supervised the work of Jon Folkman at RAND and Tatsuo Oyama at GRIPS.
- See also: Out-of-kilter algorithm, List of people diagnosed with Crohn's disease.
DJ Patil:
- Dhanurjay Patil, also known as DJ Patil, is an American mathematician and computer scientist.
- He was the Chief Data Scientist of the United States Office of Science and Technology Policy from 2015 to 2017.
- He is currently the Head of Technology for Devoted Health.
- Patil has worked at LinkedIn, Greylock Partners, Skype, PayPal, and eBay.
- In 2004, he worked in the Department of Defense on the Threat Anticipation Project.
- He has written two books: "Building Data Science Teams" and "Data Jujitsu -- The Art of Turning Data into Product."
- Patil helped launch the White House's Police Data Initiative and the White House's Data-Driven Justice Initiative.
- The Police Data Initiative aimed to build trust between the police and their communities by releasing data sets on police actions, and the Data-Driven Justice Initiative aimed to filter low-risk and low-level offenders from the criminal system.
- Patil supported the Precision Medicine Initiative, aimed at building the largest database of genomic information to improve medical treatments.
- In 2017, Patil joined Devoted Health and Venrock.
Dan Ingalls:
- Daniel Henry Holmes Ingalls Jr. is a pioneer in object-oriented computer programming and the principal architect of five generations of Smalltalk environments.
- Ingalls designed the bytecoded virtual machine that made Smalltalk practical in 1976, invented bit blit, which underlies most bitmap computer graphics systems today, and pop-up menus.
- Ingalls has made major contributions to the Squeak version of Smalltalk, including developing the original concept of a Smalltalk written in itself and made portable and efficient by a Smalltalk-to-C translator.
- Ingalls received a B.A. in physics from Harvard University and an M.S. in electrical engineering from Stanford University but did not complete his Ph.D. at Stanford as he started a company to sell a software measurement invention he perfected.
- Ingalls received several awards, including the ACM Grace Murray Hopper Award for Outstanding Young Scientist in 1984 and the ACM Software System Award in 1987 for his work on Smalltalk.
- In addition to his work on Smalltalk, Ingalls also developed an optical character recognition system for Devanagari writing in collaboration with his father, a professor of Sanskrit.
- Ingalls currently consults and lives in Manhattan Beach, California, with his wife.
- Ingalls' most recent project is a JavaScript environment named Lively Kernel, which allows live, interactive web programming and objects from inside web browsers.
Dan Jurafsky:
- Daniel Jurafsky is a professor of linguistics and computer science at Stanford University
- He is known for developing the first automatic system for semantic role labeling (SRL) with Daniel Gildea
- Jurafsky is the author of The Language of Food: A Linguist Reads the Menu and a textbook on speech and language processing
- He received his B.A in linguistics and Ph.D. in computer science, both from UC Berkeley, and a postdoc at ICSI, Berkeley
- Jurafsky received a MacArthur Fellowship in 2002 and other honors and awards, including being a LSA Fellow and receiving the Atkinson Prizes in Psychological and Cognitive Sciences
- He lives in San Francisco, California.
Dana Scott:
- Dana Stewart Scott is an American logician and university professor.
- He earned his B.A. in Mathematics from the University of California, Berkeley and his Ph.D. from Princeton under Alonzo Church.
- He is best known for his contributions to automata theory, modal logic, topology, and category theory.
- He introduced the idea of nondeterministic machines to automata theory and, together with Michael O. Rabin, received the Turing Award in 1976 for this work.
- He worked at the University of California, Berkeley, the University of Chicago, the University of Oxford, and Carnegie Mellon University.
- He collaborated with Christopher Strachey to provide a mathematical foundation for the semantics of programming languages, which became the Scott-Strachey approach to denotational semantics.
- His contributions to theoretical computer science led to numerous awards, including the 1997 Rolf Schock Prize in logic and philosophy and the 2007 EATCS Award.
- He proposed the theory of equilogical spaces as a successor theory to domain theory.
- His publications include "Finite Automata and Their Decision Problem," "An Introduction to Modal Logic," and "Continuous Lattices and Domains."
Danese Cooper:
- Danese Cooper is an American programmer and computer scientist
- She has managed teams at Symantec and Apple Inc
- Cooper served as chief open source "evangelist" for six years at Sun Microsystems before moving on to senior director for open source strategies at Intel
- She is a board member of the Open Source Hardware Association and a board observer at Mozilla
- In February 2010 Cooper was appointed Chief Technical Officer of the Wikimedia Foundation but left in July 2011
- Cooper is the founder and chair of the InnerSource Commons Foundation
- She started a consultancy, daneseWorks, in June 2011
- Cooper obtained her high school diploma from Chadwick School and her B.A. from the University of California, Los Angeles and spent time in Morocco as a volunteer in the Peace Corps.
Daniel J. Bernstein:
- Daniel Julius Bernstein is a mathematician, cryptologist, and computer scientist
- He is a visiting professor at CASA at Ruhr University Bochum and a research professor of Computer Science at the University of Illinois at Chicago. 
- He used to be a professor in the department of mathematics and computer science at the Eindhoven University of Technology.
- Bernstein brought the court case Bernstein v. United States, which declared that software was protected speech under the First Amendment and contributed to regulatory changes reducing controls on encryption.
- Bernstein designed the Salsa20 and ChaCha20 stream ciphers along with the elliptic curve Curve25519 and worked as the lead researcher on the Ed25519 version of EdDSA, which made their way into popular software.
- Bernstein has written multiple security-aware programs, including qmail, ezmlm, djbdns, ucspi-tcp, daemontools, and publicfile.
- He proposed Internet Mail 2000, an alternative system for electronic mail, intended to replace the Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP), the Post Office Protocol (POP3) and the Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP)
- Bernstein has published numerous papers on mathematics and computation, including proposing the use of a twisted Edwards curve, Curve25519, as a basis for elliptic curve cryptography.
- In 2004, Bernstein taught a course on computer software security where he assigned each student to find ten vulnerabilities in published software.
Daniel P. Friedman:
- Daniel Paul Friedman is a professor of Computer Science at Indiana University in Bloomington
- His research focuses on programming languages and he is a prominent author in the field
- He wrote a highly influential paper on lazy programming with David Wise, exploring a programming style with potentially infinite data structures and no computational effects
- In the 1980s, he focused on studying the Scheme programming language and explored the use of macros
- He is a prolific textbook author, writing several "little" books, including The Little Schemer, which is still in its fourth edition
- He is also the lead author of Essentials of Programming Languages, a widely used textbook on programming languages
- Recently, he has resumed work on his "Little" series with The Reasoned Schemer and The Little Prover
- He has authored or co-authored several books, including Coordinated Computing: Tools and Techniques for Distributed Software and The Little Typer
- His work has had a significant impact on the study of programming languages, including the use of operational semantics and type theory in textbooks.
Daniel Siewiorek:
- Daniel P. Siewiorek is an American computer engineer and computer scientist.
- He is currently the Buhl University Professor Emeritus of Electrical and Computer Engineering and Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University.
- His research focuses on electronic design automation, reliability computing, and context aware mobile computing.
- He has designed or been involved with the design of nine multiprocessor systems, and contributed to the dependability design of over two dozen commercial computing systems.
- He has written nine textbooks and over 475 papers.
- He served as Director of Carnegie Mellon University's Quality of Life Technology NSF Engineering Research Center and Department Head of the Human Computer Interaction Institute.
- He was the former Chairman of the IEEE Technical Committee on Fault-Tolerant Computing and founding Chairman of the IEEE Technical Committee on Wearable Information Systems.
- He is the recipient of the AAEE Terman Award, the IEEE/ACM Eckert–Mauchly Award, and the ACM SIGMOBILE Outstanding Contributions Award.
- He was awarded the IEEE Computer Society Taylor L. Booth Education Award in February 2018.
- He is a Fellow of IEEE, ACM, and AAAS, and was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 2000.
- He received his B.A. from the University of Michigan and his M.A. and Ph.D. from Stanford University, all in Electrical Engineering.
Daniel Sleator:
- Daniel Dominic Kaplan Sleator is a Professor of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University.
- He won the ACM Paris Kanellakis Award in 1999 for the splay tree data structure.
- Sleator was a pioneer in amortized analysis of algorithms, and he developed many data structures with Robert Tarjan.
- He invented link/cut trees, splay trees, and skew heaps.
- He developed the theory of link grammars and the Serioso music analyzer.
- Sleator's paper on the move-to-front heuristic suggested the idea of competitive analysis.
- He commercialized the Internet Chess Server into the Internet Chess Club.
- He is the younger brother of William Sleator, a science fiction writer.
- From 2003 to 2008, he co-hosted the talk show Left Out on WRCT-FM.
- He is an active member of the competitive programming platform Codeforces.
Daniel Thalmann:
- Prof. Daniel Thalmann is a Swiss and Canadian computer scientist and a pioneer in virtual humans.
- He is currently an Honorary Professor at EPFL, Switzerland and Director of Research Development at MIRALab Sarl in Geneva, Switzerland.
- Thalmann earned a PhD in Computer Science from the University of Geneva in 1977 and was a Professor at the University of Montreal from 1977 to 1989.
- He founded the virtual reality lab (VRlab) at EPFL, Switzerland and has been a Visiting Professor/ Researcher at several universities worldwide.
- Thalmann has published more than 650 papers in graphics, animation, and virtual reality and is the co-editor-in-chief of the Journal of Computer Animation and Virtual Worlds.
- His research focuses on realistic computer modelling and rendering of the human form, in motion, as well as behavioural animation of virtual humans and crowd simulation.
- Thalmann coined the term Virtual Rehabilitation with Professor Grigore Burdea of Rutgers University and is a founder of the International Society of Virtual Rehabilitation.
- He has received several awards and honors, including the Eurographics Distinguished Career Award in 2010 and the 2015 CGI Career Achievement Award.
- Thalmann directed the short film Rendez-vous in Montreal, which is widely regarded as the first computer film to employ synthetic actors.
Darrell Long:
- Darrell Don Earl Long is a computer scientist and computer engineer.
- He is the Kumar Malavalli Endowed Chair of Storage Systems Research and Distinguished Professor of Engineering at the University of California, Santa Cruz.
- Long was the founder of the Conference on File and Storage Technologies in 2002.
- He did his undergraduate studies at San Diego State University and received his Ph.D. from the University of California, San Diego.
- Long's research interests include computer data storage, operating systems, distributed computing, and computer security.
- He has worked on metadata for exascale file systems, data deduplication, and web caching.
- Long is a fellow of both the IEEE and the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
David A. Bader:
- David A. Bader is a Distinguished Professor and Director of the Institute for Data Science at the New Jersey Institute of Technology.
- He previously served as the Chair of the Georgia Institute of Technology School of Computational Science & Engineering and the executive director of High-Performance Computing at the Georgia Tech College of Computing.
- Bader is an expert in the design and analysis of parallel and multicore algorithms for real-world applications such as those in cybersecurity and computational biology.
- His main areas of research are at the intersection of high-performance computing and real-world applications, including cybersecurity, massive-scale analytics, and computational genomics.
- Bader built the first Linux supercomputer using commodity processors and a high-speed interconnection network.
- Bader has received awards from IBM, Microsoft Research, Nvidia, Facebook, Intel, Accenture, and Sony.
- Bader is an IEEE Fellow, an AAAS Fellow, SIAM Fellow, and an ACM Fellow.
- Bader has served on numerous conference program committees related to parallel processing and has edited numerous journals.
- In 2019, Bader joined the New Jersey Institute of Technology as a Distinguished Professor in the Ying Wu College of Computing Sciences and was named the first director of the school's new Institute for Data Science.
- Bader is credited with the development of the first Linux supercomputer using commodity parts.
- Bader has one child, Sadie "Sage" Rose, who is an avid artist.
David A. Wagner:
- David A. Wagner is a professor of computer science at the University of California, Berkeley
- He is a well-known researcher in cryptography and computer security
- Wagner is a member of the Election Assistance Commission's Technical Guidelines Development Committee and the ACCURATE project
- He received an A.B. in mathematics and a Ph.D. in computer science from Berkeley
- Wagner has published two books and over 90 peer-reviewed scientific papers
- Wagner served as a principal investigator for the source code review and documentation review of the California state Top-to-Bottom review of electronic voting systems certified for use
- He has made notable achievements in cryptanalysis, including the discovery of flaws in WEP, A5/1, and Microsoft's PPTP tunnelling protocol
- Wagner was involved in the development of the Twofish block cipher, which was a finalist for NIST's Advanced Encryption Standard competition
- He also discovered a flaw in the implementation of SSL in Netscape Navigator in 1995.
David Blei:
- David Meir Blei is a professor at Columbia University in the Statistics and Computer Science departments.
- He was previously an associate professor at Princeton University.
- His research interests are primarily in machine learning, particularly in topic models.
- Blei was involved in the development of latent Dirichlet allocation, along with Andrew Ng and Michael I. Jordan.
- As of June 2020, his publications have been cited 109,821 times with an h-index of 97.
- Blei received the ACM Infosys Foundation Award in 2013 for computer scientists under the age of 45.
- He was named Fellow of ACM in 2015 for his contributions to probabilistic topic modeling and Bayesian machine learning.
David C. Evans:
- David Cannon Evans was the founder of the computer science department at the University of Utah and co-founder of Evans & Sutherland, a computer graphics hardware company.
- He earned his Bachelor of Science in Physics and Doctorate in Physics from the University of Utah.
- Evans worked at Bendix aviation electronics company as a project manager where he developed an early personal computer called Bendix G-15.
- He became a faculty member at the University of California, Berkeley where he did several experiments on an IDIOM display hooked up to a Digital Equipment Corporation PDP-5.
- In 1963, he was co-Principal Investigator for project Genie to produce an early multi-user timesharing system, which included key developments in virtual memory.
- He was a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints and was awarded the Silver Beaver for his role in scouting.
- His students at the University of Utah included Alan Kay, Edwin Catmull, John Warnock, and Henri Gouraud.
- Brigham Young University established the David C. Evans Chair of Computer Engineering and Graphics in his honor.
- Evans had ten children, only seven of which lived to adulthood, and passed away in 1998 due to Alzheimer's disease.
David Canfield Smith:
- David Canfield Smith is a computer scientist known for inventing computer icons and programming by demonstration.
- His primary focus has been on human-com
David F. Bacon:
- David Bacon is an American computer programmer.
- He began working as a programmer at age 16 and worked for a startup during his senior year of high school.
- At Columbia College, he worked on the NON-VON supercomputer and then on network algorithms and simulation.
- He spent most of his career at IBM's Thomas J. Watson Research Center, where he worked on garbage collection and became a Principal Research Staff Member.
- He was inducted as an ACM Fellow for contributions to real-time systems and to object-oriented language design and implementation.
- His work on garbage collection has been used in various programming languages, including PHP.
- He joined Google in 2014 and is currently a Principal Engineer working on the Spanner distributed database system.
David Gelernter:
- David Hillel Gelernter is an American computer scientist, artist, and writer.
- He is a professor of computer science at Yale University.
- Gelernter made seminal contributions to the field of parallel computation in the 1980s, specifically the tuple space coordination model, as embodied by the Linda programming system he and Nicholas Carriero designed.
- Gelernter is also known for his views on topics such as computed worlds and his belief that liberal academia and women in the workforce have a destructive influence on American society.
- He is a former national fellow at the American Enterprise Institute and senior fellow in Jewish thought at the Shalem Center.
- Gelernter has written several books, including Americanism: The Fourth Great Western Religion and America-Lite: How Imperial Academia Dismantled Our Culture (and Ushered in the Obamacrats).
- In 1993, Gelernter was almost killed by a mail bomb sent by the Unabomber, leaving him with permanent loss of use of his right hand and damage to his right eye.
- Gelernter's paintings have been exhibited, sold, stolen, and recovered in New Haven and Manhattan.
- Gelernter has rejected the scientific consensus regarding anthropogenic climate change and evolution.
- He has contributed to magazines such as City Journal, The Weekly Standard, and Commentary, and has published in The Wall Street Journal, the New York Post, the Los Angeles Times, and the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung.
David H. D. Warren:
- David H. D. Warren is a computer scientist.
- He worked on logic programming, particularly Prolog in the 1970s and 1980s.
- Warren wrote the first compiler for Prolog.
- The Warren Abstract Machine execution environment for Prolog is named after him.
- He received a Ph.D. in artificial intelligence from the University of Edinburgh in 1977.
- Warren worked for the Artificial Intelligence Center at SRI International in the 1980s.
- He founded Quintus Computer Systems in 1983 with others to commercialize the Prolog compiler.
- Quintus was sold to Intergraph Corporation in 1989.
- Warren also worked at the University of Bristol Department of Computer Science.
David J. Brown (computer scientist):
- David James Brown is an American computer scientist.
- He helped develop the SUN workstation system at Stanford University, which later resulted in Sun Microsystems.
- He was a co-founder of Silicon Graphics in 1982.
- Brown studied at the University of Pennsylvania, Moore School of Electrical Engineering, and received a B.S.E. degree in 1979 and an M.S.E. in 1980.
- He pursued a Ph.D. degree at the University of Cambridge, England, and his dissertation introduced the concept of Unified Memory Architecture.
- Brown worked for Digital Equipment Corporation and helped build the group responsible for introducing the DECstation line of computer systems.
- He joined Sun Microsystems in 1992 and helped establish the process for the company's system software architecture.
- Brown later worked on Solaris's adoption of open-source software and technologies for energy-efficient computing.
- He was elected to the Council of the Association for Computing Machinery in 1998 and became a founding editor of the ACM Queue magazine in 2003.
David Korn (computer scientist):
- David G. Korn is an American UNIX programmer.
- He is the author of the Korn shell (ksh), a command line interface/programming language.
- Korn received his Ph.D. in applied mathematics from NYU's Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences.
- He worked at Bell Laboratories in 1976 and developed Korn shell in response to problems with Bourne shell and C shell.
- The Korn shell was backward-compatible with Bourne shell and incorporated a choice of editing styles.
- Microsoft once included a version of the Korn shell produced by Mortice Kern Systems (MKS) in a UNIX integration package for Windows NT.
- Korn is also known as the creator of UWIN, an X/Open library for Win32 systems, and sfio, a library for managing I/O streams.
- He became a Bell Labs fellow in 1984 and worked for AT&T Labs Research until 2013.
- Korn retired from Google in early February 2018.
- His parents were Florence and Nathaniel Korn, and he married Susan Lyn Weiner in 1967.
- Korn's son Adam used to work at Goldman Sachs.
David Liddle:
- David Liddle is a co-founder of Interval Research Corporation and a consulting professor of computer science at Stanford University.

- He played a leading role in the development of the Xerox Star computer system while working at Xerox PARC.

- In 1982 he co-founded Metaphor Computer Systems.

- He has served on the board of many corporations.

- Liddle was also the chair of the board of trustees of the Santa Fe Institute from 1994 to 1999.

- He has a B.S. in computer science from the University of Michigan and a Ph.D. in EECS from the University of Toledo.

- In January 2012, he joined the board of directors of SRI International.
David P. Anderson:
- David Pope Anderson is an American research scientist and adjunct professor of computer science.
- He leads the SETI@home, BOINC, Bossa, and Bolt software projects.
- Anderson received a BA in mathematics and MS and PhD degrees in mathematics and computer science.
- He invented "Virtual Reality Television" and received a patent for it in 1996.
- Anderson created the Berkeley Open Infrastructure for Network Computing project in 2002.
- BOINC is used by about 100 projects, including SETI@home, Einstein@home, and Climateprediction.net.
- Anderson was involved in Stardust@home, Bossa, and Bolt. 
- The Berkeley Open System for Skill Aggregation (BOSSA) is a software framework for distributed thinking.
David P. Reed:
- David Patrick Reed is a computer scientist from the US.
- He was educated at MIT and has made significant contributions to computer networking and wireless communications networks.
- He was involved in early development of TCP/IP and designed the User Datagram Protocol (UDP).
- Reed is one of the authors of the paper "End-to-End arguments in system design".
- He is known for Reed's Law, which asserts that social networks can scale exponentially with size.
- From 2003 to 2010, he was an adjunct professor at MIT and co-led the Viral Communications group and Communication Futures program.
- He is currently a senior vice president at SAP Labs and on the advisory board of TTI/Vanguard.
- His 1978 dissertation introduced multiversion concurrency control (MVCC), a method for concurrent access to databases and transactional memory.
David Park (computer scientist):
- David Michael Ritchie Park is a British computer scientist.
- He worked on the first implementation of the programming language Lisp.
- He focused on topics such as fairness, program schemas and bisimulation in concurrent computing.
- He was one of the earliest members of the computer science department at the University of Warwick.
- He served as chairperson at the University of Warwick.
- He died on September 29, 1990.
- More information is available on the Mathematics Genealogy Project website.
David Parnas:
- David Lorge Parnas is a Canadian pioneer of software engineering.
- He developed the concept of information hiding in modular programming.
- He earned his PhD in electrical engineering at Carnegie Mellon University.
- Parnas taught at various universities including University of North Carolina, Technische Universität Darmstadt, and Queen's University.
- Parnas received various awards and honors for his work, including ACM "Best Paper" award and fellowships in several organizations.
- He is a proponent of precise documentation and ethics in software engineering.
- Parnas took a stand against the US Strategic Defense Initiative and advocated for professionalization of software engineering.
- He criticized the number-of-publications-based approach towards ranking academic production.
- His seminal paper "On the Criteria to Be Used in Decomposing Systems into Modules" introduced the concept of high cohesion and loose coupling in modular design.
David Patterson (computer scientist):
- David Andrew Patterson is an American computer pioneer and academic
- He has held the position of professor of computer science at the University of California, Berkeley since 1976
- Patterson coined the term RISC and led the Berkeley RISC project, with 99% of all new chips using a RISC architecture as of 2018
- He also led the research on redundant arrays of inexpensive disks (RAID) storage with Randy Katz
- His books on computer architecture are widely used in computer science education
- Patterson has advised several notable Ph.D. students like David Ditzel and Garth A. Gibson
- He has won numerous awards for research, teaching, and service, including the Turing Award for developing RISC
- Patterson is also involved in charitable work and has participated in fundraising events for the Waves to Wine MS charity from 2003 to 2012
David S. Johnson:
- David Stifler Johnson was an American computer scientist who specialized in algorithms and optimization.
- He was the head of the Algorithms and Optimization Department of AT&T Labs Research from 1988 to 2013.
- He was also a visiting professor at Columbia University from 2014 to 2016.
- He was awarded the 2010 Knuth Prize.
- Johnson was born in Washington D.C. in 1945 and earned his degrees in Mathematics from Amherst College and MIT.
- He was inducted as a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery and a member of the National Academy of Engineering.
- He was the coauthor of Computers and Intractability: A Guide to the Theory of NP-Completeness.
- Johnson's publications have been cited over 96,000 times, and he has an h-index of 78.
- He died on March 8, 2016, at the age of 70.
- See also: NP-completeness, List of computer scientists, and List of important publications in computer science.
David Turner (computer scientist):
- David A. Turner is a British computer scientist known for designing and implementing three programming languages
- The languages are SASL (1972), Kent Recursive Calculator (KRC) (1981), and Miranda (1985)
- Miranda had a strong influence on later programming language Haskell
- Turner has a Doctor of Philosophy from the University of Oxford
- He has held professorships at Queen Mary College, London, University of Texas at Austin, and the University of Kent at Canterbury
- Turner was involved in developing international standards in programming and informatics as a member of the International Federation for Information Processing
- He is also an Emeritus Professor at Middlesex University
- Turner has authored several publications on programming languages and implementation techniques
David Waltz:
- David Leigh Waltz was a computer scientist
- He made significant contributions in several areas of artificial intelligence
- He held positions in academia and industry
- He was a professor of Computer Science at Columbia University at the time of his death
- He received S.B., M.S., and Ph.D. degrees in Electrical Engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)
- His Ph.D. dissertation initiated the field of constraint propagation
- He worked on new methods for information retrieval involving comparisons to large amounts of data
- He originated the field of memory-based reasoning branch of case-based reasoning
- His research interests included massively parallel information retrieval, data mining, learning and automatic classification with applications in protein structure prediction, natural language processing, and machine learning applications applied to the electric power grid.
- He served as president of the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence (AAAI) from 1997 to 1999
- He was elected a Fellow of Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence (AAAI) in 1990 and a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery in 1998
- He died from brain cancer on March 22, 2012, at the age of 68.
David Wheeler (computer scientist):
- David John Wheeler was a computer scientist and professor of computer science at the University of Cambridge.
- He was born in Birmingham in 1927 and studied at Trinity College, Cambridge, where he was awarded the world's first PhD in computer science in 1951.
- Wheeler's contributions to the field included work on EDSAC in the 1950s and the Burrows–Wheeler transform (published 1994). He also contributed to the invention of the subroutine and the design of software libraries.
- He was responsible for the implementation of the CAP computer, the first to be based on security capabilities, and was involved in cryptography, designing the WAKE encryption algorithm.
- He married astrophysics research student Joyce Margaret Blackler in 1957 and had two daughters and a son.
- Wheeler was recognised with numerous awards and inducted as a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery.
- He is often quoted as saying "All problems in computer science can be solved by another level of indirection." and "Compatibility means deliberately repeating other people's mistakes."
- Wheeler died of a heart attack in 2004 while cycling home from the Computer Laboratory.
Dennis E. Wisnosky:
-Dennis E. Wisnosky is an American consultant, writer, and former chief architect and chief technical officer of the US DoD Business Mission Area
-He is known for being one of the creators and initiators of the Integrated Definition (IDEFs) language, a standard for modeling and analysis in management and business improvement efforts. 
-Wisnosky received his bachelor's degree in physics and mathematics from California University of Pennsylvania, a master's in management science from the University of Dayton, and a master's in electrical engineering from the University of Pittsburgh.
-He founded Wizdom Systems in 1986 and later became the Chief Technical Officer for the Department of Defense (DoD) in August 2006
-Wisnosky has published over 100 papers and authored or co-authored seven books 
-He is a frequent speaker on service-oriented architecture (SOA) and semantic technologies and has testified before subcommittees of both the U.S. House and Senate on U.S. productivity issues and the quality of American work life.
Dennis Ritchie:
- Dennis Ritchie was an American computer scientist known for creating the C programming language and Unix operating system.
- He worked at the Bell Labs Computing Sciences Research Center and was involved in the development of multics operating system.
- Ritchie and his long-time colleague Ken Thompson were awarded the Turing Award in 1983, the Hamming Medal in 1990, and the National Medal of Technology in 1999.
- Ritchie passed away in 2011 due to prostate cancer and heart disease, and his legacy is recognized in the widespread use of C and Unix in modern programming.
- He authored or contributed to about 50 academic papers, books, and textbooks and had over 15,000 citations.
- Asteroid 294727 Dennisritchie was named in his memory, and Fedora 16 and FreeBSD 9.0 were dedicated to his memory.
Derek McAuley:
- Derek Robert McAuley is a British academic and Professor of Digital Economy at the University of Nottingham.
- He is also the director of Horizon Digital Economy Research, an interdisciplinary research institute.
- He has acted as a Specialist Advisor to the House of Lords European Union Committee and Chief Innovation Officer for the Digital Catapult.
- McAuley has a PhD in computer science from Cambridge University and has held academic positions at the universities of Glasgow and Cambridge.
- He also has industry experience, including co-founding the Cambridge Microsoft Research facility and founding Intel Research Cambridge.
- His current research focuses on ubiquitous computing, computer architecture, networking, distributed systems, and operating systems.
- McAuley is also interested in interdisciplinary issues related to ethics, privacy, information policy, legislation, and economics in a digital society.
- He is a Fellow of the British Computer Society and a member of the UKCRC.
Donald Firesmith:
- Donald G. Firesmith is an American software engineer, consultant, and trainer at the Software Engineering Institute.
- He received his B.A. in Mathematics and German from Linfield College and his M.A. in Mathematics from Arizona State University.
- Firesmith has worked as a software developer, quality engineer, configuration manager, and data manager for various companies.
- He was President of Advanced Software Technology Specialists and an acquisition editor and editor in chief of reference books at SIGS Books.
- Firesmith was named a Distinguished Engineer by the Association of Computing Machinery in 2015.
- He is a co-founder of the international OPEN Consortium and the principle developer of the OPEN Modeling Language.
- Firesmith is the founder of the OPEN Process Framework Repository Organization and the primary developer of the Method Framework for Engineering System Architectures (MFESA).
- He has authored several technical books in system and software engineering and many technical articles, conference papers, and tutorials.
- Firesmith is also a novelist and has written several paranormal fantasy, apocalyptic science fiction, action, and adventure novels.
Donald Knuth:
- Donald Knuth is an American computer scientist, mathematician, and professor emeritus at Stanford University.
- He is the 1974 recipient of the ACM Turing Award, informally considered the Nobel Prize of computer science.
- Knuth has been called the "father of the analysis of algorithms" and is the author of the multi-volume work The Art of Computer Programming.
- He created the TeX computer typesetting system, the related METAFONT font definition language and rendering system, and the Computer Modern family of typefaces.
- Knuth created the WEB and CWEB computer programming systems designed to encourage and facilitate literate programming, and designed the MIX/MMIX instruction set architectures.
- Knuth strongly opposes the granting of software patents, having expressed his opinion to the United States Patent and Trademark Office and European Patent Organisation.
- Knuth is a writer and has written books on computer science and mathematics, as well as Surreal Numbers, a mathematical novelette on John Conway's set theory construction of an alternate system of numbers.
- Knuth is an organist and a composer.
- Knuth was diagnosed with prostate cancer in 2006 and underwent surgery.
- Knuth is known for his humor, which includes paying a finder's fee for typographical errors in his books, intentionally referring to circular definitions in the index of his books, and proposing a satirical XML-based successor to TeX called "iTeX".
- Knuth has received various awards and honors, including the Turing Award, the National Medal of Science, and the Kyoto Prize. He is a member of multiple academies of science and engineering.
Dora Metcalf:
- Dora Stuart Primrose Metcalf was an entrepreneur, mathematician and computing pioneer.
- She was born in Madras (now Chennai) in India to Irish parents and was the oldest of three children.
- She won a scholarship to take an external degree with the University of London when she was 15 years old and obtained her Bachelor's degree in mathematics by the age of 19.
- During World War I, she worked as a comptometer operator in a munitions factory and realised the potential of mechanical calculators.
- In 1916, she was sent to Belfast to introduce comptometers into the shipyard offices and set up offices in Dublin and Cork in 1917.
- In 1924, she founded Calculating And Statistical Services (CSS), which she ran successfully and provided international markets for information services using comptometers and tabulators.
- She joined British Tabulating Machine Company (BTM) in 1934 and founded the Service Bureaux Division, while continuing to run CSS.
- During World War II, BTM supplied "bombe" decryption machines to the codebreakers at Bletchley Park in England, and Metcalf was in charge of managing the supply contract but had to leave due to ill health.
- She introduced the first electronic computer into Ireland in 1957 and retired in 1962.
- She enjoyed fishing for salmon and trout with her husband, Commander John Savile Dent Metcalf, and they spent their final years in Otley in Yorkshire.
- Dora Metcalf died in 1982 at the age of 90 and was buried in the Lawnswood Cemetery and Crematorium in Leeds in West Yorkshire.
Dorothy Blum:
- Dorothy Toplitzky Blum was an American computer scientist and cryptanalyst.
- She worked for the National Security Agency (NSA) and its predecessors from 1944 until her death in 1980.
- She was born in 1924 in New York City to Austro-Hungarian immigrant parents.
- After graduating from Brooklyn College in 1944, she joined the cryptologic unit of the U.S. Army.
- During her time at the NSA in the 1950s, Blum recommended computer technologies that could be adapted for cryptanalysis and communications intelligence, including using the FORTRAN programming language before its public release.
- Blum continued to work in computer science throughout the 1960s and 1970s, helping to design the NSA's computer systems and automate processes.
- Blum died from cancer in 1980, aged 56. 
- The Dorothy T Blum Award for excellence in employee personal and professional development was named after her.
- In 2004, she was inducted into the NSA Hall of Honor.
- She was married to NSA mathematician Joseph Blum and had one son, David Blum.
Dorothy E. Denning:
- Dorothy Elizabeth Denning is an American information security researcher.
- She is known for her work on lattice-based access control (LBAC), intrusion detection systems (IDS), and other cybersecurity innovations.
- She has published four books and over 200 articles throughout her career.
- Denning was inducted into the National Cyber Security Hall of Fame in 2012.
- She is now Emeritus Distinguished Professor of Defense Analysis at the Naval Postgraduate School.
- Denning earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in mathematics in 1967 followed by a Master of Arts degree in 1969 at the University of Michigan.
- She received her PhD from Purdue University in 1975, her thesis focusing on secure information flow in computer systems.
- Denning began her academic career as an assistant professor at Purdue University, then held positions at SRI International, Digital Equipment Corporation, and Georgetown University before joining the Naval Postgraduate School.
- Her key innovations in computer security include the development of intrusion detection systems, encryption technology, and multilevel database security techniques.
- Denning was involved in the controversial Clipper chip initiative to give the government authorized access to encrypted private communications through a key escrow system.
- She has received over 20 awards for her contributions to computer security and was named an ACM Fellow, an ISSA distinguished fellow, and a fellow of the International Information Security Certification Consortium.
- Denning and her husband, Peter J. Denning, were married in 1974 while she was working on her PhD at Purdue University.
Dorothy Vaughan:
- Dorothy Jean Johnson Vaughan was an American mathematician and human computer who worked for NACA and NASA.
- In 1949, she became the first African-American woman to receive a promotion and supervise a group of staff at the center.
- During her 28-year career, Vaughan prepared for the introduction of computers in the early 1960s by teaching herself and her staff the programming language of Fortran.
- Vaughan is featured in Margot Lee Shetterly's book, Hidden Figures, and the film of the same name.
- Vaughan was posthumously awarded the Congressional Gold Medal in 2019 and had a lunar crater and a satellite named after her.
Douglas Comer:
- Douglas Earl Comer is a professor of computer science at Purdue University.
- He is an internationally recognized authority on TCP/IP and internetworking.
- Comer designed and implemented X25NET and Cypress networks, and the Xinu operating system.
- Xinu has been expanded and ported to a wide variety of platforms and used by companies like Motorola and Hewlett-Packard.
- Comer has authored numerous research papers and textbooks, including a three-volume series on Internetworking With TCP/IP.
- He has received numerous teaching awards and is a Fellow of the ACM.
- Comer has also received research grants for various projects related to communication and networks.
- He has won several awards, including the Usenix "The Flame" Lifetime Achievement Award and has been inducted into the Internet Hall of Fame.
Douglas Lenat:
- Douglas Bruce Lenat is the CEO of Cycorp, Inc. and a prominent researcher in artificial intelligence.
- He received the IJCAI Computers and Thought Award in 1976 for his creation of the machine-learning program AM.
- Lenat has worked on symbolic machine learning, knowledge representation, cognitive economy, blackboard systems, and ontological engineering.
- He has also worked on military simulations and numerous projects for US government, military, intelligence, and scientific organizations.
- Lenat is a Fellow of the AAAS, AAAI, and Cognitive Science Society, and an editor of several journals.
- He was one of the founders of TTI/Vanguard in 1991 and remains a member of its advisory board.
- Lenat earned his bachelor's and master's degrees from the University of Pennsylvania and his Ph.D. from Stanford University.
- Lenat's thesis, AM, was one of the first computer programs that attempted to make discoveries.
- Lenat called for a vast knowledge base of "common sense" and an inference engine capable of finding deep conclusions and arguments to make progress toward real, general, symbolic AI.
- Lenat was principal scientist of the MCC research consortium and moved to Cycorp in 1994.
- He estimates that completing Cyc would require at least 250,000 rules and 1,000 person-years of effort, but the team has spent about 2,000 person-years of effort building Cyc.
- Lenat continues his work on Cyc as CEO of Cycorp and has applied it to various fields, including education.
- Lenat has authored several papers and books, including "Building Large Knowledge-Based Systems: Representation and Inference in the Cyc Project."
Douglas McIlroy:
- Malcolm Douglas McIlroy is a mathematician, engineer, and programmer
- He proposed Unix pipelines and developed several Unix tools such as spell, diff, sort, join, graph, speak, and tr
- He was one of the pioneering researchers of macro processors and programming language extensibility
- McIlroy participated in the design of multiple programming languages, particularly PL/I, SNOBOL, ALTRAN, TMG, and C++
- He is a pioneer of component-based software engineering and software product line engineering
- McIlroy earned his bachelor's degree from Cornell University and a Ph.D. from MIT
- He worked at Bell Laboratories from 1958 to 1997 and was head of its Computing Techniques Research Department
- McIlroy is considered a pioneer of macro processors, and his contributions to Unix had a lasting impact on modern operating systems
- He has won multiple awards for his lifetime achievements and was elected as a member of the National Academy of Engineering
- McIlroy has also made significant contributions to the field's algorithms, particularly sorting techniques
Douglas T. Ross:
- Douglas Taylor "Doug" Ross was an American computer scientist pioneer and chairman of SofTech, Inc.

- He originated the term CAD for computer-aided design.

- Ross is considered to be the father of Automatically Programmed Tools (APT), a programming language to drive numerical control in manufacturing.

- His later work focused on a pseudophilosophy he developed and named Plex.

- Ross contributed to the MIT Whirlwind I computer project, which was the first to display real-time text and graphics.

- Ross helped develop Structured Analysis into the IDEF0 method for the Air Force's Integrated Computer-Aided Manufacturing (ICAM) program's IDEF suite of analysis and design methods.

- He was an early developer of structured analysis methods and a founding member of Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM).

- Ross was a member of IFIP Working Group 2.1 on Algorithmic Languages and Calculi, which specified, maintains, and supports the programming languages ALGOL 60 and ALGOL 68.

- Ross died on January 31, 2007, after a long battle with Parkinson's Disease.
Dragomir R. Radev:
- Dragomir R. Radev is a Yale University professor of computer science.
- He has worked on natural language processing and information retrieval, as well as NLP in Bioinformatics, Social Network Analysis and Political Science.
- Radev received his PhD from Columbia University in 1999.
- He is the secretary of [1] (2006–present) and associate editor of JAIR.
- Radev has received awards such as the Gosnell Prize (2006) and the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) Fellow (2015) for contributions to natural language processing and computational linguistics.
- He has coached and led the US national team in the International Linguistics Olympiad (IOL) to several gold medals.
- Radev has published books including Puzzles in Logic, Languages and Computation (2013) and Graph-based Methods for NLP and IR (2011).
- His selected papers cover topics such as natural language processing, text summarization, and gene-disease associations.
- External links include news articles and award recognition for Radev's work.
E. Allen Emerson:
- E. Allen Emerson is an American computer scientist and winner of the 2007 Turing Award.
- He is Professor and Regents Chair Emeritus at the University of Texas at Austin.
- Emerson, together with Edmund M. Clarke and Joseph Sifakis, invented and developed model checking, a technique used in formal verification of software and hardware.
- He introduced computation tree logic (CTL) and its extension CTL*, which are used in the verification of concurrent systems.
- Emerson also developed symbolic model checking to address combinatorial explosion in many model checking algorithms.
- He received a Bachelor of Science degree in mathematics from the University of Texas at Austin in 1976 and a Doctor of Philosophy degree in applied mathematics at Harvard University in 1981.
- Emerson and Clarke coined the term model checking for their verification concept in the early 1980s.
- In 2007, Emerson, Clarke, and Sifakis won the Turing award for their role in developing Model-Checking into a highly effective verification technology.
- Emerson also received the 1998 ACM Paris Kanellakis Award for the development of symbolic model checking.
- He is recognized as one of the pioneers in computer science.
Edgar F. Codd:
- Edgar Frank "Ted" Codd was an English computer scientist who invented the relational model for database management.
- He studied mathematics and chemistry at Exeter College, Oxford before moving to New York to work for IBM in 1948.
- He received a PhD in 1965 from the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, advised by John Henry Holland, on self-replication in cellular automata.
- In the 1960s and 1970s, he worked on his theories of data arrangement and issued his paper "A Relational Model of Data for Large Shared Data Banks" in 1970.
- Codd continued to develop and extend his relational model, sometimes in collaboration with Christopher J. Date.
- He coined the term Online analytical processing (OLAP) and wrote the "twelve laws of online analytical processing."
- Codd received the Turing Award in 1981 and the SIGMOD renamed its highest prize to the SIGMOD Edgar F. Codd Innovations Award in his honor in 2004.
- Codd died of heart failure at his home in Williams Island, Florida, at the age of 79 on 18 April 2003.
Edmund M. Clarke:
- Edmund Melson Clarke Jr. was an American computer scientist and academic.
- He is noted for developing model checking, a method for formally verifying hardware and software designs.
- Clarke was the FORE Systems Professor of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University.
- He received his Ph.D. in Computer Science from Cornell University and taught at Duke University and Harvard University before joining the faculty at Carnegie Mellon.
- Clarke's research interests included software and hardware verification and automatic theorem proving.
- He was a fellow of the ACM and the IEEE and received numerous awards and honors for his contributions to computer science.
- Clarke died from COVID-19 in December 2020, at age 75, during the COVID-19 pandemic in Pennsylvania.
Edward D. Lazowska:
- Edward D. "Ed" Lazowska is an American computer scientist and Professor at the University of Washington.
- His research focuses on high-performance computing, communication systems, and data-intensive science.
- He has contributed to the development of approaches to kernel and system design in various areas, including thread management, load sharing, and cluster computing.
- From 2008 to 2017, he was the Founding Director of the University of Washington eScience Institute.
- Lazowska has held various leadership positions, including Chair of the Computing Research Association, the President’s Information Technology Advisory Committee, and the Computing Community Consortium.
- He also serves as a board member or technical advisor for several technology-oriented organizations.
- Lazowska has mentored many graduate and undergraduate students, including well-known figures in the field of computer science.
- He has received numerous awards and recognition for his contributions to the field, including the Association for Computing Machinery Presidential Award and the ACM Distinguished Service Award.
- Lazowska was born in Washington, D.C. in 1950 and earned his degrees from Brown University and the University of Toronto.
- To celebrate Lazowska's 70th birthday, funds were raised to endow a set of Lazowska Professorships at the University of Washington.
Edward Feigenbaum:
- Edward Albert Feigenbaum is a computer scientist specializing in artificial intelligence.
- He is known as the "father of expert systems."
- Feigenbaum completed his undergraduate degree and Ph.D. at Carnegie Institute of Technology (now Carnegie Mellon University).
- He developed EPAM, one of the first computer models of how people learn, in his Ph.D. thesis.
- Feigenbaum joined the faculty at the University of California, Berkeley in 1960 and later joined the Stanford faculty in 1965.
- He established the Knowledge Systems Laboratory at Stanford University and was involved in important projects in medicine, such as ACME, Mycin, SUMEX, and Dendral.
- Feigenbaum co-founded companies IntelliCorp and Teknowledge.
- He has won numerous awards including the Turing Award jointly with Raj Reddy in 1994.
- Feigenbaum is a Professor Emeritus of Computer Science at Stanford University.
- His works include the Handbook of Artificial Intelligence, which he co-edited with Avron Barr and Paul Cohen.
Edward Felten:
- Edward William Felten is a computer science and public affairs professor at Princeton University.
- He was the Director of the Center for Information Technology Policy from 2007 to 2015 and from 2017 to 2019.
- Felten was named Chief Technologist for the Federal Trade Commission in 2010 and Deputy U.S. Chief Technology Officer in 2015.
- His research involves computer security and technology policy.
- Felten was a witness in the United States v. Microsoft case where he demonstrated a tool to remove Internet Explorer without causing any problems with the operating system.
