- Dr. Richard L. Garwin at IBM Watson Research provided the motivation for this development to verify a nuclear arms treaty with the Soviet Union.
- Cooley was a member of the Digital Signal Processing Committee of the IEEE, received the IEEE Centennial Medal, and in 2002, he received the IEEE Jack S. Kilby Signal Processing Medal.
- He contributed to establishing the terminology in digital signal processing.
- Cooley published various papers, including the Numerov-Cooley method for numerically solving one-dimensional Schrödinger equations.
- He is listed as a pioneer in computer science.
- His profile is available on the Mathematics Genealogy Project.
James G. Mitchell:
- James George "Jim" Mitchell is a Canadian computer scientist.
- He has worked on programming language design and implementation, interactive programming systems, user interface design, and more.
- He was born in Kitchener, Ontario, and graduated from the University of Waterloo with a degree in mathematics in 1966.
- He helped establish Waterloo's reputation for computer science research through his work on the WATFOR compiler project.
- He earned a PhD in computer science from Carnegie Mellon University in 1970.
- He worked at Xerox PARC, Acorn Computers, and Sun Microsystems, where he was Vice President and Chief Technology Officer for Java Consumer & Embedded products.
- He was also Principal Investigator on a research program sponsored by DARPA and Sun.
- He retired from Oracle Labs in 2014.
- He has received awards, including the J.W. Graham Medal in Computing and Innovation from the University of Waterloo.
- He serves as Science Advisory Board Chairperson for the Curci Foundation.
James G. Nell:
- James G. "Jim" Nell is an American engineer known for his work on enterprise integration.
- He received a BSEE from Drexel University and an MBA from Bowling Green State University.
- He worked at Westinghouse Electric Company before becoming the principal investigator of the Manufacturing Enterprise Integration Project at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) from 1993-2000.
- Nell has focused on product-information representation, enterprise integration, and standards for information representation and enterprise integration.
- He has been a Convener of ISO TC184 SC5 WG1 and a member of the US delegation to SC5 and advisory groups to TC184 and SC5.
- Nell's work on enterprise integration aims to provide the right information, at the right place, at the right time.
- The Manufacturing Enterprise Integration Project aimed to improve business process interoperability by developing standards for better software application information sharing.
- Nell has published several scientific and professional papers and edited multiple books on enterprise engineering and integration.
James Gosling:
- James Gosling is a Canadian computer scientist and the founder and lead designer of the Java programming language.
- He received a Bachelor of Science from the University of Calgary and his M.A. and Ph.D. from Carnegie Mellon University, all in computer science.
- Gosling was with Sun Microsystems for 26 years and invented the NeWS windowing system and the Java programming language.
- He left Sun Microsystems in 2010 after it was acquired by the Oracle Corporation and joined Google and later Liquid Robotics before transitioning to Amazon Web Services in 2017 as Distinguished Engineer.
- Gosling has received numerous awards and is an advisor at the Scala company Lightbend, Independent Director at Jelastic, and Strategic Advisor for Eucalyptus.
- He is also a board member of DIRTT Environmental Solutions and a fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery.
- Gosling has authored several books, including "The Java Programming Language" and "The Java Language Specification."
- His personal weblog and presentations are available online, and he has been interviewed on various topics related to computer science and innovation.
James H. Wilkinson:
- James Hardy Wilkinson was a prominent figure in the field of numerical analysis.
- He studied at Trinity College, Cambridge, and graduated as Senior Wrangler.
- He worked on ballistics during World War II but later worked on the ACE computer project with Alan Turing at the National Physical Laboratory.
- Wilkinson's interests took him into the numerical analysis field, where he discovered many significant algorithms.
- He received the Turing Award in 1970 and was elected as a Distinguished Fellow of the British Computer Society in 1974.
- The James H. Wilkinson Prize in Numerical Analysis and Scientific Computing, and J. H. Wilkinson Prize for Numerical Software are named in his honour.
- He died of a heart attack at home on October 5, 1986.
- Some of his works include Rounding Errors in Algebraic Processes, The Algebraic Eigenvalue Problem, and Handbook for Automatic Computation.
James Hendler:
- James Alexander Hendler is an AI researcher at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and a Fellow of the National Academy of Public Administration.
- He completed his Ph.D. and M.Sc. degrees from Brown University, an MS in Cognitive Psychology from Southern Methodist University, and a BS from Yale University.
- Hendler's research interests include the semantic web and artificial intelligence.
- He has been a professor at the University of Maryland where he was the Director of the Joint Institute for Knowledge Discovery and held joint appointments in Computer Science, the Institute for Advanced Computer Studies, and the Institute for Systems Research.
- Hendler was the Director for Semantic Web and Agent Technology at the Maryland Information and Network Dynamics Laboratory.
- He is the Editor in Chief Emeritus of IEEE Intelligent Systems and was the first computer scientist to serve on the Board of Reviewing Editors for Science.
- Hendler has served on multiple advisory boards including Timbr.AI, Web Science Trust (former chairman), Radar Networks, TopQuadrant, Franz Inc, Bright Hub, SocialWire, and Common Crawl.
- He has authored or edited multiple books, including Social Machines, Spinning the Semantic Web, and Semantic Web for the Working Ontologist.
- Hendler has received numerous honors and awards, including the Robert Engelmore Memorial Lecture Prize from AAAI, Fellowships from AAAI, IEEE, and the Semantic Technology Institute International, and the Distinguished Service Award from AAAI.
- He was appointed as Senior Constellation Professor of the Tetherless World Constellation at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in 2006 and became its head in 2022.
- He also serves as the Rensselaer lead of the joint RPI-IBM Center for Health Empowerment by Analytics, Learning and Semantics (HEALS) and the RPI-IBM Artificial Intelligence Research Collaboration Director.
James Rumbaugh:
- James E. Rumbaugh is an American computer scientist and object-oriented methodologist. 
- He is best known for his work in creating the Object Modeling Technique (OMT) and the Unified Modeling Language (UML). 
- Rumbaugh received a B.S. in physics from MIT, an M.S. in astronomy from Caltech, and a Ph.D. in computer science from MIT under Professor Jack Dennis. 
- He worked at Digital Equipment Corporation (DEC) and General Electric Research and Development Center before joining Rational Software in 1994. 
- At Rational Software, he worked with Ivar Jacobson and Grady Booch to develop UML and later merged their software development methodologies into the Rational Unified Process (RUP). 
- He retired in 2006 and lived in Saratoga, California with his wife. 
- Rumbaugh's research interests include formal description languages, productivity tools for programming, and algorithms and data structures. 
- He has written several books about UML and RUP with Jacobson and Booch.
James Z. Wang:
- James Ze Wang is a Chinese-American computer scientist
- He is a Distinguished Professor of the College of Information Sciences and Technology at Pennsylvania State University
- He is co-director of the Intelligent Information Systems Laboratory and has roles in various other programs and departments
- He has a summa cum laude Bachelor's degree in Mathematics and Computer Science from the University of Minnesota and a Ph.D. degree in Medical Information Sciences from Stanford University's Biomedical Informatics and Database groups
- Wang has authored or coauthored two monographs and over 100 journal articles, book chapters, and refereed conference papers
- He has developed image retrieval systems for biomedical image analysis, satellite imaging, web image filtering, and art and cultural imaging, some of which have been sought after and obtained by researchers from more than 100 institutions
- Wang has served on various committees and has been a recipient of an NSF Career award and the endowed PNC Technologies Career Development Professorship
- He has been featured in a PBS series NOVA ScienceNow for his work in developing new computerized methods to detect fake Van Gogh paintings.
Jan Dietz:
- Jan Dietz is a Dutch information systems researcher and professor.
- He is known for developing the Design & Engineering Methodology for Organizations and his work on enterprise ontology.
- Dietz studied at Eindhoven University of Technology, where he obtained his MA in Electrical Engineering and his PhD in 1987.
- He has been a practitioner in the field of automation and information systems from 1970 to 1980.
- In 1980, he returned to academia and was appointed Professor of Management Information Systems at the University of Maastricht.
- From 1994 to 2009, Dietz was a Professor of Information Systems Design at Delft University of Technology.
- He is currently a part-time Professor of Enterprise Engineering at Delft TopTech and the Instituto Superior Técnico in Lisbon.
- Dietz's main research interests are in modeling, design, and engineering of organizations and the development of ICT-applications to support them.
- He co-founded and chairs the DEMO Knowledge Center and has participated in numerous practical DEMO-projects.
- In 2006, he published a book on Enterprise Ontology and is continuing working on Enterprise Architecture.
- Dietz has published over 200 scientific and professional papers and several books.
- He is the founder of the DEMO methodology and is also co-founder and chairman of the CIAO network.
Jan Weglarz:
- Jan Węglarz is a Polish computer scientist.
- His current research focuses on operations research.
- He graduated from the University of Adam Mickiewicz and later, Poznań University of Technology.
- He received his doctorate in 1974 and habilitation in 1977.
- He is a member of the Polish Academy of Sciences and various other organizations.
- He is the author of 12 monographs and over 200 articles.
- He discovered the two-phase method in operations research.
- He participated in the development of Elwro Polish computers.
- He was awarded the EURO Gold Medal in 1991 and the EURO Distinguished Service Award in 2018.
- He received honorary degrees from several Polish institutions.
Janet L. Kolodner:
- Janet Lynne Kolodner is an American cognitive scientist and learning scientist. 
- She is a Professor of the Practice at the Lynch School of Education at Boston College and co-lead of the MA Program in Learning Engineering. 
- She is also Regents' Professor Emerita in the School of Interactive Computing, College of Computing at the Georgia Institute of Technology. 
- Kolodner was the Founding Editor in Chief of The Journal of the Learning Sciences and served in that role for 19 years. 
- She was Founding Executive Officer of the International Society of the Learning Sciences (ISLS). 
- Kolodner was a program officer at the National Science Foundation from August 2010 through July 2014 and headed up the Cyberlearning and Future Learning Technologies program. 
- Kolodner's research addresses issues in learning, memory, and problem solving, both in computers and in people. 
- She pioneered the computer reasoning method called case-based reasoning. 
- Her research interests are the implications and applications of cognition to education and educational technology, artificial intelligence, cognitive science, case-based reasoning, novice-expert evolution, the role of experience in expert and common-sense reasoning, design cognition, creativity, design of decision-aiding tools, and interactive learning environments. 
- Kolodner has published several books and articles, including "Case-Based Reasoning" and "Project-Based Inquiry Science."
Jean E. Sammet:
- Jean E. Sammet was an American computer scientist who developed the FORMAC programming language in 1962.
- She was one of the developers of the influential COBOL programming language.
- Sammet received her B.A. in Mathematics from Mount Holyoke College in 1948 and her M.A. in Mathematics from University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign in 1949.
- She was the first female president of the ACM, from 1974 to 1976.
- Sammet founded the ACM Special Interest Committee on Symbolic and Algebraic Manipulation (SICSAM) in 1965 and was chair of the Special Interest Group on Programming Languages (SIGPLAN).
- Sammet died on May 20, 2017, in Silver Spring, Maryland after a brief illness.
- She received numerous awards including the Augusta Ada Lovelace Award, the SIGPLAN Distinguished Service Award, Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery and the Computer Pioneer Award.
Jean Ichbiah:
- Jean David Ichbiah was a French computer scientist.
- He was the initial chief designer of Ada, a general-purpose, strongly typed programming language.
- He worked on designing an experimental system implementation language called LIS based on Pascal and Simula.
- He founded the Alsys corporation in La Celle-Saint-Cloud, which continued language definition to standardize Ada 83.
- He designed the keyboard layout FITALY, specifically optimized for stylus or touch-based input.
- He received numerous awards including becoming a chevalier of the French Legion of Honour and a correspondent of the French Academy of Sciences.
- He died from complications of a brain tumor on January 26, 2007.
Jeff Bonwick:
- Jeff Bonwick invented and led development of the ZFS file system.
- ZFS was used in Oracle Corporation's ZFS storage products and startups including Nexenta, Delphix, Joyent, and Datto, Inc.
- Bonwick is the inventor of slab allocation and the LZJB compression algorithm.
- He was a Sun Fellow, Sun Storage CTO, and Oracle vice president.
- In 2010, Bonwick co-founded DSSD and became chief technical officer.
- He co-invented DSSD's system hardware architecture and software, and developed their whole-system simulator.
- DSSD was acquired by EMC Corporation in 2014 and then became part of Dell Technologies in 2016.
- Bonwick remained as CTO after the acquisition, but the DSSD product, called D5, was cancelled in March 2017.
Jeff Rulifson:
- Johns Frederick (Jeff) Rulifson is an American computer scientist.
- He was born on August 20, 1941, in Bellefontaine, Ohio.
- Rulifson married Janet Irving on June 8, 1963, and had two children.
- He received a B.S. in mathematics from the University of Washington in 1966 and a Ph.D. in computer science from Stanford University in 1973.
- Rulifson worked at the Stanford Research Institute (now SRI International) from 1966 and was involved in the development of "timesharing" software and the oN-Line System (NLS), a system that foreshadowed many future developments in modern computing and networking.
- Rulifson also developed the command language for the NLS, among other features, and was the lead programmer for the first use of hypertext.
- He left SRI to join Xerox PARC in 1973 to work on personal computing and the creation of local networks, where he developed the concept for the desktop icon.
- In 1985, he joined Syntelligence, an artificial intelligence applications vendor in Sunnyvale, California, and later worked for Sun Microsystems Laboratories and managed Ivan Sutherland's lab until his retirement.
- Rulifson won the Association for Computing Machinery's Software System Award in 1990 and was inducted as a Fellow of the Association for his pioneering work in 1994.
- In 2006, Rulifson was named to the SRI International Hall of Fame.
Jeffrey D. Ullman:
- Jeffrey David Ullman is an American computer scientist and the Stanford W. Ascherman Professor of Engineering, Emeritus, at Stanford University.
- His textbooks on compilers, theory of computation, data structures, and databases are regarded as standards in their fields.
- Ullman and his long-time collaborator Alfred Aho are the recipients of the 2020 Turing Award, generally recognized as the highest distinction in computer science.
- Ullman received a Bachelor of Science degree in engineering mathematics from Columbia University in 1963 and his PhD in electrical engineering from Princeton University in 1966.
- He worked for three years at Bell Labs and later moved to Princeton as an associate professor.
- He was named the Stanford W. Ascherman Professor of Computer Science in 1994 and became an Emeritus in 2003.
- Ullman is the co-recipient (with John Hopcroft) of the 2010 IEEE John von Neumann Medal.
- Ullman's research interests include database theory, data integration, data mining, and education using online infrastructure.
- He is a founder of Gradiance Corporation and teaches courses on automata and mining massive datasets on the Stanford Online learning platform.
- Ullman was elected as a member of the National Academy of Sciences in 2020.
- In 2011, Ullman stated his opposition to assisting Iranians in becoming graduate students at Stanford due to the anti-Israel position of the Iranian government.
- In April 2021, an open letter by CSForInclusion criticized the ACM and the ACM A.M. Turing Award Committee for nominating and selecting Ullman as a recipient of the ACM A.M. Turing award.
- He has authored several books on various topics in computer science.
Jeffrey Scott Vitter:
- Jeffrey Scott Vitter is a U.S. computer scientist and academic administrator.
- He was born in 1955 in New Orleans and has served in several senior higher education administration posts.
- Vitter is a former chancellor of the University of Mississippi, assuming the position on January 1, 2016.
- He has a Bachelor of Science in mathematics, a PhD in computer science, and a Master of Business Administration from Duke University.
- Vitter progressed through the faculty ranks at Brown University from 1980 to 1992 and was a distinguished professor at Duke University from 1993 to 2002.
- He was the Frederick Hovde Dean of the College of Science at Purdue University from 2002 to 2008 and served as provost and executive vice president for academics at Texas A&M University from 2008 to 2009.
- From 2010 to 2015, Vitter was provost and executive vice chancellor and Roy A. Roberts Distinguished Professor at the University of Kansas.
- Vitter is a computer scientist with over 350 books, journals, and conference publications.
- He helped establish the field of I/O algorithms and has made fundamental contributions in databases, compressed data structures, hashing, and machine learning.
- Vitter has three children and is a brother of former U.S. Senator David Vitter of Louisiana.
- Vitter stepped down as chancellor of the University of Mississippi in January 2019 and is now a Distinguished Professor Emeritus.
Jeremy Gibbons:
- Jeremy Gibbons is a computer scientist and professor of computing at the University of Oxford
- He is the Deputy Director of the Software Engineering Programme in the Department of Computer Science, Governing Body Fellow at Kellogg College and Pro-Proctor of the University of Oxford
- He holds a Bachelor of Science (BSc) (Hons) in computer science from the University of Edinburgh and a Doctor of Philosophy (DPhil) in Computation from the University of Oxford
- His research activities include programming languages and methods; functional programming; generic programming; object technology; program specification, derivation and transformation
- Current projects include CancerGrid; Datatype-Generic Programming; Automatic Generation of Software Components; Workflow for Cancer Bioinformatics
- He is a member of the International Federation for Information Processing (IFIP) and chairperson of IFIP Working Group 2.1 on Algorithmic Languages and Calculi
- His publications cover generic programming, functional programming, formal methods, computational biology and bioinformatics
- He maintains a blog called "Patterns in Functional Programming"
Jerre Noe:
- Jerre Noe was an American computer scientist born in California in 1923.
- He received a Bachelor's degree in electrical engineering from the University of California and a Ph.D. in electrical engineering at Stanford University.
- Noe led the technical team for the ERMA project, the Bank of America's first venture into computerized banking, during the 1950s.
- In 1968, he became the first chair of the University of Washington's Computer Science Group.
- Noe remained active in his department as a professor emeritus and in other aspects of his life until his death in 2005.
- He was an avid flautist, sailor, and skier into his eighties.
- Noe married twice, had three children, and died from peritoneal mesothelioma caused by exposure to asbestos at the age of 82.
Jiawei Han:
- Jiawei Han is a Chinese-American computer scientist and researcher.
- He is currently a professor at the Department of Computer Science at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.
- His research focuses on data mining, text mining, database systems, information networks, data mining from spatiotemporal data, Web data, and social/information network data.
- Han received his BS from University of Science and Technology of China in 1979 and his PhD from the University of Wisconsin-Madison in Computer Science in 1985.
- He served as the Director of Information Network Academic Research Center (INARC) and the Co-Director of KnowEng, a BD2k (Big Data to Knowledge) research center.
- Han has chaired or served on over 100 program committees of international conferences and workshops.
- He is an ACM Fellow and an IEEE Fellow.
- Han received the 2004 ACM SIGKDD Innovations Award, and the 2005 IEEE Computer Society Technical Achievement Award.
- He was the 2009 winner of the McDowell Award, the highest technical award made by IEEE.
- Han has authored the book "Data Mining: Concepts and Techniques" (3rd ed., Morgan Kaufmann, 2011).
- Han's academic website and Data Mining Research Group are available online.
Jie Wu:
- Jie Wu is a Chinese computer scientist based in Pennsylvania.
- He is the Associate Vice Provost for International Affairs and Director for Center for Networked Computing at Temple University.
- Wu is also a Laura H. Carnell professor in the Department of Computer and Information Sciences.
- He is noted for his research in routing for wired and wireless networks.
- Wu served as Program Director of Networking Technology and Systems (NeTS) at the National Science Foundation from 2006 to 2008.
- He has served as the General Chair and Program Chair of various IEEE conferences and is a Fellow of IEEE.
- Wu has received multiple awards for his contributions to computer science, including the 2011 China Computer Federation (CCF) Overseas Outstanding Achievements Award.
- He is currently a CCF Distinguished Speaker.
- Wu resides in Fort Washington, Pennsylvania.
Jill Zimmerman:
- Jill Loraine Zimmerman is an American computer scientist and professor
- She is the James M. Beall Professor of Mathematics and Computer Science at Goucher College
- Zimmerman and her father built a computer in 1975 after being inspired by an article in Popular Mechanics
- She earned a Bachelor of Science with distinction in Computer and Informational Sciences from Purdue University and a doctorate in computer science from the University of Minnesota
- Zimmerman has been the head of the Goucher Robotics Lab since 2006
- She was the principal investigator for a scholarship program funded by the National Science Foundation
- Zimmerman has published work on robotics and computer languages with her husband, James Gil de Lamadrid
- In 1985, she married de Lamadrid.
Jim Gray (computer scientist):
- James Nicholas Gray was an American computer scientist who received the Turing Award in 1998 for his contributions to database and transaction processing research and technical leadership in system implementation.
- Gray was born in San Francisco and spent most of the first three years of his life in Rome, Italy, where he learned to speak Italian before English.
- Gray pursued his career by working as a researcher and software designer at a number of industrial companies, including IBM, Tandem Computers, and DEC. He joined Microsoft in 1995.
- Gray is known for his contributions to major database and transaction processing systems, including SQL relational databases that have become a standard throughout the world.
- Gray disappeared on January 28, 2007, during a short solo trip to scatter his mother's ashes at the Farallon Islands near San Francisco. His boat was not found, and he was declared legally dead on January 28, 2012.
- Microsoft Research presents the Jim Gray eScience Award each year to a researcher who has made an outstanding contribution to the field of data-intensive computing.
Jochen Liedtke:
- Jochen Liedtke was a German computer scientist.
- He studied for a diploma degree in mathematics in the mid-1970s.
- He created the Eumel operating system that supported orthogonal persistence and ran on multiple processors.
- In 1987, he designed the L3 operating system to succeed Eumel.
- In the early 1990s, Liedtke redesigned L3 from scratch and created the L4 microkernel operating system family.
- He worked on computer architecture and created guarded page tables to implement a sparsely-mapped 64-bit address space.
- Liedtke joined the Thomas J. Watson Research Center in 1996 and worked on the Saw Mill project to turn Linux into an L4-based multi-server OS.
- In April 1999, he took up the System Architecture Chair at the University of Karlsruhe and continued to work on L4.
- Liedtke died unexpectedly on June 10, 2001, at Frankfurt Airport while returning from the SOSP'01 program committee meeting in Chateau Lake Louise.
- His work on L4 was completed after his death by his students and was released under the name Pistachio in 2002.
John Cocke (computer scientist):
- John Cocke was an American computer scientist known for his contributions to computer architecture and optimizing compiler design.
- He was born in Charlotte, North Carolina, and received his bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering and Ph.D. in mathematics from Duke University.
- Cocke spent his entire career as an industrial researcher for IBM, from 1956 to 1992.
- He is considered the "father of RISC architecture" and his innovations were noted in the IBM 801 minicomputer project.
- Cocke was involved in speech recognition and machine translation at IBM and originated the idea of using a trigram language model for speech recognition.
- He won numerous awards including the ACM Turing Award, National Medal of Technology, and National Medal of Science.
- Cocke was a member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the American Philosophical Society, and the National Academy of Sciences.
- In 2002, he was made a Fellow of the Computer History Museum.
- Cocke died in Valhalla, New York, in 2002.
John George Kemeny:
- John George Kemeny was a mathematician, computer scientist, and educator.
- He co-developed the BASIC programming language in 1964 with Thomas E. Kurtz.
- Kemeny served as the 13th President of Dartmouth College from 1970 to 1981.
- He pioneered the use of computers in college education.
- Kemeny chaired the presidential commission that investigated the Three Mile Island accident in 1979.
- He was a Hungarian-born American who emigrated to the United States during World War II.
- Kemeny attended Princeton University for his undergraduate and graduate studies and worked as Albert Einstein's mathematical assistant during graduate school.
- Kemeny was appointed to the Dartmouth Mathematics Department as a full professor in 1953, and later became the chairman of the department.
- He introduced Finite mathematics courses and co-authored several textbooks on the subject.
- Kemeny and Kurtz were pioneers in the use of computers for ordinary people and invented the world's first time-sharing system, the Dartmouth Time-Sharing System (DTSS).
- Kemeny was president of Dartmouth from 1970 to 1981 and made Dartmouth a pioneer in student use of computers.
- In 1983, Kemeny and Kurtz co-founded a company called True BASIC, Inc. to market True BASIC, an updated version of the language.
- John Kemeny died of heart failure in Lebanon, New Hampshire in 1992.
John Henry Holland:
- John Henry Holland was a scientist and Professor of psychology and Professor of electrical engineering and computer science at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor.
- He was a pioneer in what became known as genetic algorithms and a founding father of the complex systems approach.
- Holland received the 1961 Louis E. Levy Medal from The Franklin Institute, and the MacArthur Fellowship in 1992.
- He authored several books about complex adaptive systems, including "Adaptation in Natural and Artificial Systems" and "Emergence: From Chaos to Order".
- Holland died on August 9, 2015 in Ann Arbor, Michigan.
John Hopcroft:
- John Edward Hopcroft is an American theoretical computer scientist
- He is the IBM Professor of Engineering and Applied Mathematics in Computer Science at Cornell University
- He is Co-Director of the Center on Frontiers of Computing Studies at Peking University
- He is the Director of the John Hopcroft Center for Computer Science at Shanghai Jiao Tong University
- His textbooks on Theory of Computation and data structures are standards in their fields
- He received his bachelor's from Seattle University and his master's degree and Ph.D. from Stanford University
- He received the Turing Award in 1986 for fundamental achievements in the design and analysis of algorithms and data structures
- He is also known for the Hopcroft–Karp algorithm for finding matchings in bipartite graphs
- He was awarded an honorary doctorate by the University of Sydney, in Sydney, Australia in 2005 and from Saint Petersburg State University of Information Technologies, Mechanics and Optics in 2009
- In 2020, the Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen opened a Hopcroft Institute for Advanced Information Sciences and designated him as an Einstein professor
- He is the co-recipient of the 2010 IEEE John von Neumann Medal with Jeffrey Ullman for laying the foundations for the fields of automata and language theory and many seminal contributions to theoretical computer science
John Horton Conway:
- John Horton Conway was an English mathematician who made contributions to various fields including finite groups, knot theory, number theory, combinatorial game theory, and coding theory.
- He was also known for his contributions to recreational mathematics, including the invention of the Game of Life, a cellular automaton.
- Conway was born and raised in Liverpool, and studied mathematics at Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge.
- He spent the first half of his career at Cambridge before moving to Princeton University, where he held the John von Neumann Professorship for the rest of his career.
- Conway and Martin Gardner were frequent collaborators, with Gardner featuring Conway's work in his Mathematical Games column.
- Conway made contributions to diverse areas of mathematics, including combinatorial game theory, geometry (including polyhedron notation and the Leech lattice), geometric topology (including the Conway polynomial and Conway notation for knots), group theory (including the ATLAS of Finite Groups), number theory, algebra (including quaternions and octonions), analysis, and algorithmics.
- Conway received numerous awards and honors, including fellowships in several mathematical societies, and was given honorary degrees from the University of Liverpool and Alexandru Ioan Cuza University.
- Conway died on April 11, 2020, at the age of 82 due to complications from COVID-19.
John Hughes (computer scientist):
- R. John M. Hughes is a computer scientist and professor at Chalmers University of Technology.
- He received his PhD from the University of Oxford in 1984 for his thesis on "The Design and Implementation of Programming Languages."
- Hughes does research on programming languages, with a focus on Haskell.
- He is a member of the Functional Programming group at Chalmers and has authored many influential research papers on the subject, including "Why Functional Programming Matters."
- Hughes is a developer of QuickCheck and the cofounder and CEO of QuviQ, which provides the software and classes on how to use it.
- In 2016, he appeared on the YouTube channel Computerphile, explaining Functional Programming and QuickCheck.
- Hughes was elected as an ACM Fellow in 2018 for his "contributions to software testing and functional programming." 
- See also: Haskell programming language, QuickCheck.
John Koza:
- John R. Koza is a computer scientist and former adjunct professor at Stanford University.
- He is known for pioneering the use of genetic programming for solving complex problems.
- Koza co-founded Scientific Games Corporation, which builds computer systems for state lotteries in the US.
- He is credited with creating the 'scratch card' with the help of Daniel Bower.
- Koza earned a bachelor's and doctoral degree from the University of Michigan in computer science.
- He created the "invention machine" which alters its own code to find complex solutions and received a patent for it.
- Koza advocates for revamping the way electors for the Electoral College are chosen in the US.
- He established the organization National Popular Vote Inc. to advocate for state adoption of the policy and electing supportive candidates.
- Koza has published several works on genetic programming and machine intelligence.
John Krogstie:
- John Krogstie is a Norwegian computer scientist and a professor in information systems at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology.
- He received a MSc and a PhD in information systems from the same university.
- Krogstie's research interests include information systems, conceptual modeling, mobile information systems, eGovernment, and enterprise modeling.
- He developed the SEQUAL framework, a reference model for evaluating the quality of models, based on semiotic theory.
- He has published around 150 refereed papers in journals, books, and archival proceedings.
- Krogstie is the Norwegian representative for IFIP TC8 and was Chair (2010–2015) of IFIP WG 8.1 on information systems design and evaluation.
John L. Hennessy:
- John Leroy Hennessy is an American computer scientist, academician, and businessman.
- He is the Chairman of Alphabet Inc., one of the founders of MIPS Computer Systems Inc. and Atheros.
- He served as the tenth President of Stanford University and stepped down in the summer of 2016.
- Hennessy and David Patterson received the 2017 Turing Award for developing the reduced instruction set computer (RISC) architecture.
- He earned his bachelor's degree from Villanova University and his master's degree and Doctor of Philosophy from Stony Brook University.
- Hennessy became a faculty member at Stanford University in 1977 and founded MIPS Computer Systems Inc. in 1984.
- He served as Provost of Stanford University before being appointed President.
- Hennessy serves as a board member of Google (later Alphabet Inc.), Cisco Systems, Atheros Communications, and the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation.
- He co-founded the Knight-Hennessy Scholars program with a $750 million endowment to fully fund graduate students at Stanford for up to three years.
- He was appointed as the new Chairman of Alphabet Inc. in February 2018.
- Hennessy has received numerous awards and honors, including the IEEE Medal of Honor and the Turing Award.
- He is married to Andrea Berti, whom he met in high school.
John Lions:
- John Lions was an Australian computer scientist born in 1937 and died in 1998.
- He received a degree with first-class honours from the University of Sydney in 1959 and completed his doctorate on Control engineering at the University of Cambridge in 1963.
- Lions worked in various positions including Burroughs in Los Angeles, KCS Ltd in Toronto and Dalhousie University in Halifax.
- In 1972, Lions became a senior lecturer in the Department of Computer Science at the University of New South Wales (UNSW).
- His most famous work, the Lions Book, was written as course notes for his operating systems course at UNSW, containing the entire UNIX 6 operating system.
- Lions was involved in the setting up of an annual conference for academics, the Australian Computer Science Conference and he was the editor of the Australian Computer Journal for six years.
- After his death, a campaign was started to raise funds to create the John Lions Chair of Operating Systems at UNSW, and the John Lions Garden was dedicated to his memory in 2002.
- In 2011, The School of Computer Science and Engineering at UNSW initiated the John Lions Award for Contribution to Open Software.
John Mashey:
- John R. Mashey is an American computer scientist, director and entrepreneur.
- He holds a Ph.D. in computer science from Pennsylvania State University.
- He worked on the PWB/UNIX operating system at Bell Labs from 1973 to 1983 and authored the PWB shell, also known as the "Mashey Shell".
- He joined MIPS Computer Systems in early 1985, managing operating systems development and helping design the MIPS RISC architecture.
- He continued similar work at Silicon Graphics (1992–2000), contributing to the design of the NUMAflex modular computer architecture using NUMAlink, ending as VP and chief scientist.
- He was one of the founders of the Standard Performance Evaluation Corporation (SPEC) benchmarking group, an ACM National Lecturer for four years, and a trustee of the Computer History Museum.
- He wrote articles for the Skeptical Inquirer regarding climate change denial and investigated the secretive funding of climate contrarian thinktanks.
- He became a scientific and technical consultant for the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry in 2015.
- Mashey is married to Angela Hey, a Cambridge University and Waterloo University graduate with a Ph.D. from Imperial College, London.
John Mauchly:
- John William Mauchly designed the first general-purpose electronic digital computer, ENIAC, with J. Presper Eckert, as well as EDVAC, BINAC, and UNIVAC I.
- They founded the Eckert–Mauchly Computer Corporation (EMCC) and pioneered fundamental computer concepts like stored program, subroutines, and programming languages.
- Their work led to an explosion of computer development in the late 1940s all over the world.
- Mauchly earned a Ph.D. in physics and was a head of the physics department at Ursinus College.
- Mauchly and Eckert met at the University of Pennsylvania Moore School of Electrical Engineering, where they were contracted to build ENIAC, which could perform high-speed calculations and solve problems that were previously unsolvable.
- John Mauchly was involved in computer development for his entire career, founding Mauchly Associates and Dynatrend, and becoming a consultant to Sperry Univac.
- Mauchly received numerous awards and honors, including being a founding member and president of the Association for Computing Machinery. 
- His patent on the ENIAC was invalidated by U.S. Federal Court decision in October, 1973 for various reasons.
John McCarthy (computer scientist):
- John McCarthy was an American computer scientist and cognitive scientist 
- He was one of the founders of the discipline of artificial intelligence 
- He co-authored the document that coined the term "artificial intelligence" (AI) 
- Developed the programming language family Lisp 
- Significantly influenced the design of the language ALGOL 
- Popularized time-sharing, and invented garbage collection 
- McCarthy spent most of his career at Stanford University 
- Received many accolades and honors, such as the 1971 Turing Award for his contributions to the topic of AI, the United States National Medal of Science, and the Kyoto Prize 
- McCarthy championed mathematics such as lambda calculus 
- McCarthy and his colleagues coined the term "artificial intelligence" 
- He invented Lisp, the programming language of choice for AI applications 
- Involved with developing international standards in programming and informatics 
- Instrumental in creating three of the earliest time-sharing systems 
- McCarthy was married three times and declared himself an atheist 
- He wrote an article entitled "Ascribing Mental Qualities to Machines" 
- Received the Turing Award from the Association for Computing Machinery 
- Inducted into IEEE Intelligent Systems' AI's Hall of Fame.
John O'Sullivan (engineer):
- John O'Sullivan is an Australian engineer
- He co-authored a paper in 1977 about image sharpness and improving picture clarity in radio astronomy images
- In the early 1990s, he led a team at CSIRO to reduce multipath interference in radio signals for computer networking, which is now used in all recent WiFi implementations
- CSIRO has earned over $430 million in royalties and settlements from this patent, with more expected after further lawsuits against other parties
- O'Sullivan joined Morse Micro in 2019 to develop a Wi-Fi microprocessor
- He has a PhD in Electrical Engineering and a Bachelor of Engineering and Science from Sydney University
- O'Sullivan has received several awards and achievements, including the IEEE Masaru Ibuka Consumer Electronics Award in 2017 and the European Inventor Award in 2012 for his work on WiFi technology
- He has conducted research on various areas in radio astronomy and contributed to the development of adaptive optics and redundant baseline interferometer
- O'Sullivan has over 40 scientific and technical papers and has been granted 12 patents in the area of special purpose FFT processors, Wireless LANs, and antennas
- He is a member of various organizations and committees in the field, including IEEE and the Australian Square Kilometre Array Consultative Committee
John Ousterhout:
- John Kenneth Ousterhout is a professor of computer science at Stanford University.
- He founded Electric Cloud with John Graham-Cumming.
- Ousterhout was a professor of computer science at University of California, Berkeley where he created Tcl scripting language and Tk toolkit and proposed coscheduling.
- Ousterhout led the research group that designed the Sprite operating system and the first log-structured file system.
- He also led the team that developed the Magic VLSI CAD program.
- Ousterhout received his bachelor's degree in physics from Yale University in 1975, his Ph.D. in computer science from Carnegie Mellon University in 1980 and the Grace Murray Hopper Award in 1987.
- In 1994, he left Berkeley to join Sun Microsystems Laboratories and later co-founded Scriptics, Inc.
- Ousterhout joined the faculty of Stanford University in 2008.
- His selected works include "The Design of XPRS" and "A Philosophy of Software Design".
- Ousterhout's dichotomy and Raft (computer science) are related topics.
- Additional information on Tcl's early days and Ousterhout's web page at Stanford University are available online.
John P. Moon:
- John P. Moon is an Apple Computers executive with engineering degrees from Pennsylvania State University and New York University.

- From the 1960s to the 1980s, Moon worked for companies including IBM, National Micronetics Corporation, Tandon Magnetics Corporation, and Apple.

- Moon was born in Philadelphia in 1938, and spent his time building model cars and taking apart electronic devices in his family's basement.

- He graduated with honors from Pennsylvania State University in 1960 and later received a masters from NYU in engineering.

- Moon was hired by IBM in New York city during a time when major companies were recruiting African Americans with experience in math and science.

- He established the National Micronetics Corporation in 1970 with a few other engineers in a garage, and the business grew from five people working in a garage to a multimillion-dollar company.

- Four years later, he began working with Tandon Magnetics Corporation and found a new way to manufacture ferrite recording heads through mass production.

- In 1980, Moon moved to Apple Computers where he helped the company design and make its own floppy disks and disk drives, and became Vice President of the Apple Computer Products division.
John Presper Eckert:
- John Adam Presper Eckert Jr. was an American electrical engineer and computer pioneer
- He designed the first general-purpose electronic digital computer (ENIAC) with John Mauchly
- He presented the first course in computing topics, the Moore School Lectures
- He founded the Eckert-Mauchly Computer Corporation
- He designed the first commercial computer in the U.S., the UNIVAC
- He developed the mercury delay-line memory
- Eckert and Mauchly left the Moore School in 1946 over a dispute involving the assignment of claims on intellectual property developed at the University
- They started the Electronic Control Company which built the Binary Automatic Computer (BINAC)
- The Eckert-Mauchly Computer Corporation was formed, and they received an order to build the Universal Automatic Computer (UNIVAC), which was finished on December 21, 1950
- Eckert received the Howard N. Potts Medal in 1949
- He was awarded the National Medal of Science in 1968
- Eckert believed that the widely adopted term "von Neumann architecture" should properly be known as the "Eckert architecture"
- He died of leukemia in Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania in 1995
- In 2002, he was posthumously inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame.
John Vincent Atanasoff:
- John Vincent Atanasoff was an American physicist and inventor of mixed Bulgarian-Irish origin.
- He is credited with inventing the first electronic digital computer in the 1930s. 
- His computer was named the Atanasoff–Berry Computer and used binary math and Boolean logic to solve up to 29 simultaneous linear equations. 
- Atanasoff first met John Mauchly in 1940 and they discussed computing theories, including Atanasoff's design manuscript. 
- Atanasoff left Iowa State College in 1941 and Mauchly did not mention his own computer project until early 1944. 
- The 1973 Honeywell v. Sperry Rand lawsuit ruled that Atanasoff was the inventor of the electronic digital computer over Mauchly and J. Presper Eckert's patent claims. 
- Atanasoff received many honors throughout his life, including the U.S. National Medal of Technology and the Order of Saints Cyril and Methodius. 
- Various schools, streets, and awards in Bulgaria and the United States are named after him.
John Yen:
- John Yen is a professor of data science and leads the Laboratory of AI for Cyber Security at Penn State.
- He was the founder and former Director of the Cancer Informatics Initiative at Penn State.
- His current research goals are using AI and big data to address challenges in cybersecurity and advancing the frontier of artificial intelligence.
- Yen has been a Principal investigator or co-Principal investigator on several multimillion-dollar research projects funded by organizations such as the National Science Foundation, Army Research Office, Office of Naval Research, and Department of Energy.
- He is the lead inventor of the AI architecture R-CAST, which has been granted a U.S. patent and successfully applied to a real-world dynamic cyber-physical domain.
- Yen received his Ph.D. from the University of California, Berkeley in 1986 and his B.S. degree from National Taiwan University in 1980.
- He is the co-author of "Emergent Information Technologies and Enabling Policies for Counter-Terrorism" and "Fuzzy Logic: Intelligence, Control, and Information."
- See also: Recognition primed decision.
- External links: Dr. John Yen's website, the Cancer Informatics Initiative at Penn State, and Yen's Google Scholar profile.
Jon Crowcroft:
- Jonathan Andrew Crowcroft is the Marconi Professor of Communications Systems at the University of Cambridge.
- He received a bachelor's degree in physics from the University of Cambridge and a master's degree in computing and a PhD from University College London.
- Crowcroft has contributed to successful start-up projects and has served on the advisory board of Max Planck Institute for Software Systems.
- His research has focused on theoretical network science, including the idea of using specially-built hardware for packet switching and optical technology.
- Crowcroft was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 2013 and has received numerous other awards and honours throughout his career.
- He served as general chair for the ACM SIGCOMM conference between 1995 and 1999 and received the SIGCOMM Award in 2009.
Jon Michael Dunn:
• J. Michael Dunn was a philosopher and professor Emeritus at Indiana University. 

• He was the first in his family to attend college and earned an A.B in Philosophy from Oberlin College and a Ph.D. from the University of Pittsburgh. 

• Dunn taught at Wayne State University, Yale University, and Indiana University Bloomington. 

• He was the recipient of many grants and awards, including the Techpoint Mira for Outstanding Education Contribution to Information Technology. 

• Dunn was a Fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and served as President of the Society for Exact Philosophy. 

• His research focused on information-based logics, and he developed "gaggle theory" and worked with relevance logic and quantum computation. 

• He co-authored books, including Algebraic Methods in Philosophical Logic and Generalized Galois Logics: Relational Semantics of Nonclassical Logical Calculi. 

• Dunn directed or co-directed 17 Ph.D. dissertations, published six books and over 100 papers. 

• After retiring, he served on the board of HealthLINC for ten years and was affiliated with the Info-Metrics Institute at American University. 

• Dunn passed away on April 5, 2021.
Jonathan Bowen:
- Jonathan P. Bowen is a British computer scientist and Emeritus Professor at London South Bank University.
- He has also been a professor of computer science at Birmingham City University, visiting professor at Pratt Institute, University of Westminster, and King's College London, and a visiting academic at University College London.
- Bowen's early work was on formal methods, and he later became Chair of the Z User Group and FACS Specialist Group on Formal Aspects of Computing Science.
- He is also an associate editor for Innovations in Systems and Software Engineering and on the editorial board for the ACM Computing Surveys journal.
- Bowen founded the Virtual Library museums pages and the Virtual Museum of Computing and later founded Museophile Limited to support museums, especially online.
- He has worked in industry at various companies, including Oxford Instruments, Marconi Instruments, Logica, Silicon Graphics, and Altran Praxis.
- Bowen has written and edited several books on formal methods, including Formal Specification and Documentation using Z and The Turing Guide.
- He has received numerous fellowships and awards, including from the Royal Society for the encouragement of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce (RSA) and the British Computer Society (BCS).
- Bowen was educated at the Dragon School, Bryanston School, and University College, Oxford.
Jonathan James:
- Jonathan Joseph James was an American hacker.
- He was the first juvenile to be incarcerated in the United States for cybercrime. He was 15 years old at the time of his first offense and 16 years old when he was sentenced.
- He committed a series of intrusions into various systems, including those of BellSouth, the Miami-Dade school system, and the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA) of the United States Department of Defense.
- He was later found to have installed an unauthorized backdoor in a computer server in Dulles, Virginia, which allowed him to intercept over three thousand messages passing to and from DTRA employees and obtain numerous usernames and passwords of other DTRA employees, including at least 10 on official military computers. He also obtained the International Space Station's source code.
- James was raided on January 26, 2000, by agents from the Department of Defense, NASA and the Pinecrest Police Dept.
- He pleaded guilty to two counts of juvenile delinquency in exchange for a lenient sentence and was sentenced to seven months of house arrest and probation until the age of eighteen, required to write apology letters to NASA and the Department of Defense, and banned from using computers for recreational purposes. He later violated that probation, tested positive for drug use, and was taken into custody and served six months.
- In 2008, the TJX department store chain was the victim of a massive computer systems intrusion that compromised the personal and credit information of millions of customers. James was investigated as a possible conspirator, but there was no evidence linking him to the intrusion. However, notes discovered during a search of his home revealed he had considered suicide.
- On May 18, 2008, Jonathan James was found dead of a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head.
Joseph F Traub:
- Joseph Frederick Traub was an American computer scientist and professor.
- He held positions at Bell Laboratories, University of Washington, Carnegie Mellon, and Columbia, as well as sabbatical positions at various universities.
- Traub authored or edited ten monographs and around 120 papers in several fields including computer science, mathematics, physics, finance, and economics.
- He pioneered work on computational complexity applied to science problems and developed algorithms like the Jenkins-Traub Algorithm for Polynomial Zeros.
- Traub was the founding Chair of the Computer Science and Telecommunications Board, National Academies and founding editor of the Annual Review of Computer Science.
- He received multiple awards and honors, including the IEEE Emanuel R. Piore Award and the 1999 New York City Mayor's Award for Excellence in Science and Technology.
- Traub donated some 100 boxes of archival material to Carnegie Mellon University Library.
- He was married to author Pamela McCorduck and had two daughters.
- His works have been cited 8,500 times as of November 2015, and he has an h-index of 35.
Joseph Halpern:
- Joseph Yehuda Halpern is a professor of computer science at Cornell University.
- His research is focused on reasoning about knowledge and uncertainty.
- He graduated from the University of Toronto with a B.S. in mathematics in 1975.
- He earned a Ph.D. in mathematics from Harvard University in 1981.
- Halpern has written three books on actual causality, reasoning about uncertainty, and reasoning about knowledge.
- He won the Gödel Prize in theoretical computer science in 1997 and the Dijkstra Prize in distributed computing in 2009.
- Halpern served as editor-in-chief of the Journal of the ACM from 1997 to 2003.
- He was inducted as a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery in 2002 and an IEEE Fellow in 2012.
- Halpern was awarded a Senior Fellowship of the Zukunftskolleg at the University of Konstanz in 2011.
- He became a member of the National Academy of Engineering in 2019 for his methods of reasoning about knowledge, belief, and uncertainty and their applications to distributed computing and multiagent systems.
- Halpern is the administrator for the Computing Research Repository and a moderator for subsections of arXiv.org.
- His notable students include Nir Friedman, Daphne Koller, and Yoram Moses.
Joseph Henry Wegstein:
- Joseph Henry Wegstein was an American computer scientist born on April 7, 1922 in Washburn, Illinois.
- He earned a Bachelor of Science degree in physics and a Master of Science degree in engineering physics from the University of Illinois.
- He worked at the National Bureau of Standards (now NIST) as Acting Chief of the Office for Information Processing Standards, specializing in technical standards for automatic data processing and fingerprint recognition technology.
- He participated in conferences in Zurich and Paris that developed the programming languages ALGOL 58 and ALGOL 60, respectively.
- He was involved with international standards in programming and informatics as a member of the IFIP Working Group 2.1 on Algorithmic Languages and Calculi and the CODASYL committee, and helped develop the COBOL language.
- He published several reports on fingerprint identification systems and the M40 fingerprint matcher.
- His death occurred on August 16, 1985.
Joseph Kruskal:
- Joseph Bernard Kruskal was an American mathematician, statistician, computer scientist, and psychometrician.
- He had two notable brothers, Martin David Kruskal and William Kruskal, who were also scientists.
- Kruskal earned his Bachelor of Science and Master of Science in Mathematics from the University of Chicago and completed his PhD from Princeton University in 1954.
- Kruskal worked at Bell Labs from 1959 to 1993 and was also a former president of the Psychometric Society.
- Kruskal's most influential work was his contribution to the formulation of multidimensional scaling and Kruskal's algorithm for computing the minimal spanning tree of a weighted graph.
- He is also known for Kruskal's tree theorem and Kruskal-rank, and he applied his work in linguistics in an experimental lexicostatistical study of Indo-European languages.
- Kruskal passed away in 2010.
Joseph Sifakis:
- Joseph Sifakis is a Greek-French computer scientist born in Heraklion, Crete in 1946.
- He received the Turing Award in 2007 for his work on model checking alongside Edmund M. Clarke and E. Allen Emerson.
- Sifakis studied Electrical Engineering at the National Technical University of Athens and Computer Science at the University of Grenoble.
- He founded the CAV conference with Clarke and Amir Pnueli in 1989 and coordinated the ARTIST European Network of Excellence for research on Embedded Systems from 2004 to 2012.
- Sifakis has worked on the verification of timed and hybrid systems and the synthesis of timed systems, as well as the development of verification tools.
- He has focused on component-based design using the BIP component framework and the design of trustworthy autonomous systems, with a recent focus on self-driving cars.
- Sifakis has received numerous awards, including the Leonardo da Vinci Medal, Grand Officer of the National Order of Merit in France, and membership in the French Academy of Sciences, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and the National Academy of Engineering.
Joshua Lederberg:
- Joshua Lederberg was an American molecular biologist known for his work in microbial genetics, artificial intelligence, and the United States space program.
- He won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1958 at the age of 33 for discovering bacterial conjugation, the exchange of genes among bacteria. He shared the prize with Edward Tatum and George Beadle, who won for their work with genetics.
- Lederberg did extensive research in artificial intelligence, which included work in the NASA experimental programs seeking life on Mars and the chemistry expert system Dendral.
- He founded the Department of Medical Genetics at the University of Wisconsin–Madison in 1957 and later moved to Stanford University as the founder and chairman of the Department of Genetics.
- Lederberg was concerned about the biological impact of space exploration, and his public advocacy for exobiology helped expand the role of biology in NASA.
- Awards and accolades include the Presidential Medal of Freedom and the Benjamin Franklin Medal for Distinguished Achievement in the Sciences of the American Philosophical Society.
- In Lederberg's honor, a large impact crater on the surface of Mars was named in 2012.
Joyce K. Reynolds:
- Joyce Kathleen Reynolds was an American computer scientist who contributed to the development of protocols underlying the Internet.
- She authored or co-authored many RFCs (Request for Comments) including Telnet, FTP, and POP protocols.
- Reynolds worked with Jon Postel to develop early functions of the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority and managed the root zone of DNS.
- She served as Area Director of the User Services area, a member of the Internet Engineering Steering Group of IETF, and co-led the RFC Editor function.
- Reynolds died due to complications from cancer in 2015 at the age of 63.
- She received the 2006 Postel Award for her services to the Internet.
- Reynolds' works include "The DARPA experimental multimedia mail system", "Standard for the transmission of IP datagrams over IEEE 802 networks", and "The helminthiasis of the Internet".
- Reynolds is mentioned in RFC 1336, "Who's Who in the Internet", and is recognized as an Internet pioneer and woman in technology.
Juan E. Gilbert:
- Juan E. Gilbert is an American computer scientist, researcher, inventor, and educator.
- He is an advocate of diversity in the computing sciences and has been recognized for his efforts to increase the number of underrepresented minorities in the field.
- Gilbert was awarded the first Presidential Endowed Chair at Clemson University in 2012.
- His efforts in 2012 led to Clemson having 10% African American computer science professors and 10% of the African American computer science doctoral students in the US.
- Gilbert has received numerous awards and honors, including the Computing Research Association's A. Nico Habermann Award in 2018 and the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) Chairman's Award for Advancement in Accessibility in 2012.
- He is a fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and the African Scientific Institute.
- Gilbert has developed projects such as "Prime III: The world's first all-accessible, electronic voting system" and "The Virtual Traffic Stop."
Juan Pav\u00f3n:
- Juan Pavón is a Spanish computer scientist and full professor at Complutense University of Madrid.
- He is a pioneer researcher in the field of Software Agents and co-creator of the FIPA MESSAGE and INGENIAS methodologies.
- Pavón worked at Alcatel-Lucent R&D for 10 years before joining the academic world in 1997.
- His work has focused on software agents research, INGENIAS, agent-based social simulation, and other interdisciplinary research areas.
- Pavón has achieved multiple agreements with relevant research groups and has worked on more than 30 research projects.
- He has published over 260 scientific publications and has an H-index of 31.
- Pavón has received scientific recognitions including an honorary PhD from the Université Pierre et Marie Curie in 2006.
- His research group GRASIA has achieved recognition through awards such as the AAMAS 2008 Best Academic Software Demo for INGENIAS.
- Pavón is the author of several books and highly cited scientific articles.
Judy Goldsmith (computer scientist):
- Judy Goldsmith is a computer scientist and professor at the University of Kentucky
- Her publications cover topics such as artificial intelligence, computational complexity theory, decision theory, and computer science education
- Goldsmith completed her Ph.D. at the University of Wisconsin-Madison in mathematics in 1988
- She has spoken in favor of using science fiction to teach the ethics of artificial intelligence in computer science education
- Goldsmith participates in the Lexington, Kentucky Havurah and serves on the board of Sapiens Plurum
- In 1997, she won the Mentor Award of the American Association for the Advancement of Sciences
- Selected publications include papers on nondeterminism within P*, the computational complexity of probabilistic planning, and the complexity of finite-horizon Markov decision process problems
Juris Hartmanis:
- Juris Hartmanis was a Latvian-born American computer scientist and computational theorist.
- He was awarded the 1993 ACM Turing Award alongside Richard E. Stearns for their paper on computational complexity theory.
- Hartmanis received a master's degree in applied mathematics from the University of Kansas City and a Ph.D. in mathematics from Caltech in 1955.
- He contributed significantly to national efforts to advance computer science and engineering.
- Hartmanis died on July 29, 2022.
- The foundational notion of complexity classes and the time hierarchy theorem were defined in Hartmanis and Stearns' seminal paper.
- Hartmanis continued to make significant contributions to the field of computational complexity theory for decades.
- He received many awards throughout his career, including the ACM Distinguished Service Award and the grand medal of the Latvian Academy of Sciences.
- Hartmanis was interviewed several times and videos of two of these interviews are available.
J\u00fcrg Gutknecht:
- Jürg Gutknecht is a Swiss computer scientist and professor.
- He worked for Swissair and IBM before getting his Ph.D. in mathematics from ETH Zurich in 1978.
- He joined Niklaus Wirth's research team in 1981, where they developed the Lilith computer and Modula-2.
- After a sabbatical at PARC, Gutknecht developed the Oberon operating system and programming language with Wirth.
- He also developed the system Sakkara and the programming language Zonnon.
- Gutknecht's publications are not mentioned.
- His personal webpage and profile on ETH Zurich's website are provided as external links.
J\u00fcrgen Schmidhuber:
- Jürgen Schmidhuber is a German computer scientist known for his work in artificial intelligence (AI), deep learning, and artificial neural networks.
- He is currently the scientific director of the Dalle Molle Institute for Artificial Intelligence Research in Lugano, Switzerland.
- Schmidhuber completed his undergraduate and PhD studies at the Technical University of Munich in Germany and later became a professor of AI at the Università della Svizzera Italiana in Lugano.
- With his students, Schmidhuber has published increasingly sophisticated versions of a type of recurrent neural network called the long short-term memory (LSTM), which has become a crucial component in speech recognition technology used by Google, Apple, Amazon, and Facebook.
- Schmidhuber's team at IDSIA achieved groundbreaking speedups of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) using fast parallel computers called GPUs, which led to the first superhuman performance in a computer vision contest.
- In 2014, Schmidhuber founded Nnaisense, a company focused on commercial applications of AI in fields such as finance, heavy industry, and self-driving cars.
- Schmidhuber has been referred to as the "father of modern AI" and the "father of deep learning," though he has credited Alexey Grigorevich Ivakhnenko as the "father of deep learning."
- Schmidhuber has been critical of fellow deep learning researchers Geoffrey Hinton, Yann LeCun, and Yoshua Bengio for allegedly understating the contributions of early machine learning pioneers, including Schmidhuber and Ivakhnenko.
- Schmidhuber has received several awards and honors, including the Helmholtz Award and the Neural Networks Pioneer Award for his contributions to deep learning and neural networks.
Karlheinz Brandenburg:
- Karlheinz Brandenburg is a German electrical engineer and mathematician
- He developed the MP3 method for audio data compression with Ernst Eberlein, Heinz Gerhauser, Bernhard Grill, Jurgen Herre, and Harald Popp
- He has also worked in the fields of audio coding, perception measurement, wave field synthesis, and psychoacoustics
- Brandenburg received a Dipl. Ing. degree from Erlangen University in Electrical Engineering and a Dipl. Math. degree in Mathematics and obtained his PhD from the Friedrich-Alexander University Erlangen-Nuremberg in Electrical Engineering
- Brandenburg's research on digital audio coding and perceptual measurement techniques is the basis for MPEG-1 Layer 3 (MP3), MPEG-2 Advanced Audio Coding (AAC), and most other modern audio compression schemes
- He has been a professor of electronic media technology at the Technical University Ilmenau since 2000 and currently serves as the director of the Fraunhofer Institute for Digital Media Technology (IDMT)
- Brandenburg has received numerous national and international research awards, prizes, and honors
- He has been called the "father of MP3" format
- Some of the awards he has received include the IEEE Masaru Ibuka Consumer Electronics Award, the German Future Award, and the Information of the IIS about the German Future Award 2000.
Kathleen Booth:
- Kathleen Booth was a British computer scientist and mathematician
- She wrote the first assembly language and designed the assembler and autocode for the first computer systems at Birkbeck College, University of London
- She helped design three different machines including the ARC (Automatic Relay Calculator), SEC (Simple Electronic Computer), and APE(X)C
- Booth obtained a BSc in mathematics from the University of London in 1944 and a PhD in Applied Mathematics in 1950
- She was a Research Scientist at British Rubber Producers' Research Association and a Research Fellow and Lecturer at Birkbeck College, University of London
- Booth's research on neural networks led to successful programs simulating ways in which animals recognise patterns and characters
- She co-authored "Automatic Digital Calculators" (1953) which illustrated the 'Planning and Coding' programming style
- Booth died on 29 September 2022, at the age of 100.
Kathy Pham:
- Kathy Pham is a computer scientist and product management executive.
- She has held leadership roles at Google, IBM, the Georgia Tech Research Institute, and Harris Healthcare.
- Pham was a founding member of the United States Digital Service in the Executive Office of the President of the United States at The White House.
- She is a Fellow and Faculty member at the Harvard Kennedy School, where she teaches Product Management and Society.
- Pham has been a Fellow at Mozilla and the Harvard Berkman Klein Center, where she co-founded the Ethical Tech Group and was part of the Ethics and Governance of Artificial Intelligence Fellows.
- Pham co-leads the Responsible Computer Science Challenge and co-founded the Mozilla Fix the Internet Incubator.
- She founded Product and Society, which focuses on product management, ethics, and the public interest.
- Pham has won several honors, including being inducted into the Computing Hall of Fame at the Georgia Institute of Technology and being invited to give commencement speeches at Harvard University and the Harvard Kennedy School.
- She is also the founder and executive director of the Cancer Sidekick Foundation and the founder of the Boston Chapter of Women in Product.
Kelsey Hightower:
- Kelsey Hightower is an American software engineer, developer advocate, and speaker.
- He is known for his work with Kubernetes, open-source software, and cloud computing.
- Hightower grew up in Long Beach, California and later moved to Atlanta, Georgia for high school.
- He enrolled in Clayton State University but didn't continue because he found the technology courses lacking.
- Hightower earned his CompTIA A+ information technology (IT) certification and got a job with BellSouth installing DSL service.
- He started his own IT consultancy and later worked briefly at Google and Total Systems before joining Puppet as a software engineer in 2013.
- Hightower briefly worked at a small Portland startup called Monsoon Commerce, at which he wrote confd, his open-source project.
- He joined CoreOS in 2014 and began to contribute significantly to the Kubernetes project.
- Hightower has worked for Google as an engineer and developer advocate in their cloud computing division since November 2015.
- In 2014, Hightower became an active evangelist of Kubernetes and began to speak widely on the topic at developer conferences.
- He co-founded the Kubernetes-focused conference KubeCon in 2015 and co-wrote a book with Kubernetes co-founders Joe Beda and Brendan Burns titled "Kubernetes Up and Running" in 2017.
- Hightower was co-chair of the O'Reilly Open Source Convention in 2019 and on the governing board of the Cloud Native Computing Foundation.
- He is a distinguished engineer, level 9 (L9) as an individual contributor, with Google Cloud as of October 2022.
Ken Forbus:
- Ken Forbus is a Walter P. Murphy Professor of Computer Science and Professor of Education at Northwestern University.
- He received his Bachelor of Science, Master of Science, and PhD in artificial intelligence from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
- Forbus is known for his research in qualitative process theory, automated sketch understanding, and automated analogical reasoning.
- He developed the structure mapping engine based on the structure-mapping theory of Dedre Gentner.
- Forbus is a fellow of the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence (AAAI) and the Cognitive Science Society.
Ken Kennedy (computer scientist):
- Ken Kennedy was an American computer scientist and professor at Rice University
- He was the founding chairman of Rice's Computer Science Department
- Kennedy directed the construction of several substantial software systems for programming parallel computers
- He wrote over 200 articles and book chapters, plus numerous conference addresses
- Kennedy was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 1990 and named a Fellow of the AAAS in 1994 and of the ACM and IEEE in 1995
- In 1999, he was named recipient of the ACM SIGPLAN Programming Languages Achievement Award
- Kennedy died of pancreatic cancer in Houston at the age of 61
- On November 18, 2009, the ACM and IEEE awarded the first Ken Kennedy CS Award to Francine Berman of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute
- His last publication was about the failure of the High Performance Fortran language which he had championed
- Kennedy directed the PhD dissertations of 38 graduate students and masters theses for 8 students.
Ken Thompson (computer programmer):
- Kenneth Lane Thompson is an American pioneer of computer science
- He designed and implemented the original Unix operating system while working at Bell Labs
- Thompson invented the B programming language, the predecessor to C, and was involved in the development of the Plan 9 operating system
- Other notable contributions include work on regular expressions, text editors, endgame tablebases in chess, and the UTF-8 encoding
- Thompson won the Turing Award in 1983 with Dennis Ritchie for their development of generic operating systems theory and specifically for the implementation of the UNIX operating system
- Thompson retired from Bell Labs in 2000 and began working at Google, where he co-developed the Go programming language
- He has received numerous awards throughout his career, including the National Medal of Technology, the IEEE Richard W. Hamming Medal, and the Japan Prize
- Thompson is married and has a son.
Kit Cosper:
- James Kitchen "Kit" Cosper was the sixth employee at Red Hat and a founder of Linux Hardware Solutions and Linux International.
- After LHS was acquired by VA Linux, Cosper became the Director of Miscellaneous, then managed their Open Source advocacy group.
- In 2001, he left VA and became the Executive Technical Advisor and interim CTO at Telkonet, a powerline networking startup in Maryland.
- Cosper is married to Lourie Cosper, and they have three children: William, Keifer, and Elizabeth.
- His first grandchild, Hulet James Cosper, was born in January 2019 to his oldest son and his wife.
- External links include an article on open source and Microsoft, and a personal info page from WayBackMachine.
Klara Dan von Neumann:
- Klára Dán von Neumann was a Hungarian-American computer scientist and one of the first computer programmers.
- She was born in Budapest in 1911 to a wealthy Jewish family and became a national champion in figure skating at the age of 14.
- After marrying mathematician John von Neumann, she moved to the United States and worked as a programmer at Los Alamos National Laboratory and Princeton University.
- She helped program the MANIAC I and ENIAC machines, and assisted in producing the first successful meteorological forecast on a computer.
- Dán wrote the preface to her husband's Silliman Lectures after his death in 1957.
- She married oceanographer and physicist Carl Eckart in 1958 and died in 1963, with her death listed as a suicide.
- Further reading includes "Turing's Cathedral: The Origins of the Digital Universe" by George Dyson and "Klara and the Bomb" by Crystal Bennes.
- There is a podcast episode about Dán titled "A Grasshopper in Very Tall Grass" in the "Lost Women of Science" series.
Klaus-Robert M\u00fcller:
- Klaus-Robert Müller is a German computer scientist and physicist.
- He is known for his work in machine learning and brain-computer interfaces.
- He received his Diplom in mathematical physics and PhD in theoretical computer science from the University of Karlsruhe.
- He started building up the Intelligent Data Analysis (IDA) group at GMD/Berlin in 1995.
- He became an associate professor for neuroinformatics at the University of Potsdam in 1999 and a full professor for Neural Networks and Time Series Analysis in 2003.
- Since 2006, he has held the chair for Machine Learning at the Technical University Berlin.
- He co-founded and co-directs the Berlin Big Data Center (BBDC).
- 29 former doctoral or postdoctoral researchers he has supervised have become full professors themselves.
- His research interests include statistical learning theory, learning of non-stationarity data, fusion of structured heterogeneous multi-modal data, and various applications of machine learning.
- He has received several honours and awards, including the Vodafone Innovations Award 2017 and the Science Prize of Berlin 2014.
- He has co-edited several books, including "xxAI - Beyond Explainable Artificial Intelligence" and "Explainable AI: Interpreting, Explaining, and Visualizing Deep Learning".
- His publications are indexed by Google Scholar, and he has an official website.
Kleene closure:
- Kleene star is a unary operation used in mathematical logic and computer science.
- It can be applied to sets of strings or characters and is often used in the context of regular expressions.
- When applied to a set of strings, it produces the smallest superset of the set that contains the empty string and is closed under string concatenation.
- When applied to a set of characters, it produces the set of all possible strings that can be generated from the characters.
- The Kleene plus is a variation that omits the empty string from the resulting set.
- The Kleene star can be applied to any monoid, not just strings, and is part of the algebraic structure of complete star semiring.
Kristen Nygaard:
- Kristen Nygaard was a Norwegian computer scientist, programming language pioneer, and politician.
- Nygaard co-invented object-oriented programming and the programming language Simula with Ole-Johan Dahl in the 1960s.
- Nygaard and Dahl received the 2001 A. M. Turing Award for their contribution to computer science.
- Nygaard worked at the Norwegian Defense Research Establishment and the Norwegian Computing Center, where he became the Director of Research.
- Nygaard conducted research on planning, control, and data processing for Norwegian trade unions, as well as the social impact of computer technology and the general system description language DELTA.
