- Nygaard was a professor at Aarhus University and the University of Oslo, where he developed the Scandinavian School in System Development and the general object-oriented programming language BETA.
- Nygaard received several awards and recognitions for his work, including the Norbert Wiener Award and the IEEE John von Neumann Medal.
- Nygaard was also involved in Norwegian politics and activism, particularly against Norway's membership in the European Common Market and the European Union.
- Nygaard died of a heart attack in 2002.
Kunihiko Fukushima:
- Kunihiko Fukushima is a Japanese computer scientist.
- He is known for his work on artificial neural networks and deep learning.
- He published neocognitron in 1980, the original deep convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture.
- He proposed several supervised and unsupervised learning algorithms to train the parameters of the neocognitron to learn internal representations of incoming data.
- Fukushima received his Bachelor of Engineering in electronics from Kyoto University in 1958.
- He served as founding President of the Japanese Neural Network Society (JNNS) and was a founding member on the Board of Governors of the International Neural Network Society (INNS) and President of the Asia-Pacific Neural Network Assembly (APNNA).
- In 2020, Fukushima received the Bower Award and Prize for Achievement in Science, the IEICE Achievement Award and Excellent Paper Awards, the IEEE Neural Networks Pioneer Award, the APNNA Outstanding Achievement Award, the JNNS Excellent Paper Award, and the INNS Helmholtz Award.
- He is currently working part-time as a Senior Research Scientist at the Fuzzy Logic Systems Institute in Fukuoka, Japan.
- His ResearchMap profile can be found in the External links section.
Kurt Bollacker:
- Kurt Bollacker is an American computer scientist.
- He has a research background in machine learning, digital libraries, semantic networks, and electro-cardiographic modeling.
- Bollacker received a Ph.D. in Computer Engineering from The University of Texas at Austin.
- He worked as a biomedical research engineer at the Duke University Medical Center where he worked on electro-cardiography.
- Bollacker co-created the CiteSeer research tool while a visiting researcher at the NEC Research Institute.
- He led the work to create The Wayback Machine while Technical Director of the Internet Archive.
- Bollacker was a key contributor to the development of Freebase while Chief Scientist at Metaweb Technologies.
- He worked at Applied Minds and as a consulting Data Scientist after Metaweb.
- Bollacker is involved with multiple non-profit organizations and serves on the Advisory Board of The Common Crawl Foundation.
- He has pursued research on long-term digital archiving as the Digital Research Director at the non-profit Long Now Foundation.
- Lester Randolph Ford Jr. was an American mathematician specializing in network flow problems
- He is the son of mathematician Lester R. Ford Sr.
- Ford's paper with D. R. Fulkerson established the max-flow min-cut theorem in 1954
- He developed the Bellman–Ford algorithm for finding shortest paths in graphs with negative weights in 1956
- With Selmer M. Johnson, he developed the Ford–Johnson algorithm for sorting
- In 1963, he published an innovative textbook on calculus with his father, Lester R. Ford
- He earned his bachelor's degree from the University of Chicago and his Ph.D. in mathematics from the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign
- He worked for the U. S. Army, University of North Carolina, and RAND Corporation
- He was married twice and had nine children with his first wife, Janet Johnson
- He passed away on February 26, 2017.
Larry Tesler:
- Lawrence Gordon Tesler was an American computer scientist who focused on human-computer interaction.
- He worked at Xerox PARC, Apple, Amazon, and Yahoo!.
- At PARC, Tesler worked on Smalltalk, the first dynamic object-oriented programming language, and Gypsy, the first word processor with a graphical user interface (GUI) for the Xerox Alto. He also developed the idea of copy and paste functionality and the idea of modeless software.
- At Apple, Tesler worked on the Apple Lisa, the Apple Newton, and helped to develop Object Pascal and its use in application programming toolkits including MacApp.
- Tesler also co-founded Stagecast Software and was later an independent consultant helping Silicon Valley companies with designing their user interfaces.
- He maintained a counterculture vision that computers should be for everyone and was an advocate for modeless software.
- Tesler died on February 16, 2020, at the age of 74.
Latanya Sweeney:
- Latanya Arvette Sweeney is an American computer scientist and a professor at Harvard University.
- She is the founder and director of the Public Interest Tech Lab and the Data Privacy Lab.
- Sweeney is credited with the observation that "87% of the U.S. population is uniquely identified by date of birth, gender, postal code".
- She completed her undergraduate degree in computer science at the Harvard University Extension School and received her Ph.D. from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
- Sweeney founded the Data Privacy Lab at Carnegie Mellon University in 2001.
- Her research has focused on data privacy and re-identification, which includes her successful identification of then Massachusetts governor, William Weld, using publicly accessible records.
- Her work has had a significant impact on privacy-centered policymaking, including the health privacy legislation HIPAA.
- Sweeney's research aims to provide a cross-disciplinary perspective about privacy in the process of disseminating data.
- In 2021, Sweeney launched the Public Interest Technology Lab at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government.
Lawrence J. Fogel:
- Lawrence Fogel was a pioneer in evolutionary computation and human factors analysis.
- He worked in aerospace engineering and antenna design, and designed active noise cancellation to reduce noise in helicopter cockpit environments.
- He was interested in information theory and communications, and worked for Convair and General Dynamics on the F-102 Delta Dagger, F-106 Delta Dart, and other missile and electronics products.
- Fogel explored evolutionary programming for time-series prediction, which became the basis of his Ph.D. dissertation and the first book in the field of evolutionary computation.
- In 1965, he founded Decision Science, Inc. specifically for applications of evolutionary programming.
- He was also well known for his interest in radio-controlled sailboats and sailplanes, as well as music.
- Fogel received many scientific honors and published several articles and books on evolutionary programming and other topics.
Lawrence M. Breed:
- Lawrence Moser "Larry" Breed was a computer scientist, artist and inventor.
- He created the first computer animation language and system at Stanford University in 1961.
- As a graduate student, he corresponded with APL's inventor, Ken Iverson, and helped create the first implementation of APL with Philip S. Abrams.
- Breed received the Grace Murray Hopper Award in 1973 for his work in the design and implementation of APL.
- He co-founded Scientific Time Sharing Corporation in 1969 and led the development of the APL PLUS time-sharing system.
- Breed rejoined IBM in 1977 and worked on the ISO APL standard and porting BSD Unix onto IBM platforms.
- After retiring in 1992, he became a significant contributor to the Burning Man event, creating artistic installations and promoting the "Leave No Trace" ethos.
- Breed also devised the Gray-B-Gon and Evapotron evaporators for graywater disposal, directing the construction of over 100 units by Burning Man campers as of 2012.
- Breed authored several publications related to APL and file systems.
Lawrence Paulson:
- Lawrence Charles Paulson is a computer scientist and a professor of Computational Logic at the University of Cambridge.
- He graduated from the California Institute of Technology in 1977 and obtained his PhD in Computer Science from Stanford University in 1981.
- Paulson is best known for his text on the programming language ML and his research on the interactive theorem prover Isabelle.
- He has worked on the verification of cryptographic protocols and formalised the constructible universe of Kurt Gödel.
- Paulson teaches an undergraduate course called Logic and Proof.
- In 2017, he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society and in 2008, a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery.
- Paulson has two children from his first marriage, and he married Dr Elena Tchougounova in 2012.
Lee Giles:
- Clyde Lee Giles is a computer scientist and professor at Pennsylvania State University
- He has graduate degrees from the University of Michigan and the University of Arizona, and undergraduate degrees from Rhodes College and the University of Tennessee
- He is known for his work on creating novel scientific and academic search engines and digital libraries, and is considered one of the founders of academic document search
- He has researched in various fields, including recurrent neural networks, optical computing, intelligent web and cyberinfrastructure tools, search engines and information retrieval, and data mining
- He has over 500 publications and an h-index of 113
- He is a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery, Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, and International Neural Networks Society
- He has twice received the IBM Distinguished Faculty Award and other awards from various societies and organizations
- He has also served as an expert witness for Google and Yahoo
Lenore Blum:
- Lenore Carol Blum is an American computer scientist and mathematician.

- She has contributed to the theories of real number computation, cryptography, and pseudorandom number generation.

- She was a distinguished career professor of computer science at Carnegie Mellon University until 2019 and is currently a professor in residence at the University of California, Berkeley.

- Blum has made efforts to increase diversity in mathematics and computer science by establishing mentoring and outreach programs for women, including the Women@SCS program at CMU.

- She is known for the Blum Blum Shub pseudorandom number generator and the Blum-Shub-Smale machine, a theoretical model of computation over the real numbers.

- Blum has won several awards, including the Presidential Award for Excellence in Science, Mathematics, and Engineering Mentoring and the Simmons University 2018 Distinguished Alumnae Lifetime Achievement Award.

- She is a fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and the American Mathematical Society, and she was selected as a fellow of the Association for Women in Mathematics in the inaugural class.

- Blum is married to Manuel Blum and is the mother of Avrim Blum, all of whom are MIT alumni and professors of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon.
Leonard Adleman:
- Leonard Adleman is an American computer scientist and mathematician.
- He is one of the creators of the RSA encryption algorithm.
- Adleman received the Turing Award in 2002 for his work on the RSA cryptosystem.
- He also created the field of DNA computing, which uses DNA as a computational system.
- Adleman solved a seven-node instance of the Hamiltonian Graph problem using DNA computing in 1994, which was the first known use of DNA to compute an algorithm.
- He is referred to as the Father of DNA Computing.
- Adleman and his research group solved a 20-variable SAT problem using DNA computation in 2002.
- Adleman is also known for his work on the Adleman-Pomerance-Rumely primality test and for coining the term "computer virus."
- He is currently working on the mathematical theory of Strata and is a Computer Science professor at the University of Southern California.
- Adleman has received numerous awards, including the Paris Kanellakis Theory and Practice Award and the 2021 ACM Fellow.
Leonard Kleinrock:
- Leonard Kleinrock is an American computer scientist and a professor at UCLA's Henry Samueli School of Engineering and Applied Science.
- Kleinrock is best known for his work in queueing theory, which he applied to model delays in message switching networks in his Ph.D. thesis.
- He later applied queueing theory to model the performance of packet switching networks, which played an influential role in the development of the ARPANET.
- Kleinrock supervised graduate students who worked on communication protocols for internetworking, which led to the development of the Internet protocol suite.
- His work on hierarchical routing in the late 1970s with student Farouk Kamoun remains critical to the operation of the Internet today.
- Kleinrock has received numerous professional awards, including being elected as a member of the National Academy of Engineering and receiving the Draper Prize for the development of the Internet.
- He has been inducted into the Internet Hall of Fame by the Internet Society and granted the 2014 BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award for his contributions to the theory and practical development of the Internet.
Leonid Levin:
- Leonid Anatolievich Levin is a Soviet-American mathematician and computer scientist
- He is known for his work in randomness in computing, algorithmic complexity and intractability, average-case complexity, foundations of mathematics and computer science, algorithmic probability, theory of computation, and information theory.
- He obtained his master's degree at Moscow University in 1970 where he studied under Andrey Kolmogorov and completed the Candidate Degree academic requirements in 1972.
- He and Stephen Cook independently discovered the existence of NP-complete problems.
- This NP-completeness theorem, often called the Cook–Levin theorem, was a basis for one of the seven Millennium Prize Problems declared by the Clay Mathematics Institute with a $1,000,000 prize offered.
- The Cook–Levin theorem was an important step in the development of the theory of computational complexity.
- Levin was awarded the Knuth Prize in 2012 for his discovery of NP-completeness and the development of average-case complexity.
- He is a member of the US National Academy of Sciences and a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
- Levin currently works as a professor of computer science at Boston University, where he began teaching in 1980.
Leslie Lamport:
- Leslie B. Lamport is an American computer scientist and mathematician.
- He is best known for his work in distributed systems and for developing LaTeX and its first manual.
- He won the 2013 Turing Award for his contributions to distributed and concurrent systems.
- His research in distributed systems includes work on logical clocks, consensus algorithms, and determining consistent global states.
- Lamport also worked on temporal logic, including the introduction of temporal logic of actions (TLA).
- He has received multiple awards and honors, including five honorary doctorates and the IEEE John von Neumann Medal.
Leslie Valiant:
- Leslie Gabriel Valiant is a British American computer scientist and computational theorist.
- He is the T. Jefferson Coolidge Professor of Computer Science and Applied Mathematics at Harvard University.
- Valiant was awarded the Turing Award in 2010, described by the A.C.M. as a heroic figure in theoretical computer science.
- Valiant was educated at King's College, Cambridge, Imperial College London, and the University of Warwick.
- He made significant contributions to complexity theory, including the notion of #P-completeness and the probably approximately correct (PAC) model of machine learning.
- Valiant also works in computational neuroscience, focusing on memory and learning.
- He received numerous awards and honors, including the Nevanlinna Prize, Knuth Prize, and EATCS Award.
- Valiant is a Fellow of the Royal Society, the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence, and a member of the United States National Academy of Sciences.
- Valiant's two sons are both theoretical computer scientists.
Linus Torvalds:
- Linus Torvalds is a Finnish software engineer.
- He is the creator and former lead developer of the Linux kernel.
- Torvalds was also the creator of the Git distributed version control system.
- He was honored with the Millennium Technology Prize in 2012 for his creation of Linux.
- Torvalds is married with three daughters and is an atheist.
- He has been recognized by Time magazine as one of the most influential people in the world and was named one of "the best managers" by BusinessWeek.
- Torvalds holds the Linux trademark and monitors its use through the Linux Mark Institute.
- He developed an interest in scuba diving and created the Subsurface project.
- Torvalds has been involved in controversy over his behavior on the Linux kernel mailing list.
- He has authored or co-authored several books, including "Just for Fun: The Story of an Accidental Revolutionary."
Lisa Anthony:
- Lisa Anthony is an Associate Professor in the Department of Computer & Information Science & Engineering (CISE) at the University of Florida and director of the Intelligent Natural Interaction Technology Laboratory (INIT Lab).
- Her research interests are in developing natural user interfaces for greater human-computer interaction, specifically for children.
- Lisa Anthony earned a B.S. and M.S. in computer science from Drexel University and a Ph.D. from Carnegie Mellon University in 2008, focusing on developing handwriting-based systems for algebra equation-solving.
- Anthony was also a Post-Doctoral Research Associate and Research Assistant Professor at the University of Maryland and worked on advanced user interface technologies at Lockheed Martin Advanced Technology Laboratories.
- Lisa Anthony has won a National Science Foundation CAREER Award, HWCOE Undergraduate Faculty Adviser/Mentor of the Year, and various Best Paper Awards. 
- Her publications include journal articles on computer-aided design, user interface prototypes, intelligent tutors, and inferring smartphone users' age group from touch measurements alone.
Lisa Gelobter:
- Lisa Gelobter is a computer scientist, technologist, and CEO.
- She was the Chief Digital Service Officer for the United States Department of Education.
- She founded tEQuitable, a start-up that provides an independent platform to address workplace issues.
- Gelobter raised over $2 million for tEQuitable, becoming one of only 34 Black women to raise $1 million or more in venture capital.
- Gelobter's father was Jewish, and her mother was African-American and from the Caribbean.
- She graduated from Brown University with a degree in computer science with a concentration in artificial intelligence and machine learning.
- Gelobter has experience in strategy development, product management, and engineering.
- She helped to improve HealthCare.gov and led the team that built the United States Department of Education College Scorecard.
- Gelobter was the Chief Digital Officer for BET Networks and worked on Shockwave, a multimedia platform for video games.
- She is on the advisory board of Bridge Foundry and was named one of Fast Company’s Most Creative People.
Lotfi Zadeh:
- Lotfi Aliasker Zadeh was a mathematician, computer scientist, electrical engineer, artificial intelligence researcher, and professor of computer science at the University of California, Berkeley.
- Zadeh proposed fuzzy mathematics, which includes concepts of fuzzy sets, fuzzy logic, fuzzy algorithms, and others.
- He was born in Baku, Azerbaijan, and educated in Iran and the United States.
- Zadeh taught at Columbia University and then joined the faculty at the University of California, Berkeley in 1959, where he remained until he died in 2017.
- He was known for his contributions to classical control systems and to fuzzy sets and systems.
- Zadeh received numerous awards and honors, including the IEEE Medal of Honor and the Benjamin Franklin Medal in Electrical Engineering.
- In 2014, the IEEE Systems, Man, and Cybernetics Society established the "Lotfi A. Zadeh Pioneer Award" to honor his contributions to academic and industrial research in systems science and engineering, human-machine systems, and cybernetics.
Luca Cardelli:
- Luca Andrea Cardelli is an Italian computer scientist and research professor at the University of Oxford.
- He is known for his research in type theory and operational semantics.
- Cardelli helped design the language Modula-3 and implemented the first compiler for the functional language ML.
- He defined the concept of typeful programming and helped develop the experimental language Polyphonic C#.
- Cardelli received his PhD from the University of Edinburgh in 1982.
- He previously worked for Bell Labs and Digital Equipment Corporation on Unix software including vismon.
- Cardelli was inducted as a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery in 2004 and was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 2005.
- In 2007, he was awarded the Senior AITO Dahl-Nygaard Prize named for Ole-Johan Dahl and Kristen Nygaard.
M. A. Rothman:
- Michael A. Rothman is an American engineer and writer of science fiction, epic fantasy, and techno thriller novels. 
- He holds over 1000 patents worldwide and is one of the primary architects of the UEFI standard.
- His debut novel was the epic fantasy young adult Heirs of Prophecy, published in 2012. 
- Three of his novels have appeared on the USA Today bestseller list.
- He has written several novels in the hard science fiction, epic fantasy, techno thriller, and dystopia genres.
- Rothman is a senior engineer at Intel and is the chair of the UEFI Configuration Sub-team (UCST).
- His non-fiction writing includes books and papers on the UEFI standard, published under his full name.
- His fiction writing includes multiple series in different genres, published under the name M. A. Rothman. 
- Critical reception of his writing has been positive, with praise for his character development and use of science.
Maciej Stachowiak:
- Maciej Stachowiak is a Polish American software developer.
- He is currently employed by Apple Inc. as a leader of the development team responsible for the WebKit Framework.
- Stachowiak was involved with the SCWM, GNOME, and Nautilus projects for Linux before joining Apple.
- He is actively involved in the development of web standards and served as a co-chair of the World Wide Web Consortium's HTML 5 working group.
- Stachowiak completed his education at MIT, where he worked on the Rethinking CS101 project.
- From 1999 to 2001, he worked for Eazel and contributed to various Linux software projects, including Nautilus file manager.
- Most of the engineers from Eazel joined Apple's Safari team in June 2001.
- Stachowiak announced the release of JavaScriptCore on a mailing list in 2002.
- He co-authored the W3C HTML Design Principles for HTML5 in May 2009.
- Stachowiak is a co-chair of the World Wide Web Consortium's HTML Working Group along with IBM's Sam Ruby and Microsoft's Paul Cotton.
Madhu Sudan:
- Madhu Sudan is an Indian-American computer scientist
- He is currently a Gordon McKay Professor of Computer Science at the Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences
- Sudan received his bachelor's degree in computer science from IIT Delhi in 1987 and his doctoral degree in computer science at the University of California, Berkeley in 1992
- He worked at IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center and then at MIT before joining Microsoft Research New England as a permanent researcher from 2009 to 2015
- Sudan was awarded the Rolf Nevanlinna Prize, the ACM's Distinguished Doctoral Dissertation Award, the Gödel Prize, and the Infosys Prize for his work in advancing the theory of probabilistically checkable proofs and developing error-correcting codes
- He is a fellow of the ACM and the American Mathematical Society
- In 2017, Sudan was elected to the National Academy of Sciences
- In 2021, he was awarded the IEEE Richard W. Hamming Medal for his contributions to theoretical computer science
Mahadev Satyanarayanan:
- Mahadev "Satya" Satyanarayanan is an Indian experimental computer scientist and professor at Carnegie Mellon University.
- His research focuses on performance, scalability, availability, and trust challenges in computing systems from the cloud to the mobile edge.
- He is credited with many advances in edge computing, distributed systems, mobile computing, pervasive computing, and Internet of Things.
- He played a role in the development of the Andrew File System (AFS).
- His work on the Coda File System received the ACM SIGOPS Hall of Fame Award in 2015.
- He initiated the Odyssey, Aura, ISR, Olive, Diamond, Elijah, and Gabriel projects.
- His pioneer work on the concept of cloudlets and edge computing has become influential in industry and academia.
Mahmoud Samir Fayed:
- Mahmoud Samir Fayed is a computer programmer and researcher at King Saud University.
- Fayed created the PWCT programming language, a free open source visual programming language for software development, in 2008.
- Fayed also created or designed the Supernova and Ring programming languages, which are also free and open source.
- Fayed received a Master's degree in 2017 from King Saud University, having previously studied computer science at Menoufia University in Egypt.
- In 2013, Fayed worked with other researchers to design the LASCNN algorithm for graph theory.
- Fayed has authored various papers and books on programming languages, and he has worked as a reviewer for the Journal of Visual Languages and Computing.
- Fayed's home page at King Saud University and links to his programming languages can be found on external websites.
Manfred K. Warmuth:
• Manfred Klaus Warmuth is a researcher and former professor at the University of California, Santa Cruz.

• He is mainly interested in computational learning theory.

• Warmuth focuses on online learning algorithms.
Manindra Agrawal:
- Manindra Agrawal is a professor at the Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur.
- He received the first Infosys Prize for Mathematics, the Godel Prize in 2006, and the Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Award in Mathematical Sciences in 2003.
- Agrawal and his co-authors created the AKS primality test, winning the 2006 Fulkerson Prize and the 2006 Gödel Prize.
- He was also awarded the 2002 Clay Research Award for this work.
- The AKS primality test is the first unconditional deterministic algorithm to test an n-digit number for primality in a time that has been proven to be polynomial in n.
- Agrawal was chosen for the first Infosys Mathematics Prize in 2008.
- He served on the Mathematical Sciences jury for the Infosys Prize in 2014 and 2015.
- Agrawal was a visiting scholar at the Institute for Advanced Study in 2003-04.
- He was honored with the Padma Shri in 2013 and the TWAS Prize in 2010.
Manny M Lehman:
- Meir "Manny" Lehman was a professor at Middlesex University and Imperial College London.
- He studied mathematics at Imperial College London and worked at Ferranti and Israel's Ministry of Defense before joining IBM's research division.
- Lehman's research contributions include the early discovery of software evolution and Lehman's laws of software evolution.
- He returned to Imperial College London in 1972 and remained there for 30 years before moving to Middlesex University in 2002.
- Lehman was a Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering and the ACM, and received the Harlan D. Mills Award.
- He passed away in Jerusalem in 2010.
Manolis Kellis:
- Manolis Kellis is a professor of computer science at MIT in the area of computational biology and a member of the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard.
- He has made significant contributions to genomics, human genetics, epigenomics, gene regulation, genome evolution, disease mechanism, and single-cell genomics.
- Kellis co-led several large-scale genomics projects, including the Roadmap Epigenomics project, the ENCODE, GENCODE, and modENCODE projects, and the Genotype Tissue-Expression (GTEx) project.
- He has specific domain expertise in obesity, diabetes, Alzheimer's disease, schizophrenia, heart disease, ALS and FTLD, and cancer.
- Kellis has authored 187 journal publications that have been cited 68,380 times as of July 2018.
- He received numerous awards, including the US Presidential Early Career Award for Scientists and Engineers, the National Science Foundation CAREER award, and the Sloan Research Fellowship.
- Kellis co-taught MIT's required undergraduate introductory algorithm courses and a computational biology course at MIT.
- He gave a TEDx talk on "Decoding A Genomic Revolution" and participated in a Reddit Ask Me Anything (AMA) session.
Manuela M. Veloso:
- Manuela Maria Veloso is the Head of J.P. Morgan AI Research and a professor in the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon University.
- Prior to her current position, she was the Head of the Machine Learning Department at Carnegie Mellon.
- Veloso is a fellow of AAAI, IEEE, AAAS, and ACM.
- She is an international expert in artificial intelligence and robotics and has won several awards for her work.
- Veloso received her Licenciatura and Master of Science degree from Lisbon's Instituto Superior Técnico and her Ph.D. in computer science from Carnegie Mellon.
- Her research focuses on autonomous agents and the combination of cognition, perception, and action to address planning, execution, and learning tasks.
- Veloso and her students have researched and developed various autonomous robots, including soccer robots and mobile service robots.
- She has won the NSF CAREER Award, the Allen Newell Medal, the Einstein Chair Professorship, and the ACM/SIGART Autonomous Agents Research Award.
- Veloso has also served as the president of AAAI and the co-founder and past president of the RoboCup Federation.
- She is featured in the Notable Women in Computing cards.
Marco Dorigo:
- Marco Dorigo is a research director for the Belgian Funds for Scientific Research and a co-director of IRIDIA, the artificial intelligence lab of the Université Libre de Bruxelles.
- He received a PhD in System and Information Engineering in 1992 from the Polytechnic University of Milan.
- He is the leading proponent of the ant colony optimization metaheuristic and one of the founders of the swarm intelligence research field.
- He is involved with research in swarm robotics and is the coordinator of two swarm robotics projects funded by the Future and Emerging Technologies Program of the European Commission.
- He is the founding editor and editor in chief of Swarm Intelligence, the principal peer-reviewed publication dedicated to reporting research and new developments in this multidisciplinary field.
- He has received multiple awards for his contributions to the field, including the Marie Curie Research Excellence Award, Dr A. De Leeuw-Damry-Bourlart award in Applied Sciences, Cajastur International Prize for Soft Computing, and IEEE Frank Rosenblatt Award.
- He is the recipient of an ERC Advanced Grant (2010).
- He is the most cited author in three journals: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man, and Cybernetics; IEEE Computational Intelligence Magazine; and Artificial Life.
- He has authored several notable publications, including "Ant Colony Optimization" with Thomas Stützle, "Swarm Intelligence: From Natural to Artificial Systems" with Eric Bonabeau and Guy Theraulaz, and "Robot Shaping" with Marco Colombetti.
Marek Karpinski:
- Marek Karpinski is a computer scientist and mathematician.
- He is known for his research in the theory of algorithms and their applications, combinatorial optimization, computational complexity, and mathematical foundations.
- He has received several research prizes in these areas.
- Karpinski is currently a Professor of Computer Science and Head of the Algorithms Group at the University of Bonn.
- He is also a member of Bonn International Graduate School in Mathematics BIGS and the Hausdorff Center for Mathematics.
- See also: List of computer scientists, List of mathematicians.
- References are not provided in the summary.
Margaret Burnett:
- Margaret M. Burnett is a computer scientist specializing in human computer interaction and software engineering.
- She is known for her work in visual programming languages, end-user software engineering, and gender-inclusive software.
- Burnett is a Distinguished Professor of Computer Science at Oregon State University and a member of the CHI Academy and a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery.
- She studied at Miami University of Ohio and the University of Kansas where she earned a Ph.D.
- Burnett founded the Lawrence Women's Network, a group for professional women of Lawrence, Kansas.
- She has developed methods for software engineers to check the gender inclusivity of their software and given keynote addresses on the topic.
- In 2016, Burnett became a Distinguished Professor at Oregon State University and was named to the CHI Academy.
- She was elected as a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery in 2017 for her contributions to end-user software engineering and gender-inclusivity.
Margaret Hamilton (scientist):
- Margaret Elaine Hamilton is an American computer scientist, systems engineer, and business owner
- She was the director of the Software Engineering Division of the MIT Instrumentation Laboratory, which developed on-board flight software for NASA's Apollo program
- Hamilton has published more than 130 papers, proceedings, and reports and is one of the people credited with coining the term "software engineering"
- In 2016, she received the Presidential Medal of Freedom from President Barack Obama for her work leading to the development of on-board flight software for NASA's Apollo Moon missions
- Hamilton founded two software companies: Higher Order Software in 1976 and Hamilton Technologies in 1986 in Cambridge, Massachusetts
- She played a critical role in getting humans to the Moon by developing systems software and designing and testing all on-board in-flight software for the Apollo spacecraft's Command and Lunar Module
- Hamilton's innovations go beyond the feats of getting humans to the Moon and include legitimizing software development as an engineering discipline
- Hamilton has received numerous awards including the Augusta Ada Lovelace Award, the NASA Exceptional Space Act Award, the Outstanding Alumni Award by Earlham College, and The Washington Award
- Hamilton was inducted into the National Aviation Hall of Fame in Dayton, Ohio in 2022.
Mario Szegedy:
• Mario Szegedy is a Hungarian-American computer scientist and professor at Rutgers University.
• He received his Ph.D. in computer science from the University of Chicago in 1989.
• Szegedy's research areas include computational complexity theory and quantum computing.
• He has held postdoctoral fellowships at the Hebrew University and University of Chicago, as well as at Bell Laboratories.
• He won the Gödel Prize in 2001 and 2005 for his work on probabilistically checkable proofs and frequency moments in streamed data.
• His work on streaming was also recognized by the 2019 Paris Kanellakis Theory and Practice Award.
• Szegedy is married and has two daughters.
• His home page is available as an external link.
Mario Tchou:
- Mario Tchou was an Italian engineer of Chinese descent who was a pioneer of computer science in Italy.
- He led a group of scientists from the University of Pisa to invent the Olivetti Elea, the world's most powerful computer in 1959.
- Tchou was also a professor at Columbia University and had a bachelor's degree in electrical engineering from the Catholic University of America and graduated from New York University Polytechnic School of Engineering.
- He married artist Elisa Montessori in 1955, and they had two daughters.
- Tchou died at the age of 37 in a car accident between Turin and Milan.
- His wife and colleagues believed his death was part of a wider plan to eliminate Olivetti from the international computer scene.
- After Tchou's death, Olivetti sold its computer division to General Electric.
Mark Overmars:
- Markus Hendrik Overmars is a Dutch computer scientist.
- He is known for his game development application, GameMaker, which allows people to create computer games using a drag-and-drop interface.
- He was the former head of the Center for Geometry, Imaging, and Virtual Environments at Utrecht University, which focuses on computational geometry and its application in various fields, including games.
- Overmars has published over 100 journal papers, largely on computational geometry, and is the co-author of several books.
- He worked in robotics and developed the probabilistic roadmap method in 1992, which is considered one of the most influential studies in motion planning.
- Overmars also co-developed the snake video game, Super Snake HD, as a mobile app.
- He founded and was CTO of Tingly Games, which focused on HTML5 games and "greeting games".
- Overmars founded Quarterfall in 2020, a teaching product that helps teachers use formative assessment to improve student learning.
- He is also the original author of the XForms toolkit.
Mark Weiser:
- Mark D. Weiser was a computer scientist and CTO at Xerox PARC, known as the father of ubiquitous computing
- He coined the term "ubiquitous computing" in 1988
- Weiser taught computer science at the University of Maryland and joined PARC in 1987, becoming its CTO in 1996
- He received posthumous honors such as the Mark Weiser Award and the Mark D. Weiser Excellence in Computing Scholarship Fund
- Weiser was also a drummer for an avant-garde/experimental rock band, Severe Tire Damage
- He advocated for low-powered portable computing and "calm technology"
- Weiser's work includes "The Computer for the 21st Century" published in Scientific American Special Issue on Communications, Computers, and Networks, September 1991.
Marshall Kirk McKusick:
- Marshall Kirk McKusick is a computer scientist known for his work on BSD UNIX.
- He was the president of the USENIX Association and serves on the board.
- He received his B.S. from Cornell University and his Ph.D. in computer science from the University of California, Berkeley.
- McKusick is openly gay and married Eric Allman in 2013.
- He contributed to the design of the Fast File System and implemented soft updates in FFS and UFS2.
- He also created filesystem snapshots and background fsck.
- The Design and Implementation of the 4.3BSD UNIX Operating System and The Design and Implementation of the FreeBSD Operating System are regarded as high-quality works.
- The BSD Daemon is copyrighted by McKusick.
- His home page is available online.
Martin Campbell-Kelly:
- Martin Campbell-Kelly is an Emeritus Professor at the University of Warwick
- He has specialized in the history of computing
- Campbell-Kelly served on the editorial board of the IEEE Annals of the History of Computing journal
- He is a committee member of the Computer Conservation Society and a Gresham College lecturer
- Campbell-Kelly was awarded a PhD in 1980 from Sunderland Polytechnic
- His PhD focused on the Foundations of computer programming in Britain 1945–1955
- He has authored and edited numerous books and journal articles in the history of computing
- Martin Campbell-Kelly can be found on ResearchGate
Martin Charles Golumbic:
- Martin Charles Golumbic is a mathematician and computer scientist
- Known for research on perfect graphs, graph sandwich problems, compiler optimization, and spatial-temporal reasoning
- Professor emeritus of computer science at the University of Haifa
- Founder of the journal Annals of Mathematics and Artificial Intelligence
- Educated at Pennsylvania State University and Columbia University
- Worked for New York University, Bell Laboratories, IBM, Bar-Ilan University, and the University of Haifa
- Fellow of the European Association for Artificial Intelligence and elected to the Academia Europaea
- Awarded the Lifetime Achievement and Service Award of the Israeli Association for Artificial Intelligence in 2019
- Author of Algorithmic Graph Theory and Perfect Graphs, Tolerance Graphs, and Fighting Terror Online: The Convergence of Security, Technology, and the Law
- Highly-cited publications on spill code minimization, reasoning about time, physical mapping of DNA, and graph sandwich problems.
Martin Fowler (software engineer):
- Martin Fowler is a British software developer, author, and international public speaker.
- He specializes in object-oriented analysis and design, UML, patterns, and agile software development methodologies, including extreme programming.
- Fowler's 1999 book Refactoring popularized the practice of code refactoring, and in 2004 he introduced a new architectural pattern called Presentation Model (PM).
- Fowler has written nine books on software development and is a member of the Agile Alliance.
- He helped create the Manifesto for Agile Software Development in 2001.
- Fowler popularized the term Dependency Injection as a form of Inversion of Control. 
- In his book, Domain-specific languages, Fowler discusses the benefits and costs of DSLs, including examples of internal and external DSLs and how to implement them.
Martin Hellman:
- Martin Edward Hellman is an American cryptologist and mathematician.
- He is best known for his involvement with public key cryptography with Whitfield Diffie and Ralph Merkle.
- Hellman has contributed to the computer privacy debate and has applied risk analysis to a potential failure of nuclear deterrence.
- He was elected a member of the National Academy of Engineering in 2002.
- In 2016, he wrote a book with his wife, Dorothie Hellman, on creating love at home to bring peace to the planet.
- Hellman received multiple awards, including the Marconi Fellowship, The Franklin Institute's Louis E. Levy Medal, and the Turing Award in 2015 with Whitfield Diffie.
- He has been active in researching international security since 1985, including involvement in the Beyond War movement and a current project on defusing the nuclear threat.
- Hellman's website NuclearRisk.org has been endorsed by a number of prominent individuals.
Martin Richards (computer scientist):
• Martin Richards is a British computer scientist known for his development of the BCPL programming language. 
• BCPL was part of early research into portable software and is the ancestor of the B programming language invented by Ken Thompson in early versions of Unix. 
• Dennis Ritchie used BCPL as the basis of his widely used C programming language. 
• Richards studied mathematics and earned a PhD in programming language design and implementation from the University of Cambridge. 
• He was a senior lecturer at the University of Cambridge Computer Laboratory until his retirement in 2007. 
• Richards also developed the TRIPOS portable operating system. 
• He was awarded the IEEE Computer Society's Computer Pioneer Award in 2003. 
• Richards is a fellow of St John's College at the University of Cambridge.
Marvin Minsky:
- Marvin Lee Minsky was an American cognitive and computer scientist, co-founder of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's AI laboratory, and author of several texts concerning AI and philosophy.
- Minsky received many accolades and honors, including the 1969 Turing Award, Golden Plate Award of the American Academy of Achievement, Japan Prize, IJCAI Award, Benjamin Franklin Medal, and Dan David Prize for "Artificial Intelligence, the Digital Mind".
- Minsky's contributions to computer science include inventions such as the first head-mounted graphical display and the confocal microscope, the first Logo "turtle", the first randomly wired neural network learning machine, and several AI models.
- His book Perceptrons attacked the work of Frank Rosenblatt and became the center of a controversy in the history of AI, as some claim it discouraged research into neural networks in the 1970s.
- Minsky also developed the Society of Mind theory, which attempts to explain how intelligence could be a product of the interaction of non-intelligent parts.
- Minsky was an adviser on Stanley Kubrick's movie 2001: A Space Odyssey and is mentioned in Arthur C. Clarke's derivative novel of the same name.
- Minsky married pediatrician Gloria Rudischin in 1952, and together they had three children. He was an atheist and a signatory to the Scientists' Open Letter on Cryonics.
- Minsky received a $100,000 research grant from Jeffrey Epstein in 2002, and organized two academic symposia on Epstein's private island Little Saint James. Minsky's widow denies allegations of any inappropriate behavior.
- Minsky died of a cerebral hemorrhage in January 2016, and may or may not have been cryonically preserved by the Alcor Life Extension Foundation.
- Minsky was affiliated with several organizations, including the United States National Academy of Engineering, National Academy of Sciences, and Alcor Life Extension Foundation's Scientific Advisory Board.
Mary Allen Wilkes:
- Mary Allen Wilkes is a lawyer, former computer programmer and logic designer.
- She is known for her work with the LINC computer, now recognized as the world's first "personal computer."
- Wilkes graduated from Wellesley College in 1959 where she majored in philosophy and theology.
- She worked on the Speech Recognition Project at MIT's Lincoln Laboratory in Lexington, Massachusetts from 1959 to 1960.
- Wilkes joined the Digital Computer Group, also at Lincoln Laboratory, just as work was beginning on the LINC design under Wesley A. Clark in June 1961.
- Wilkes left the computer field in 1972 to attend the Harvard Law School and practiced as a trial lawyer for many years.
- Her work has been recognized in Great Britain's National Museum of Computing's 2013 exhibition "Heroines of Computing" at Bletchley Park, and by the Heinz Nixdorf Museums Forum in Paderborn, Germany, in its 2015-16 exhibition, Am Anfang war Ada: Frauen in der Computergeschichte (In the beginning was Ada: Women in Computer History).
- Some of her famous quotes include "I'll bet you don't have a computer in your living room." and "We had the quaint notion at the time that software should be completely, absolutely free of bugs. Unfortunately, it's a notion that never really quite caught on."
Mary Jane Irwin:
- Mary Jane Irwin is an Emerita Evan Pugh Professor at Pennsylvania State University.
- She is an expert in computer architecture, embedded and mobile computing systems design, power and reliability aware design, and emerging technologies in computing systems.
- Irwin received her B.S. in Mathematics from Memphis State University and her M.S. and Ph.D. in Computer Science from the University of Illinois.
- She joined Penn State as an assistant professor in 1977 and retired in 2017.
- Irwin has worked on application-specific architectures and resource constrained systems design.
- She has received numerous awards and honors for her contributions to the field, including being elected a member of the National Academy of Engineering in 2003.
- She has also served on multiple boards and committees within the computer science research community.
- Irwin received the 2019 Phil Kaufman Award, the EDA Industry's highest honor, and is the first woman to receive the award.
- She is married with one son who is also a computer scientist and two grandchildren.
Mathai Joseph:
- Mathai Joseph is an Indian computer scientist and author.

- He studied physics and electronics before obtaining a PhD in computing from Churchill College, Cambridge.

- Joseph worked for the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research and the University of Warwick, where he was a professor of computer science.

- He has also been a visiting professor at Carnegie-Mellon University, Eindhoven University of Technology, and the University of York.

- Joseph's research interests include formal methods related to computer systems, including real-time systems.

- His most cited paper, "Finding Response Times in a Real-Time System", won a Test-of-Time Award in 2020.

- Joseph's joint work with Zhiming Liu on fault tolerance proposes a design process for fault-tolerant systems.

- He is the author of several books, including Digital Republic: India's rise to IT power.

- Joseph is interested in improving science in India.
Matthew Dillon (computer scientist):
- Matthew Dillon is a software engineer known for his work on Amiga software, contributions to FreeBSD, and for starting and leading the DragonFly BSD project since 2003.
- He studied electronic engineering and computer science at the University of California, Berkeley in 1985.
- He founded and worked at Best Internet from 1994 until 1997, contributing to FreeBSD in that time.
- Dillon started the DragonFly BSD project in 2003, implementing the SMP model using light-weight kernel threads.
- The DragonFly project also led to the development of Virtual Kernel and HAMMER file system.
- Dillon has done extensive research on CPU errata, including evaluating Intel Core errata, discovering a deficiency in some AMD processors in 2012, and presenting solutions to tackle security vulnerabilities like Meltdown in 2018.
- He has been a frequent guest on bsdtalk and interviewed several times for KernelTrap.
- External links include his personal website and interviews on IRC and OSNews.
Maurice Nivat:
- Maurice Paul Nivat was a French computer scientist.
- His research focused on formal languages, programming language semantics, and discrete geometry.
- In 2006, he was called one of the fathers of theoretical computer science.
- He was a professor at the University Paris Diderot until 2001 and remained professor emeritus until his death in 2017.
- Nivat was involved in many endeavours in theoretical computer science in Europe, including founding the European Association for Theoretical Computer Science (EATCS) in 1972 and organizing the first International Colloquium on Automata, Languages and Programming (ICALP) conference in the same year.
- He was also a member of the International Federation for Information Processing (IFIP) IFIP Working Group 2.1 on Algorithmic Languages and Calculi.
- Nivat received numerous awards and honors, including being a corresponding member of the French Academy of Sciences, an officer of both the Legion d'honneur and the Ordre national du Mérite, and a commander of the Ordre des Palmes Académiques in France.
- He won the EATCS award in 2002 and received honorary doctorates from the University of Bologna in 1997 and the University of Quebec at Montreal in 2006.
- Nivat completed his 1967 thesis on "Transductions of Chomsky Languages" after studying mathematics at the École Normale Supérieure in Paris under the supervision of Marcel-Paul Schützenberger.
Maurice Vincent Wilkes:
- Sir Maurice Wilkes was a British computer scientist who designed and built the Electronic Delay Storage Automatic Calculator (EDSAC), one of the earliest stored program computers
- He also invented microprogramming, a method for using stored-program logic to operate the control unit of a central processing unit's circuits
- He was born in Dudley, Worcestershire in 1913 and educated at King Edward VI College, Stourbridge
- He studied the Mathematical Tripos at St John's College, Cambridge from 1931 to 1934 and completed his PhD in physics in 1936
- In 1945, Wilkes was appointed as the second director of the University of Cambridge Mathematical Laboratory (later known as the Computer Laboratory)
- Wilkes received several honours and awards, including becoming a Knight Bachelor, receiving the Turing Award in 1967, and being awarded the Faraday Medal by the Institution of Electrical Engineers in 1981
- He died in 2010, leaving behind his wife, one son, and two daughters
Michael Dertouzos:
- Michael Leonidas Dertouzos was a Greek professor in the department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).
- He was also the Director of the MIT Laboratory for Computer Science from 1974 to 2001.
- Dertouzos was a pioneer in many areas of technology and predicted the expansion of computer use very early.
- He made significant contributions to the Web, particularly through his visionary approach to ubiquitous computing.
- His interest in technology was cultivated at an early age when he accompanied his father, an admiral in the Greek navy, aboard destroyers and submarines.
- Dertouzos earned his Ph.D. in electrical engineering from MIT in 1964, and immediately joined the faculty of MIT where he stayed until the end of his career.
- He co-founded Computek, Inc., a manufacturer of graphics and intelligent terminals, with Marvin C. Lewis and Dr. Huber Graham in 1968.
- Dertouzos was instrumental in creating the World Wide Web Consortium and bringing it to MIT.
- He died in 2001 at the age of 64 and is buried at the First Cemetery of Athens.
- On November 5, 2018, Google recognized him with a doodle.
- Dertouzos authored books like "What Will Be: How the New World of Information Will Change Our Lives", "The Unfinished Revolution: Human-Centered Computers and What They Can Do For Us", and "Made in America: Regaining the Productive Edge."
Michael Guy:
- Michael J. T. Guy is a British computer scientist and mathematician.
- He is known for his work on computer systems and his contributions to number theory, computer algebra, and the theory of polyhedra in higher dimensions.
- He worked with John Horton Conway and is the son of Conway's collaborator Richard K. Guy.
- With Conway, he found the complete solution to the Soma cube of Piet Hein and discovered the grand antiprism, an unusual uniform polychoron in four dimensions.
- Guy's work includes contributions to geometry, number and game theory, and discrete mathematics.
- He also worked on the sporadic groups.
- Guy began work as a research student at the University of Cambridge, but did not complete a Ph.D.
- He subsequently went into computer science and worked on the filing system for Titan, Cambridge's Atlas 2, and was co-author of ALGOL 68C.
- Some of Guy's bibliography includes "Four-Dimensional Archimedean Polytopes" (1965), "On the Distribution of Values of Angles Determined by Coplanar Points" (1979), and "On rational Morley triangles" (2000).
- A book called "The Symmetries of Things" mentions Guy's work on the grand antiprism.
Michael K\u00f6lling:
- Michael Kölling is a German computer scientist.
- He is known for developing BlueJ and Greenfoot, educational development environments, and authoring introductory programming textbooks.
- He earned a degree in informatics from the University of Bremen and a Ph.D. in computer science from the University of Sydney.
- He has held positions at various universities, including the University of Kent, UK, and is currently a professor at King's College London.
- He co-wrote Objects First with Java with David J. Barnes and wrote Introduction to Programming with Greenfoot.
- In 2013, he received the SIGCSE Award for Outstanding Contribution to Computer Science Education.
- He was involved in a patent issue with Microsoft over similarities between the object test bench in BlueJ and a feature in Visual Studio 2005.
- He has received several awards and honors, including the SIGCSE Test of Time Award in 2020 and the Victorian Pearcey Award in 1999.
Michael L. Scott:
- Michael Lee Scott is a professor of computer science at the University of Rochester in New York.
- He received his PhD from the University of Wisconsin–Madison.
- He served as chair of the computer science department at Rochester from 1996 to 1999 and again from 2007 to 2017.
- In 2001, he received the Robert and Pamela Goergen Award for Distinguished Achievement and Artistry in Undergraduate Teaching.
- Scott has published four editions of his text Programming Language Pragmatics, with translations to Greek and simplified Chinese.
- He won the Edsger W. Dijkstra Prize in Distributed Computing in 2006 for a paper he co-wrote in 1991.
- He was also inducted as a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery in 2006.
- Scott is a Unitarian Universalist and served as secretary and president of the New York State Convention of Universalists.
- His work on lock-free concurrent exchanges and synchronous queues is included in the Java 6 concurrency library.
Michael O. Rabin:
- Michael Oser Rabin is an Israeli mathematician and computer scientist
- He was born in 1931 in Breslau, Germany and emigrated to Mandate Palestine in 1935
- He was interested in mathematics from a young age and studied under mathematician Elisha Netanyahu
- He received an M.Sc. from Hebrew University of Jerusalem in 1953 and a Ph.D. from Princeton University in 1956
- Rabin became a professor at various universities including UC Berkeley, MIT, and Harvard University
- He and Dana Scott wrote the paper "Finite Automata and Their Decision Problems" which introduced the idea of nondeterministic machines
- Rabin invented the Miller–Rabin primality test and the Rabin cryptosystem
- He was awarded the Turing Award in 1976 for his work on nondeterministic machines
- Rabin is a member of various prestigious academic societies and has been honored with numerous awards and prizes, including the Israel Prize and the Dan David Prize
- He is currently the Thomas J. Watson Sr. Professor of Computer Science at Harvard University and Professor of Computer Science at Hebrew University
- Rabin has a daughter, computer scientist Tal Rabin.
Michael Stonebraker:
-Michael Ralph Stonebraker is a computer scientist specializing in database systems. 
-Founder of several database companies including Ingres Corporation, Illustra, and StreamBase Systems. 
-Received the 2014 Turing Award for his contributions to database research. 
-Stonebraker's career can be divided into two phases: his time at UC Berkeley when he focused on relational DBMS and at MIT where he developed more novel data management techniques. 
-Notable projects include Ingres, Postgres, Cohera, Aurora, C-Store, Morpheus, H-Store, SciDB, and VoltDB. 
-Stonebraker has been a mentor to over 30 students including founders and CEOs of notable companies in the database industry. 
-Co-founder of Goby, a search engine for free time activities.
Mihai Nadin:
- Mihai Nadin is a scholar and researcher in various fields, including electrical engineering, computer science, aesthetics, semiotics, human-computer interaction, computational design, post-industrial society, and anticipatory systems.
- He has published over 200 works and has lectured worldwide.
- He is currently a professor at the University of Texas at Dallas and is the director of the Institute for Research in Anticipatory Systems.
- Nadin's work in human-computer interaction is grounded in semiotics, with the computer being seen as the "semiotic machine par excellence."
- He founded the world's first program in Computational Design in 1994 at the University of Wuppertal, with the goal of developing a theory of computational design and designing products and processes through digital means.
- The program's long-term goal is the integration of digital technology into all products and processes, leading to a world of ubiquitous computing.
Mihalis Yannakakis:
- Mihalis Yannakakis is a Greek professor of computer science at Columbia University.
- He has made significant contributions to computational complexity, databases, computer-aided verification and testing, and algorithmic graph theory.
- Yannakakis obtained his PhD in Computer Science from Princeton University in 1979.
- He has served on the editorial board of various journals and chaired conferences, such as the ACM Symposium on Principles of Database Systems and the IEEE Symposium on Foundations of Computer Science.
- Yannakakis has made notable contributions in complexity theory, including work on the complexity classes Max-NP and Max-SNP and the hardness of approximations.
- He has also contributed to the study of acyclic databases and non-two-phase locking in database theory.
- Yannakakis has made contributions to computer-aided verification and testing, including the designing of memory-efficient algorithms for the verification of temporal properties of finite-state programs.
- He has won numerous awards, including the Donald E. Knuth Prize in 2005, Bell Labs Distinguished Member of Technical Staff Award, and the Bell Labs President's Gold Award.
- Yannakakis is a fellow of the ACM, Bell Laboratories, and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
- As of June 2020, his publications have been cited close to 35,000 times, and he has an h-index of 93.
Mike Woodger:
- Michael Woodger is a pioneering English computer scientist.
- He worked with Alan Turing on the Pilot ACE computer at the National Physical Laboratory (NPL) in London.
- Woodger was instrumental in the design and documentation of programming languages such as ALGOL 60 and Ada.
- He graduated from University College London in 1943 and worked at the Ministry of Supply during World War II.
- Woodger spent most of his career at NPL. 
- His father was Joseph Henry Woodger, a professor of biology at the University of London.
Monica S. Lam:
- Monica Sin-Ling Lam is a computer scientist and professor at Stanford University.
- She received a B.Sc. from the University of British Columbia in 1980 and a Ph.D. in Computer Science from Carnegie Mellon University in 1987.
- Her research interests include compilers, program analysis, operating systems, security, computer architecture, high-performance computing, natural language processing, and virtual assistants with an emphasis on privacy protection.
- She is the faculty director of the Open Virtual Assistant Lab at Stanford University, which developed the open-source Almond voice assistant, sponsored by the National Science Foundation.
- Lam led the SUIF (Stanford University Intermediate Format) Compiler project, which produced a widely used compiler infrastructure known for its locality optimizations and interprocedural parallelization.
- Her program analysis group developed tools for improving software security and reliability, including the BDDBDDB tool that allows programmers to express context-sensitive analyses simply by writing Datalog queries.
- Lam is also the co-founder of Omlet, an open, decentralized social networking tool based on an extensible chat platform.
- She has received numerous awards and honors, including the National Academy of Engineering member, ACM Fellow, and NSF Young Investigator award.
- Lam has published multiple papers and books, including "Compilers: Principles, Techniques, and Tools" (the "Dragon Book") and "A Systolic Array Optimizing Compiler".
- She has also chaired several conferences and served on editorial boards and program committees for various conferences.
Murray Turoff:
- Murray Turoff was a Distinguished Professor at New Jersey Institute of Technology and a founding father of computer-mediated communication.
- He received his B.A. in Mathematics and Physics and his PhD in Physics.
- Turoff was the co-founder of the Information Systems for Crisis Response and Management (ISCRAM) community.
- He designed the Emergency Management Information System And Reference Index (EMISARI) and the Electronic Information Exchange System (EIES).
- Turoff authored or co-authored 8 books, including The Network Nation.
- He was awarded the EFF Pioneer Award in 1994 and inducted into the International Academy for Systems and Cybernetic Sciences in 2018.
Nadia Magnenat Thalmann:
- Nadia Magnenat Thalmann is a computer graphics scientist and robotician.
- She founded and currently heads the MIRALab at the University of Geneva.
- Thalmann has authored and co-authored more than 600 papers in the field of virtual humans, social robots, VR, and 3D simulation of human articulations.
- She has participated in more than 45 European research projects and created the Computer Animation and Social Agents (CASA) in Geneva.
- Thalmann made numerous research contributions in the area of computer graphics and is known for her work on simulating realistic virtual humans.
- She has worked on the social autonomous robot Nadine, modeled in her image, that can speak, recognize people and gestures, express mood and emotions, and remember actions.
- Thalmann has received several honorary degrees and awards including the Humboldt Research Award, Doctor Honoris Causa in Natural sciences, and the Career Achievement Award by the Canadian Human Computer Communications Society.
- Her film "High Fashion in Equations" won the CGI 2007 Best International Scientific Video award and was shown at the SIGGRAPH Electronic Theatre.
- Thalmann co-created the first simulation of a 3D version of Marilyn Monroe in the film Rendez-vous in Montreal (1987).
Nancy Lynch:
- Nancy Ann Lynch is a mathematician and a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).
- She was born in Brooklyn and received her Ph.D. from MIT in 1972.
- Prior to joining the MIT faculty in 1982, she served on the faculty at several other universities.
- Her research focuses on applying mathematics to the understanding and construction of complex distributed systems.
- In 1985, she worked with Michael J. Fischer and Mike Paterson on consensus problems, which received the PODC Influential-Paper Award in 2001.
- Lynch has authored numerous research articles and a graduate textbook on distributed algorithms.
- She is a member of the National Academy of Sciences, National Academy of Engineering, and an ACM Fellow.
- Lynch has received several awards and recognition, including the Van Wijngaarden Award, Knuth Prize, and the IEEE Emanuel R. Piore Award.
- Lynch's bibliography includes books on atomic transactions, distributed algorithms, and the theory of timed I/O automata.
Neeraj Kayal:
- Neeraj Kayal is an Indian computer scientist and mathematician.
- He is noted for developing the AKS primality test with Manindra Agrawal and Nitin Saxena.
- Kayal was born and raised in Guwahati, India.
- He graduated with a B.Tech from the Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur in 2002.
- Kayal received his PhD from the Department of Computer Science and Engineering at the Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur.
- He has worked at the Microsoft Research Lab India since 2008.
- Kayal has received several awards, including the Distinguished Alumnus Award from the IITK and the Gödel prize and Fulkerson Prize for his work in computational complexity theory.
- He won the Young Scientist Award from the Indian National Science Academy in 2012.
- In 2021, Kayal received the Infosys Prize in Mathematical Sciences.
Neil Daswani:
- Neil Daswani is a co-director of the Stanford Advanced Security Certification Program and an expert in web application security.
- He is the lead author of the book "Foundations of Security: What Every Programmer Needs To Know."
- In 2008, he co-founded Dasient, a web security company.
- Before working at Google and Stanford, he served in research, development, teaching, and managerial roles at Yodlee, Lucent, and Bellcore.
- He has expertise in wireless data technology and peer-to-peer systems, and has published extensively in these areas.
- At Google, he led the authoring of "The Anatomy of Clickbot.A", a detailed analysis of a 100,000 machine botnet constructed to conduct click fraud.
- While at Stanford, he co-founded the Stanford Center for Professional Development (SCPD) Security Certification Program.
- Daswani holds a Ph.D. in computer science from Stanford University, an M.S. in computer science from Stanford University, and a B.S. in computer science with honors with distinction from Columbia University.
Neil J. Gunther:
- Neil Gunther is a computer information systems researcher known for developing the open-source performance modeling software and the Guerrilla approach to computer capacity planning and performance analysis.
- He has made contributions to the field of large transients in computer systems and packet networks, and his universal law of computational scalability.
- Gunther is a Senior Member of various computing organizations, including ACM, IEEE, AMS, APS, and CMG.
- He was born in Melbourne in 1950 and has a background in physics and quantum mechanics.
- Gunther has worked for companies such as Xerox PARC and Pyramid Technology, where he developed performance analysis software and attained high TPC benchmarks on Unix multiprocessors.
- He founded Performance Dynamics Company in 1994 to provide consulting and educational services for high-performance computer systems and developed his own open-source performance modeling software called "PDQ."
- Gunther is currently focused on developing quantum information system technologies and has developed a theory of photon bifurcation.
- He has also worked on performance visualization tools and has co-founded the PerfViz google group.
- Gunther has written several books on performance analysis and has received various awards and recognitions for his work.
Nello Cristianini:
- Nello Cristianini is a Professor of Artificial Intelligence at the University of Bath.
- He has a degree in physics from the University of Trieste, a Master in computational intelligence from the University of London, and a PhD from the University of Bristol.
- Cristianini's research focuses on machine learning, artificial intelligence, and bioinformatics.
- He is the co-author of two widely known books in machine learning and one in bioinformatics.
- Cristianini frequently gives public talks about the need for a deeper ethical understanding of the effects of modern data-science on society.
- He has received the Royal Society Wolfson Research Merit Award and a European Research Council Advanced Grant.
- Cristianini has been listed among the "most influential scientists of the decade" and the Top100 most influential researchers in Machine Learning.
- He was the keynote speaker at the Annual STOA Lecture at the European Parliament in 2017 and a member of the International Advisory Board of STOA from 2020 to 2024.
- Cristianini has published four books and has several online resources available.
- External links include his personal webpage and news articles about his recognition as a top scientist in his field.
Nico Habermann:
- Arie Nicolaas Habermann was a Dutch computer scientist.
- He received his B.S. and M.S. from the Free University of Amsterdam and his Ph.D. from the Eindhoven University of Technology.
- Habermann joined the department of computer science at Carnegie Mellon University in 1968 and served as associate professor, full professor, acting department head, department head, and Dean of the School of Computer Science.
- He co-founded Carnegie Mellon's Software Engineering Institute (SEI) in 1985.
- Habermann's research covered programming languages, operating systems, and software systems development.
- He made contributions to the development of operating systems such as THE multiprogramming system, FAMOS, DAS, and Unix.
- Habermann was known for his work on inter-process communication, process synchronization and deadlock avoidance, and software verification.
- He served as a visiting professor at the University of Newcastle upon Tyne, the Technical University of Berlin, and as an adjunct professor at Shanghai Jiao Tong University.
- The Computing Research Association began giving the A. Nico Habermann Award to people for work that increases the involvement of underrepresented communities in computer research.
Nigel Shadbolt:
- Sir Nigel Richard Shadbolt is currently the Principal of Jesus College, Oxford and a Professorial Research Fellow in the Department of Computer Science at the University of Oxford.
- He co-founded the Open Data Institute with Tim Berners-Lee and serves as its Chairman.
- Shadbolt is an interdisciplinary researcher and commentator, with a focus on understanding intelligent behavior in humans, machines, and on the web. His research covers areas such as psychology, cognitive science, computational neuroscience, artificial intelligence, computer science, and web science.
- He obtained his undergraduate degree in philosophy and psychology at Newcastle University and his PhD from the Department of Artificial Intelligence at the University of Edinburgh.
- Shadbolt has held academic positions at the University of Nottingham and the University of Southampton, where he was Professor of Artificial Intelligence from 2000 to 2015.
- He was elected Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2006 and Fellow of the British Computer Society in 2007. He was also President of the British Computer Society in its 50th jubilee year.
- Shadbolt co-founded the Web Science Research Initiative with Tim Berners-Lee, Wendy Hall, and Daniel Weitzner in 2006 to promote the discipline of web science and foster collaboration between the University of Southampton and Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
- He played a leading role in developing data.gov.uk, a single point of access for UK non-personal governmental public data, and was appointed by the UK Coalition Government to the Public Sector Transparency Board responsible for setting open data standards across the public sector and developing the legal Right to Data.
- Shadbolt and Tim Berners-Lee formally launched the Open Data Institute in December 2012, which focuses on incubating and nurturing new businesses wanting to harness open data, training, and promoting standards.
- He is the author of numerous articles and co-authored the book "The Spy in the Coffee Machine" with Kieron O'Hara.
- Shadbolt is married and has two children.
Niklaus Wirth:
- Niklaus Emil Wirth is a Swiss computer scientist
- He has designed several programming languages, including Pascal and Oberon
- In 1984, he won the Turing Award for developing innovative computer languages
- He was a member of the IFIP Working Group 2.1 on Algorithmic Languages and Calculi
- He was involved in developing international standards in programming and informatics
- Wirth was the chief designer of Euler, PL360, ALGOL W, Pascal, Modula, Modula-2, Oberon, Oberon-2, and Oberon-07 programming languages
- He wrote several books, including The Pascal User Manual and Report, Algorithms + Data Structures = Programs, and Systematic Programming: An Introduction
- He popularized Wirth's law, which states that software is getting slower more rapidly than hardware becomes faster
- He retired in 1999 and was made a Fellow of the Computer History Museum in 2004
- He has an asteroid named after him, 21655 Niklauswirth
Nils John Nilsson:
- Nils John Nilsson was an American computer scientist and one of the founding researchers in the discipline of artificial intelligence.
- He was the first Kumagai Professor of Engineering in computer science at Stanford University from 1991 until his retirement.
- Nilsson's contributions include search, planning, knowledge representation, and robotics.
- He co-led a research team in the construction of Shakey, a robot that constructed a model of its environment from sensor data and reasoned about that environment to arrive at a plan of action.
- Nilsson was the fourth President of the AAAI and a Founding Fellow of that organization.
- He authored several books on AI, including Principles of Artificial Intelligence and Logical Foundations of Artificial Intelligence.
- In 2011, he was inducted into IEEE Intelligent Systems' AI's Hall of Fame.
- Nilsson died on April 23, 2019, at the age of 86.
Nobuo Yoneda:
- Nobuo Yoneda was a Japanese mathematician and computer scientist.
- He graduated from the University of Tokyo in 1952 and became an Assistant Professor in the Department of Mathematics at the same university.
- He obtained his Doctor of Science degree from the University of Tokyo in 1961 and was appointed Associate Professor at Gakushuin University in 1962.
- Yoneda became a professor of Theoretical Foundation of Information Science in 1972 and retired from the University of Tokyo in 1990.
- He is known for his work on dialects of the programming language ALGOL and for his involvement in developing international standards in programming and informatics.
- The Yoneda lemma in category theory and the Yoneda product in homological algebra are named after him.
- Yoneda was a member of the International Federation for Information Processing and the IFIP Working Group 2.1 on Algorithmic Languages and Calculi. 
- More information about Yoneda can be found at the Mathematics Genealogy Project.
Oded Goldreich:
- Oded Goldreich is a professor of Computer Science at the Weizmann Institute of Science, Israel.
- His research interests include randomness and computation, cryptography, and computational complexity theory.
- He has contributed to the development of pseudorandomness, zero knowledge proofs, secure function evaluation, and property testing, among other areas.
- Goldreich has authored several books including Foundations of Cryptography and Modern Cryptography, Probabilistic Proofs and Pseudorandomness.
- He won the Knuth Prize in 2017 for his contributions to theoretical computer science.
- In 2021, he was selected to receive the Israel Prize in mathematics but was vetoed by Education Minister Yoav Galant due to alleged support for the boycott, divestment and sanctions movement against Israel.
- Goldreich maintains that he did not support BDS, but instead signed a petition calling for a halt to EU funding for Israeli Ariel University on the occupied West Bank.
- The Israel Prize committee petitioned the Supreme Court of Israel to ensure Goldreich's award, but the Court ruled in favor of Galant's petition.
- Former prize-winner David Harel shared his award with Goldreich in protest of the decision.
- In November 2021, Education Minister Yifat Shasha-Biton announced that she would block Goldreich from receiving the prize, but Attorney General Mandelblit later recommended that he be awarded the prize.
- In March 2022, the High Court of Israel ruled that the 2021 prize must be awarded to Goldreich.
- Goldreich is married to Dana Ron, also a computer scientist, and has collaborated with her on approximation algorithms.
Olaf Storaasli (computing):
- Olaf O. Storaasli is a researcher and VP at Synective Labs.
- He was previously a researcher at Oak Ridge National Laboratory and USEC, and also had a career at NASA.
- He led the development of one of NASA's first parallel computers, the Finite element machine, and developed rapid matrix equation algorithms for high-performance computers.
- He has mentored 25 NHGS students, and is recognized by American Men and Women of Science, Marquis Who's Who, and NASA, Cray, Intel and Concordia College awards.
- Storaasli has a B.A. in Physics, Mathematics & French, an M.A. in Mathematics, and a Ph.D. in Engineering Mechanics.
- His research involves developing parallel analysis software for matrix equation solutions to simulate physical and biological behavior on advanced-computer architectures.
- Storaasli has published various books and papers on large-scale analysis, design, and parallel computational methods.
- References to his work can be found in the Mathematics Genealogy Project, Intel Supercomputing Pioneers, and NASA Lessons Learned.
Ole-Johan Dahl:
- Ole-Johan Dahl was a Norwegian computer scientist and professor at the University of Oslo
- He is considered one of the fathers of Simula and object-oriented programming, alongside Kristen Nygaard
- Dahl and Nygaard developed the concepts of class, subclass, inheritance, and dynamic object creation, which are important aspects of object-oriented programming
- Dahl's expertise ranged from practical application to formal mathematical underpinning of programming approaches
