- He received the Turing Award in 2001 and the IEEE John von Neumann Medal in 2002, both with Nygaard
- Dahl was named Commander of the Royal Norwegian Order of St. Olav in 2000
- The Dahl-Nygaard Prize was named after him and Nygaard by the Association Internationale pour les Technologies Objets
- Dahl wrote several papers on simulation programming languages and discrete event simulation
- He was born in Mandal, Norway in 1931 and fled to Sweden with his family during World War II 
- Dahl studied numerical mathematics at the University of Oslo after the war ended.
Oleg A. Mukhanov:
- Oleg A. Mukhanov is a Russian-American electrical engineer focusing on superconductivity.
- He earned a bachelor's degree from the National Research Nuclear University/Moscow Engineering Physics Institute and a Ph.D. in physics from Moscow State University.
- Mukhanov is the co-inventor of SFQ digital technology and has authored and co-authored over 200 scientific papers and holds 24 patents.
- He was the president of the US Committee on Superconducting Electronics and is an editor of IEEE Transactions on Applied Superconductivity.
- Mukhanov worked at HYPRES as Chief Technical Officer from 1991 to 2013 and co-invented a digital RF architecture and developed the world's first commercial use of superconducting computing.
- He worked as CTO and Senior Executive Vice-President of HyPR from 2013 to 2019 and is currently the Chief Technical Officer, co-CEO, and co-founder of SeeQC since May 2019.
- Mukhanov has been recognized as an IEEE Fellow (2012) and received the IEEE Award for Continuing and Significant Contributions in the Field of Small Scale Applied Superconductivity in 2015.
- He resides in Putnam Valley, New York, with his wife Irina B. Mukhanov.
Oren Etzioni:
- Oren Etzioni is an American entrepreneur, Professor Emeritus of Computer Science, and founding CEO of the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence (AI2).
- He announced on June 15, 2022, that he will step down as CEO of AI2 effective September 30, 2022, but will remain as a board member and advisor and take the position of Technical Director of the AI2 Incubator.
- Etzioni was the first student to major in computer science at Harvard University and earned a PhD from Carnegie Mellon University in 1991.
- He joined the University of Washington faculty in 1991 and worked on projects such as Internet Softbots and the KnowItAll project for acquiring massive amounts of information from the web.
- Etzioni founded multiple companies including MetaCrawler, Netbot, ClearForest, Farecast, and co-founded Decide.com, and has written commentary on AI for The New York Times, Wired, and Nature.
- He was selected as the founding CEO of the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence in 2013, where he developed an organizational culture focused on conquering grand AI challenges.
- Under his leadership, the AI2 team grew from zero to over 200 team members, and over the last eight years, AI2 researchers have published close to 700 papers in premier venues.
- Etzioni has received several awards, including a National Young Investigator Award, the Robert S. Engelmore Memorial Award, and was voted "Geek of the Year" through GeekWire. 
- He will continue to be involved with AI2 as a board member, advisor, and Technical Director of AI2 Incubator.
Parisa Tabriz:
- Parisa Tabriz is an Iranian-American computer security expert who works for Google as a Vice President of engineering.
- She grew up in the suburbs of Chicago and was not exposed to coding and computer science until her first year of university.
- She completed a bachelor of science and master of science degree in computer science at the University of Illinois at Urbana–Champaign.
- Tabriz was offered a summer internship with Google's security team while at college, and joined the company a few months after her graduation in 2007.
- She chose the title "Security Princess" on her business card, and trained Google staff interested in learning more about security and worked with youth at DEFCON and Girl Scouts of the USA to expose a more diverse set of people to the field of computer security.
- In 2013, Tabriz took over responsibility for the security of Google Chrome.
- She started an effort to drive adoption of the HTTPS protocol, and spoke out against government interception of HTTPS connections on the public Internet.
- Tabriz is recognized as a tech visionary and has been included in Forbes' "Top 30 People Under 30 To Watch in the Technology Industry" list and Fortune's "40 under 40" list.
Paritosh Pandya:
- Paritosh K. Pandya is an Indian computer scientist based at the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research in Mumbai, India.
- He studied for a BE degree in Electronics at the Maharaja Sayajirao University of Baroda, an MTech degree in Computer Science at IIT Kanpur, and a PhD in Computer Science at Bombay University/TIFR.
- Since 1988, he has held academic posts at TIFR.
- From 1989 to 1991, he was a researcher at the Oxford University Computing Laboratory in England as part of the ESPRIT ProCoS project on "Provably Correct Systems".
- Pandya's main research interest is in the area of formal methods, including real-time systems, and he leads the Theoretical Computer Science Group at TIFR.
- He has been especially involved with research concerning Duration Calculus, including the DCVALID model-checking tool.
- His most cited paper, "Finding Response Times in a Real-Time System", won a 2020 Test-of-Time Award and was published in The Computer Journal in 1986, joint work with Mathai Joseph.
- He has been a member of the Editorial Board for the Formal Aspects of Computing journal published by Springer.
- Pandya is also an adjunct professor at IIT Bombay since 2020.
- His publications can be found on Google Scholar, DBLP Bibliography Server, Academia.edu, Mendeley, and ResearchGate.
Patrick Cousot:
- Patrick Cousot is a French computer scientist and currently a Silver Professor of Computer Science at the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, New York University.
- He has previously held positions at École Normale Supérieure, École Polytechnique, University of Metz, and French National Center for Scientific Research.
- He is the originator of abstract interpretation, a technique used in formal methods, which he developed with his wife Radhia Cousot.
- He has worked on practical methods of static analysis for critical embedded software, such as those found in avionics.
- Cousot has received numerous awards and accolades, including the CNRS Silver Medal, EADS Foundation Great Prize, ACM SIGPLAN Programming Languages Achievement Award, IEEE Computer Society Harlan D. Mills award, the Humboldt Research Award, the IEEE John von Neumann Medal, and the EATCS award, among others.
- He is also a member of various academic organizations and boards of trustees.
Paul Dourish:
- Paul Dourish is a computer scientist who works at the intersection of computer science and social science.
- He holds the Steckler Endowed Chair of Information and Computer Science at the University of California, Irvine, where he directs the Steckler Center for Responsible, Ethical, and Accessible Technology.
- He is a Fellow of the AAAS, the ACM, and the British Computer Society, and is a two-time winner of the ACM CSCW "Lasting Impact" award.
- Dourish has published three books and over 100 scientific articles, and holds 19 US patents.
- He studied at the University of Edinburgh and completed his Ph.D at University College London before working for Apple Computer and Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center.
- His published work is primarily in the areas of Human-Computer Interaction, Computer supported cooperative work, and Ubiquitous computing.
- Dourish is interested in how people interact with technology and how it shapes our social and cultural practices.
- He has held visiting positions at Intel, Microsoft, MIT, the IT University of Copenhagen, and the University of Melbourne.
- He has won several awards and grants for his research, including the Diana Forsythe Prize, the BM Faculty Award, and the National Science Foundation CAREER Award.
- Dourish has taught courses on Ubiquitous Computing and Interaction, Social Analysis of Computerization, and Human-Computer Interaction at UC Irvine.
Paul Graham (computer programmer):
- Paul Graham is a computer scientist, essayist, entrepreneur, venture capitalist, and author.
- He is known for his work on Lisp, his former startup Viaweb, cofounding Y Combinator, his essays, and Hacker News.
- Graham received a Bachelor of Arts in philosophy from Cornell University, and Master of Science and Doctor of Philosophy degrees in computer science from Harvard University.
- In 1996, Graham founded Viaweb, which was later sold to Yahoo! for $49.6 million.
- Graham's essays cover a variety of topics, including programming languages, startup advice, and philosophy.
- He proposed a disagreement hierarchy, and the Blub paradox to illustrate the difficulty of comparing programming languages objectively.
- Graham co-founded Y Combinator in 2005 to provide seed funding for startups, and it has invested in over 1300 startups.
- Graham married Jessica Livingston in 2008, and they have two children.
- In 2014, Graham stepped down from his day-to-day role at Y Combinator.
- In 2019, Graham announced a new dialect of Lisp called Bel.
Paul Hudak:
- Paul Raymond Hudak was an American musician and professor of computer science at Yale University
- He was involved in the design of the Haskell programming language
- He wrote several textbooks on Haskell and computer music
- He was a chair of the department and master of Saybrook College at Yale
- He died on April 29, 2015, due to leukemia
Paul Justin Compton:
- Paul Compton is an Emeritus Professor at the University of New South Wales (UNSW).
- He was the former Head of the UNSW School of Computer Science and Engineering.
- Compton proposed "ripple-down rules" with R. Jansen in 1988.
- He worked at the Garvan Institute before joining UNSW.
- He has supervised several PhD graduates.
- Compton has been published in various journals and papers from 2001-2005.
- He also holds a patent from 2003.
- Compton has presented several refereed papers at international conferences from 2001-2005.
Paul Vitanyi:
- Paul Michael Béla Vitányi is a Dutch computer scientist and professor of computer science at the University of Amsterdam, as well as a researcher at the Dutch Centrum Wiskunde & Informatica.
- He received his degree of mathematical engineer from Delft University of Technology in 1971 and his Ph.D. from the Free University of Amsterdam in 1978.
- Vitányi has held positions as a guest professor and visiting professor at various universities worldwide, including the University of Copenhagen, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Monash University, and the University of Waterloo.
- He has served on the editorial boards of several academic journals, including the Journal of Computer and Systems Sciences, Information Processing Letters, and the International journal of Foundations of Computer Science, among others.
- Vitányi has received numerous awards and honors, including the National Outstanding Scientific and Technological Book Award of the People's Republic of China, a knighthood in the Order of the Netherlands Lion, and the McGuffey Longevity Award of the Textbook & Academic Authors Association.
- He has published over 200 research papers and books on a range of topics including cellular automata, computational complexity, distributed and parallel computing, machine learning and prediction, physics of computation, Kolmogorov complexity, information theory and quantum computing.
- Vitányi has co-authored the textbook "An Introduction to Kolmogorov Complexity and Its Applications," which received the McGuffey Longevity Award and the National Outstanding Scientific and Technological Book Award of the People's Republic of China.
Paul Vixie:
- Paul Vixie is an American computer scientist known for his technical contributions to Domain Name System (DNS) protocol design and open source software methodology.
- Vixie founded the Internet Software Consortium (ISC) in 1996 to support BIND and other Internet software. ISC's activities were later assumed by Internet Systems Consortium.
- He is also the creator of the first successful commercial anti-spam service and cofounder of Mail Abuse Prevention System (MAPS).
- Vixie served on the board of trustees of the American Registry for Internet Numbers (ARIN) and the Security and Stability Advisory Committee of ICANN.
- He authored several Request for Comments (RFC)s on various subjects, including "Classless IN-ADDR.ARPA Delegation" (BCP 20).
- Vixie received his Ph.D. in Computer Science from Keio University in 2011 and founded a new company, Farsight Security, Inc., in 2013.
- Vixie was inducted into the Internet Hall of Fame as an Innovator in 2014.
- He contributed to the development of several software systems such as BIND, Vixie cron, DHCP, and sendmail.
- Vixie co-authored a book titled "Sendmail: Theory and Practice" in 1995 and holds a patent for the "Internet communication system."
Peter Eades:
- Peter D. Eades is an Australian computer scientist and emeritus professor at the University of Sydney.
- He received his bachelor's degree in mathematics from the Australian National University in 1974 and his Ph.D. in mathematics from the same university in 1977.
- Eades is known for his expertise in graph drawing and has written many highly cited research papers on the topic.
- He is the co-author of the book "Graph drawing: Algorithms for the visualization of graphs" and has been the doctoral advisor of over 30 graduate students.
- Eades was a professor of computer science at the University of Newcastle from 1992 to 1999 before joining the University of Sydney faculty in 2000.
- He has been a keynote speaker at several international conferences on information visualization, algorithms, and graph drawing.
- A workshop was held in honor of Eades' 60th birthday as part of the International Symposium on Graph Drawing in 2012.
- Eades has a home page at the University of Sydney, and a list of his publications is available on DBLP.
Peter J. Denning:
- Peter James Denning is an American computer scientist and writer.

- He is best known for his pioneering work in virtual memory, especially for inventing the working-set model for program behavior.

- Denning attended Manhattan College for a Bachelor in Electrical Engineering and then MIT for a PhD.

- Denning has written several books and has published 340 technical papers.

- He is also known for his works on principles of operating systems, computational models, and design and implementation of CSNET and ACM digital library.

- Denning created a course on innovation as a set of learnable practices called Sense 21.

- He has been a major influence in computer education and has contributed to the development of computing curriculum.

- Denning is married to computer security expert Dorothy E. Denning.
Peter J. Weinberger:
- Peter Jay Weinberger is a computer scientist.
- He is known for his early work at Bell Labs and currently works for Google.
- Weinberger obtained his undergraduate degree from Swarthmore College and his PhD in mathematics from the University of California, Berkeley.
- He contributed to the design of the AWK programming language and the Fortran compiler f77.
- Weinberger was also involved in early digital photography and the creation of the PJW face image.
- Before joining Google, he was chief technology officer at Renaissance Technologies and a member of the JASON defense advisory group.
- Weinberger co-authored the book "The AWK Programming Language".
- He has an Erdos Number of 2.
- More information on his work can be found on his Mathematics Genealogy Project page and a YouTube video where he talks about his work at Google.
Peter Landin:
- Peter John Landin was a British computer scientist.
- He realized that the lambda calculus could be used to model a programming language, which is essential for functional programming and denotational semantics.
- Landin worked as an assistant to Christopher Strachey from 1960 to 1964 before taking a position at Queen Mary University of London.
- He was involved in the definition of the ALGOL programming language and international programming and informatics standards.
- Landin invented the SECD machine, the first abstract machine for a functional programming language, and the ISWIM programming language, defining the Landin off-side rule and coining the term syntactic sugar.
- He was involved with the Gay Liberation Front during the early 1970s and was once arrested as part of an anti-nuclear demonstration.
- Landin's legacy includes an archive of material at the Bodleian Library in Oxford, an annual semantics seminar held in his memory, and a building at Queen Mary University of London named after him.
- Some of Landin's selected publications include "The mechanical evaluation of expressions", "Correspondence between ALGOL 60 and Church's Lambda-notation", and "The next 700 programming languages".
Peter Norvig:
- Peter Norvig is an American computer scientist and Distinguished Education Fellow at the Stanford Institute for Human-Centered AI.
- He previously served as a director of research and search quality at Google.
- Norvig is the co-author with Stuart J. Russell of the most popular textbook in the field of AI: Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach used in more than 1,500 universities in 135 countries.
- He received a Bachelor of Science in applied mathematics from Brown University and a Ph.D. in computer science from the University of California, Berkeley.
- Norvig is a councilor of the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence.
- He has over fifty publications in various areas of computer science, concentrating on artificial intelligence, natural language processing, information retrieval, and software engineering.
- Norvig is also one of the creators of JScheme.
- He worked with Sebastian Thrun to develop a popular online course in Artificial Intelligence that had more than 160,000 students enrolled.
- Norvig was elected an AAAI Fellow in 2001 and a fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery in 2006.
Peter O'Hearn:
- Peter William O'Hearn is a Distinguished Engineer at Lacework and a Professor of Computer Science at University College London (UCL).
- He has made significant contributions to formal methods for program correctness, particularly in the development of separation logic and concurrent separation logic.
- O'Hearn co-founded Monoidics Ltd, which was acquired by Facebook in 2013, and his team developed the Infer Static Analyzer for automated program analysis. The tool has been open-sourced and is used by companies such as Amazon, Spotify, and Uber.
- O'Hearn previously worked as an assistant professor at Syracuse University and was a reader in computer science at Queen Mary University of London before joining UCL.
- He has received numerous accolades for his contributions to computer science, including the Royal Society Wolfson Research Merit Award, the Most Influential POPL Paper Award (twice), the Gödel Prize, and being elected as a Fellow of the Royal Society and the Royal Academy of Engineering.
- In October 2021, O'Hearn and three of his Facebook colleagues were awarded an IEEE Cybersecurity Award for Practice.
Peter Wegner:
- Peter A. Wegner was a computer scientist who contributed to the theory of object-oriented programming and the Church-Turing thesis.
- He received his education from the University of Cambridge and the University of London.
- His seminal work in object-oriented programming is "On Understanding Types," co-authored with Luca Cardelli.
- He co-authored papers and edited a book on the relevance of the Church-Turing thesis for empirical aspects of computer science.
- Wegner was inducted as a Fellow of the ACM in 1995, received the ACM Distinguished Service Award in 2000, and the Austrian Cross of Honor for Science and Art, 1st class in 1999.
- He suffered serious brain injuries when hit by a bus on his trip to London to receive his award but recovered after a lengthy coma.
- He was the editor-in-chief of ACM Computing Surveys and The Brown Faculty Bulletin.
- Wegner was a professor at Brown University.
Philip Don Estridge:
-Don Estridge was an American computer engineer

-He led the development of the original IBM Personal Computer (PC)

-He is known as the "father of the IBM PC"

-His decisions dramatically changed the computer industry, resulting in a vast increase in sales of personal computers, thus creating an entire industry of hardware manufacturers of IBM PCs.

-Estridge completed a bachelor's degree in electrical engineering at the University of Florida and worked at the Army, designing a radar system using computers, IBM and finally NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center until he moved to Boca Raton, Florida, in 1969.

-Before being the leader of the team to develop the IBM PC he had been the lead manager for the development of the IBM Series/1 mini-computer.

-In mid-1980, he was given the opportunity to lead IBM's efforts in the emerging personal computer business.

-The specifications of the IBM PC were published, allowing third-party hardware and software to be used.

-He and his wife were killed in the crash of Delta Air Lines Flight 191 on August 2, 1985.

-Estridge has been honored many times, and the Don Estridge High-Tech Middle School in Boca Raton is named after him.
Philip Emeagwali:
- Philip Emeagwali is a Nigerian computer scientist born on August 23, 1954.
- He won the 1989 Gordon Bell Prize for price-performance in high-performance computing applications with a mathematical formulation and implementation for oil reservoir modeling.
- Emeagwali's early schooling was suspended due to the Nigerian Civil War and completed high-school equivalence through self-study.
- He received a bachelor's degree in mathematics from Oregon State University in 1977 and a master's degree from George Washington University and the University of Maryland.
- Emeagwali made controversial claims about his achievements, including falsely claiming to have invented the Connection Machine and receiving 41 patented inventions, which are disputed by the scientific community.
- He also claimed to be the father of the Internet, which is untrue, and that his work inspired the reinvention of supercomputers as an Internet.
- Emeagwali's Ph.D. thesis at the University of Michigan was not accepted, and he filed a court challenge stating that the university had discriminated against him because of his race, which was dismissed.
- His work has been cited as an example of what Nigerians can achieve when given the opportunity, and he is frequently featured in popular press articles for Black History Month.
- Emeagwali received the Price/performance–1989 Gordon Bell Prize, IEEE ($1,000 prize), and has published several speeches and articles.
Philip Wadler:
- Philip Lee Wadler is an American computer scientist.
- He is known for his contributions to programming language design and type theory.
- Wadler is the chair of Theoretical Computer Science at the University of Edinburgh.
- He contributed to the theory behind functional programming and the design of Haskell and XQuery languages.
- He created the Orwell programming language in 1984.
- Wadler was involved in adding generic types to Java 5.0.
- He is the author of the paper "Theorems for free!" that influenced functional language optimization.
- Wadler received a Bachelor of Science in Mathematics from Stanford University, a Master of Science in Computer Science from Carnegie Mellon University, and a PhD in Computer Science from Carnegie Mellon University.
- He was a research fellow at the Programming Research Group at Oxford University and St Cross College from 1983 to 1987.
- Wadler was a member of the technical staff at Bell Labs and Avaya Labs.
- He has been a professor at the University of Glasgow and the University of Edinburgh.
- Wadler is currently working on a new functional language called Links for writing web applications.
- He has a h-index of 72 and over 26,000 citations on Google Scholar.
- Wadler received the Most Influential POPL Paper Award in 2003 and was elected Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh in 2005.
- He was also inducted as an ACM Fellow in 2007.
Philip Woodward:
- Philip Mayne Woodward was a British mathematician, radar engineer, and horologist
- Woodward had notable success in mathematics, radar engineering, and horology
- Woodward's achievements in radar include developing a mathematical beam-shaping technique and evaluating the ambiguities inherent in all radar signals
- Woodward's achievements in horology include building W5, a clock acclaimed for its accuracy and design, and contributing to scientific horology with major analyses of balance springs and pendulums
- Woodward was also an Honorary Professor in Electrical Engineering at the University of Birmingham and a Deputy Chief Scientific Officer at the Royal Signals and Radar Establishment
- Woodward was born on September 6, 1919, and died on January 30, 2018, at the age of 98.
Phiwa Nkambule:
-Phiwa Nkambule is a technology entrepreneur, technology businessperson, and internet activist.

-He co-founded Riovic and served as its CEO, and previously founded Cybatar, a technology company focused on fuel delivery from his garage in South Africa.

-He also sat on the board of the Royal Science and Technology Park, a state-owned enterprise created to foster the conception of inventions and facilitate their patenting.

-Phiwa was born in Manzini and spent his childhood there. At 14, he began fixing and building computers with his uncle.

-He released the first tuition crowdfunding platform in South Africa in 2015, and he launched a free online learning platform for digital skills aimed at reducing the youth unemployment rate in South Africa.

-Phiwa Nkambule was invited to deliver a keynote address on Digital Technologies in Insurance at the 13th International Microinsurance Conference in Peru, South America in November 2017.

-In June 2018, he was named in the Forbes Africa 30 Under 30 list and in October 2018 he was named in Destiny Man’s Power of 40 list.

-Phiwa was named Social Media Personality of the Year by the Times of Swaziland in December 2021.
Pino Caballero Gil:
- Pino Caballero Gil is a Spanish scientist and professor in Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence at the University of La Laguna (ULL).
- She received her degree in mathematics from ULL in 1990 and her Ph.D. from the same university in 1995.
- Caballero is a coordinator of the CryptULL group of research in cryptology at ULL since 1998.
- Her research focuses on cryptography, cryptanalysis, cryptographic protocols, wireless communications security, pseudorandom number generator, strong authentication, and secure mobile applications.
- She has participated in 47 national and international research projects and is a founding member of the Spanish Network of Excellence on Cybersecurity Research.
- Caballero received the Award of the Instituto Universitario de Estudios de la Mujer, ULL in 2017 and the Premio Día de Canarias para Jóvenes Investigadores in 1998.
- In 2019, she was an unsuccessful candidate for rector at ULL.
- She gave a plenary lecture during Spanish Meeting on Cryptology and Information Security (RECSI) 2022 at the University of Cantabria.
Poul-Henning Kamp:
- Poul-Henning Kamp is a Danish computer software developer
- He has contributed to the FreeBSD project for most of its duration, including the widely used MD5crypt implementation of the MD5 password hash algorithm
- He is the lead architect and developer for the open source Varnish cache project
- He had a dispute with D-Link in 2006 over NTP vandalism
- He popularized the term "bike shed discussion" to describe the phenomenon of trivial topics receiving excessive discussion in open source projects
- He prefers a Beerware license to the GPL
- In 2019, he was accused of anti-semitism for a controversial tweet and subsequent blog post
- He has published articles in various publications, mostly on the topics of computing and time keeping.
Ralph Griswold:
- Ralph E. Griswold was a computer scientist known for his work with high-level programming languages and symbolic computation
- He was responsible for creating the string processing language SNOBOL, SL5, and Icon
- Griswold attended Stanford University and became the head of Bell Labs' Programming Research and Development department in 1967
- In 1971, he was hired by the University of Arizona to be its first professor of computer science and developed the programming language Icon while there
- Griswold was appointed Regents' Professor in 1990 and retired in 1995
- His interests after retirement turned to the mathematical aspects of weaving
- Griswold died on October 4, 2006, from cancer, and his son, Bill Griswold, is also a computer scientist.
Ramanathan V. Guha:
- Ramanathan V. Guha is a creator of web standards, including RSS, RDF, and Schema.org.
- He co-founded Epinions and Alpiri and currently works at Google as a Google Fellow.
- Guha graduated with a Bachelor of Technology in Mechanical Engineering from the Indian Institute of Technology Madras, a Master of Science from University of California, Berkeley, and a Ph.D from Stanford University.
- He was a co-leader of the Cyc Project and created the Meta Content Framework format while at Apple Computer.
- Guha created the first version of RSS and contributed to the "smart browsing" features of Netscape 4.5.
- He was named as a Distinguished Alumnus of the Indian Institute of Technology Madras in 2013 and as an ACM Fellow in 2015 for his contributions to structured data representation and specification on the web.
Ramesh Jain:
- Ramesh Chandra Jain is a scientist and entrepreneur in information and computer science
- He graduated from Visvesvaraya National Institute of Technology, Nagpur, India and has a Ph.D. in electronics engineering from Indian Institute of Technology, Kharagpur, India
- Jain has served in academic positions at many universities, including the University of Michigan, the University of California, San Diego, and Georgia Tech
- He is currently a Bren Professor in Information & Computer Sciences at the University of California, Irvine
- His research interests are in computer vision, artificial intelligence, and multimedia computing
- Jain has founded or co-founded multiple startup companies, including Imageware, Virage, Praja, and Seraja
- He has been elected a Fellow of multiple associations, including the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) and the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE)
- Jain has published over 400 research papers in scientific journals and conferences.
Ramesh Sitaraman:
- Ramesh Sitaraman is an Indian American computer scientist.
- He is known for his work on distributed algorithms, content delivery networks, streaming video delivery, and application delivery networks.
- He helped build the Akamai content delivery network.
- He received a B.Tech in electrical engineering from the Indian Institute of Technology, Madras and a Ph.D in computer science from Princeton University under Robert Tarjan.
- He is a distinguished professor in the computer science department at University of Massachusetts, Amherst.
- His early research centered on algorithms for building reliable parallel networks from unreliable components.
- He helped build the Akamai network using 190,000 servers in 110 countries in over 1,100 networks.
- His current research is focused on energy efficiency of Internet-scale distributed networks.
- He was elected as an ACM Fellow and an IEEE Fellow in 2019 for his contributions to content delivery networks, distributed systems, and scalable Internet services.
Randy Pausch:
- Randolph Frederick Pausch was an American educator and professor of computer science, human-computer interaction, and design at Carnegie Mellon University.
- Pausch was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer in 2006 and was given a terminal diagnosis in 2007.
- He delivered a lecture titled "The Last Lecture: Really Achieving Your Childhood Dreams" which became a popular YouTube video and led to a book of the same name.
- Pausch died of complications from pancreatic cancer in 2008.
- Pausch received numerous awards and honors for his contributions to computing education and mentoring of women in CS and engineering.
- The Randy Pausch Memorial Footbridge was built to link the Computer Science building and the Center for the Arts at CMU.
- Pausch's book, The Last Lecture, became a New York Times best-seller and has been translated into 46 languages.
- Pausch made appearances on The Oprah Winfrey Show and Good Morning America and filmed a cameo for the movie Star Trek.
- Pausch received honors including being listed as one of Time's World's Top-100 Most Influential People and being named Pittsburgher of the Year 2008.
Rapelang Rabana:
- Rapelang Rabana is a computer scientist, entrepreneur, and keynote speaker.
- She is the Founder and Chair of Rekindle Learning, a learning technology company.
- She co-founded Yeigo Communications, South Africa's first free VoIP mobile services provider.
- Rabana has been featured on the cover of ForbesAfrica magazine and selected as a FastCompany Maverick.
- She was named Entrepreneur for the World by the World Entrepreneurship Forum and selected as a Young Global Leader by the World Economic Forum.
- Rabana started her schooling in Botswana and attended Roedean School in Johannesburg.
- She graduated with honours from the University of Cape Town with a bachelor's degree in Business Science with a specialty in Computer Science.
- After graduating, Rabana co-created the VoIP mobile application called Yeigo in 2006.
- In 2014, Rabana founded Rekindle Learning, which empowers people to respond to the changing world of work through digital learning experiences.
- She was appointed Chief Digital Officer of BCX in November 2017.
- Rabana has been on Oprah Magazine's O Power List and Forbes's 30 under 30 list.
- She was invited to join the World Economic Forum 2012 Annual Meeting in Davos, selected as a Global Shaper, and is now a Young Global Leader.
- Rabana is an Ambassador and Juror for the United Nations World Summit Awards and gave the keynote address at Gartner Symposium 2015 in Cape Town.
Rasmus Lerdorf:
- Rasmus Lerdorf is a Danish-Canadian programmer.
- He co-authored and inspired the PHP scripting language, and authored the first two versions of the language.
- He contributed to the Apache HTTP Server and added the LIMIT clause to the mSQL DBMS.
- From 2002 to 2009, he worked for Yahoo! Inc. as an Infrastructure Architecture Engineer.
- In 2010, he joined WePay to develop their application programming interface and since then has been a roving consultant for startups.
- Lerdorf is a frequent speaker at Open Source conferences around the world.
- He was named in the MIT Technology Review TR100 as one of the top 100 innovators in the world under the age of 35 in 2003.
- Lerdorf joined Jelastic as a senior advisor in July 2013 to help them with the creation of new technology.
- He made a speech on the history of PHP, the new PHP 7 release in 2017, and the 25 years of PHP at the WeAreDevelopers Conferences 2017 and 2019.
Rediet Abebe:
Summary:

- Rediet Abebe is an Ethiopian computer scientist who works in algorithms and artificial intelligence.
- She is an Assistant Professor of Computer Science at the University of California, Berkeley.
- Abebe's research focuses on inequality and distributive justice, developing mathematical and computational frameworks to address these issues.
- She co-founded the multi-institutional interdisciplinary research initiatives MD4SG and Black in AI.
- Abebe completed her undergraduate degree in mathematics and Applied Mathematics and a doctoral degree in computer science at Cornell University, where she was advised by Jon Kleinberg.
- Throughout 2019 Abebe served on the National Institutes of Health Working Group on AI.
- Abebe co-founded the MD4SG research initiative in 2016 and Black in AI.
- Her awards and honors include the Class of Andrew Carnegie Fellows, the Harvard Society of Fellows, and the MIT Technology Review's 35 Under 35.
Reinder van de Riet:
- Reind van de Riet was a Dutch computer scientist and Emeritus Professor Information Systems at the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam.
- He developed COLOR-X, a linguistically-based event modeling language for object modeling.
- Van de Riet received his Ph.D. in computer science at the University of Amsterdam in 1968.
- He was appointed Professor Information Systems at the VU University Amsterdam in 1970 and retired in August 2000.
- He was editor of Europe of Data and Knowledge Engineering journal and member of the Editorial Board of the Information Systems Journal.
- His research interests included database and knowledge bases, the use of linguistics, security and privacy problems, and computational auditing.
- A few of his Ph.D. students were Peter Apers, Martin L. Kersten, Roel Wieringa, and Frances Brazier.
- He was knighted into the Orde van de Nederlandse Leeuw.
- He died in Baarn, Netherlands, in 2008, shortly after a lecture trip through the United States.
- Some of his notable publications include "Answering queries without revealing secrets," "Two access methods using compact binary trees," and "COLOR-X: Object Modeling pro ts from Linguistics."
Richard Hamming:
- Richard Wesley Hamming was an American mathematician who made significant contributions in computer engineering and telecommunications.
- He is credited with creating the Hamming code, Hamming window, Hamming numbers, sphere-packing (or Hamming bound), Hamming graph concepts, and the Hamming distance.
- Hamming worked on the Manhattan Project at the Los Alamos Laboratory before joining Bell Telephone Laboratories in 1946
Richard J. Lipton:
- Richard Jay Lipton is an American computer scientist
- He is Associate Dean of Research, Professor, and the Frederick G. Storey Chair in Computing in the College of Computing at the Georgia Institute of Technology
- Lipton has worked in computer science theory, cryptography, and DNA computing
- In 1980, he and Richard M. Karp proved the Karp-Lipton theorem
- Lipton developed a method for proving parallel program correctness
- He has studied and created database security models
- Lipton developed a technique for randomized testing to check the correctness of programs
- He has worked in game theory and proposed a natural quasi-polynomial algorithm to compute epsilon-equilibria
- Lipton and J. Naughton presented an adaptive random sampling algorithm for database querying
- He was critical of formal verification of programs
- Lipton generalized the notion of two-party communication protocols to multi-party communication protocols
- He was part of a team that proved SAT cannot be computed if we apply constraints to both time and space
- Lipton has received several awards and honors, including a Guggenheim Fellowship, membership in the National Academy of Engineering, and the Knuth Prize.
Richard Karp:
- Richard Manning Karp is an American computer scientist and computational theorist at the University of California, Berkeley.
- He received a Turing Award in 1985, The Benjamin Franklin Medal in Computer and Cognitive Science in 2004, and the Kyoto Prize in 2008 for his research in the theory of algorithms.
- Karp was elected a member of the National Academy of Engineering (1992).
- Karp was born in Boston to Jewish parents and grew up in the mostly Jewish neighborhood of Dorchester.
- He attended Harvard University and received a Ph.D. in applied mathematics in 1959.
- Karp joined IBM's Thomas J. Watson Research Center before becoming a professor at UC Berkeley in 1968.
- He was awarded the National Medal of Science, Harvey Prize, and became a fellow of various associations.
- His major research interests include bioinformatics and he has made important discoveries in computer science, combinatorial algorithms, and operations research.
- He co-developed the Held-Karp algorithm, Edmonds-Karp algorithm, the Hopcroft-Karp algorithm, and the Rabin-Karp string search algorithm.
- Karp proved the Karp-Lipton theorem with Richard J. Lipton in 1980. 
- Karp introduced the standard methodology for proving problems to be NP-complete.
Richard Veryard:
- Richard Veryard is a British computer scientist, author, and business consultant.
- He attended Sevenoaks School, Oxford, and Imperial College London.
- Veryard started his career with Data Logic Limited and later worked as an IT consultant with James Martin Associates.
- He became a freelance consultant in 1997 and a principal consultant at CBDi in 2006.
- Veryard has written several books on topics like data analysis, information systems and software economics, and component-based business.
- He developed the Enterprise Modelling Methodology/Open Distributed Processing (EMM/ODP) for enterprise modeling in distributed systems.
- Veryard introduced the concept of "component-based business" in 2001, which describes new business architectures as a dynamic network of components providing services to each other.
- He also wrote about business architecture and its relationship with IT-driven agendas.
Richard W. Conway:
- Richard Walter Conway is an American industrial engineer and computer scientist.
- He is the Emerson Electric Company Professor of Manufacturing Management, Emeritus in the Johnson Graduate School of Management at Cornell University.
- Conway has spent his entire academic career, both as a student and a professor, at Cornell.
- He has held faculty positions at Cornell in several different areas: industrial engineering, operations research, computer science, and management science.
- Conway is known for his work and publications in foundational questions about computer simulation methodology, production scheduling theory, developing computer languages and language compilers, authoring textbooks about computer programming, and developing simulation software for manufacturing.
- In addition, he was the first director of the Office of Computing Services at Cornell.
- Conway received his Bachelor of Mechanical Engineering degree in 1954 and his Ph.D. degree in 1958.
- He became a full professor in 1965 and was named the Emerson Electric Company Professor of Manufacturing Management in 1993.
- Conway has also won several awards including being elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 1992 and being named an inaugural Fellow of the Institute for Operations Research and the Management Sciences in 2002.
- His most notable book is Theory of Scheduling, co-authored with William L. Maxwell and Louis W. Miller, which has been described as a classic work.
- Conway is also known for developing several computer languages, including PL/C, a student-oriented dialect of PL/I, which became widely used in teaching programming.
- In his later career, he focused on simulation for manufacturing processes and developed the XCELL Factory Modelling System.
- Conway retired from the Cornell faculty around 1999 and became a professor emeritus.
- Besides academic work, Conway served as a consultant for several organizations and businesses.
- Over the years, he taught or co-taught courses on management information systems and information systems in manufacturing.
Robert C. Martin:
- Robert Cecil Martin, also known as "Uncle Bob," is an American software engineer, instructor, and author.
- He is known for promoting software design principles and being an author and signatory of the Agile Manifesto.
- Martin founded Object Mentor in 1991, which provided instructor-led training on extreme programming methodology.
- As of March 2020, Martin operates two companies: Uncle Bob Consulting and Clean Coders.
- He is a proponent of software craftsmanship, agile software development, and test-driven development.
- Martin coined the SOLID mnemonic, a collection of software principles.
- Martin has authored several books, including "Clean Code" and "Clean Architecture."
- He was the editor-in-chief of C++ Report magazine and served as the first chairman of the Agile Alliance.
Robert Cailliau:
- Robert Cailliau proposed the first hypertext system for CERN in 1987 and collaborated with Tim Berners-Lee on the World Wide Web.
- He helped design the historic logo of the WWW and organized the first International World Wide Web Conference at CERN in 1994.
- Cailliau also helped transfer Web development from CERN to the global Web consortium in 1995.
- Together with Dr. James Gillies, Cailliau wrote How the Web Was Born, the first book-length account of the origins of the World Wide Web.
- Cailliau is a recipient of several awards including the ACM Software System Award in 1995 and the Internet Hall of Fame by the Internet Society in 2012.
- He retired from CERN in 2007 and is an active member of the pan-European political movement Newropeans.
Robert Dewar:
- Robert Berriedale Keith Dewar was an American computer scientist and educator.
- Dewar helped to develop programming languages and compilers and was an advocate of freely licensed open-source software.
- He was a co-founder, CEO, and president of the AdaCore software company and was an expert in copyright and patent law for software.
- Dewar was involved with developing international standards in programming and informatics as a member of the International Federation for Information Processing.
- He was married to Karin Dewar and had two children, Jenny and Keith.
- Dewar was also an enthusiastic amateur performer and musician and enjoyed singing and playing bassoon and recorder. 
- He was an active member and benefactor of the Village Light Opera Group in New York City, serving them in many capacities, from producer and president to music director, and on stage.
- Dewar died of cancer at age 70 at his home in Bennington, Vermont.
Robert France:
- Robert Bertrand France was a Jamaica-born American computer scientist.
- He studied for a BSc degree in Natural Sciences at the University of the West Indies in Saint Augustine, Trinidad and Tobago.
- He achieved a PhD degree in computer science at Massey University in New Zealand in 1990.
- He undertook research on model-driven software development and was co-founder and editor-in-chief of the Software and Systems Modeling journal from 1999 until 2015.
- He was awarded the Ten Year Most Influential Paper Award at the MODELS 2008 Conference for a paper he co-authored in 1998.
- He was awarded a five-year International Chair at INRIA in France in 2013 and a senior Dahl–Nygaard Prize for his research by the Association Internationale pour les Technologies Objets (AITO) in 2014.
- He died on February 15, 2015, and had a son and daughter with his wife.
Robert Griesemer:
- Robert Griesemer is a Swiss computer scientist.
- He is best known for his work on the Go programming language.
- Prior to Go, he worked on Google's V8 JavaScript engine, the Sawzall language, the Java HotSpot virtual machine, and the Strongtalk system.
- Griesemer studied at the ETH Zurich and works at Google.
- He has authored papers on the Java HotSpot virtual machine and Paxos.
- Griesemer has several patents related to programming languages and optimization.
- He is associated with other notable computer scientists including Rob Pike, Ken Thompson, and Brian Kernighan.
Robert Kowalski:
- Robert Anthony Kowalski is an American-British logician and computer scientist.
- His research focuses on developing models of computing and human thinking.
- He earned a BA in mathematics from the University of Bridgeport, MSc in mathematics from Stanford University, and a PhD in computer science from the University of Edinburgh.
- Kowalski has been at Imperial College London since 1975 and became Emeritus Professor in 1999.
- He is known for his work in automated theorem proving, SLD resolution, and logic programming.
- He has developed the event calculus and applied logic programming to legal reasoning.
- He was one of the developers of Abductive Logic Programming.
- Kowalski has authored multiple books including Logic for Problem Solving and Computational Logic and Human Thinking: How to be Artificially Intelligent.
- He has received several academic honors and awards throughout his career.
- Kowalski's work on the British Nationality Act using logic programming earned him the Inaugural CodeX Prize in 2021.
Robert L. Glass:
- Robert L. (Bob) Glass is an American software engineer and writer.
- He is known for his works on software engineering, especially on measuring the quality of software design and studying the state of the art of software engineering research.
- Glass held his first job in computing in 1954.
- Glass authored more than 200 papers and 25 books, including "The Dark Side of Software Engineering: Evil on Computing Projects."
- He was the emeritus editor-in-chief of the Journal of Systems and Software and writes regular columns for Communications of the ACM and IEEE Software.
- Glass criticized open-source software in 2000, predicting that it will not reach far and will be limited to one or a few cults emerging from a niche culture.
- Glass worked from 1954 to 1957 in the aerospace industry at North American Aviation, from 1957 to 1965 at Aerojet-General Corp., and from 1965 to 1982 at Boeing Company, where he built software tools used by applications specialists.
- He has been a visiting professor at the Linköping University in Sweden and at the Griffith University in Queensland, Australia. 
- Glass worked on a tools-focused research grant at the University of Washington between 1970 and 1972.
- Glass was awarded an honorary Ph.D. from Linkoping University of Sweden in 1995, and he was named a fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) professional society in 1999.
- Using the pseudonym Miles Benson, Glass wrote disguised stories of failed computing projects in the 1970s for industry publication Computerworld.
- After 45 years in the field, Glass described himself as "my head is in the academic area of computing, but my heart is in its practice."
Robert M. Graham (computer scientist):
- Robert M. Graham was a cybersecurity researcher, computer scientist, and Professor Emeritus of Computer Science at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.
- He was born in Michigan, US to a Scottish emigrant.
- He received his undergraduate and graduate degrees from the University of Michigan.
- Graham co-authored two compilers, GAT for the IBM 650 and MAD for the IBM 704/709/7090, while working at UofM's Computing Center.
- In 1963, he moved to MIT to participate in the development of Multics, one of the first virtual memory time-sharing computer operating systems.
- Graham worked at UC Berkeley, City College of New York, and the University of Massachusetts Amherst.
- He officially retired in 1996 but continued to teach until the end of 2003.
- He was inducted as a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery in 1996.
- Graham authored numerous books and professional articles.
- His home page is available on the internet.
Robert S. Boyer:
- Robert Stephen Boyer is a retired American professor of computer science, mathematics, and philosophy at The University of Texas at Austin.
- He and J Strother Moore invented the Boyer-Moore string-search algorithm in 1977.
- They also collaborated on the Boyer-Moore automated theorem prover, Nqthm, in 1992.
- Boyer worked with Moore and Matt Kaufmann on another theorem prover called ACL2.
- Boyer has published extensively and edited books, including "A Computational Logic Handbook," "Automated Reasoning: Essays in Honor of Woody Bledsoe," and "The Correctness Problem in Computer Science."
- See also Boyer-Moore majority vote algorithm and QED manifesto.
- More information can be found on Boyer's home page and Mathematics Genealogy Project page.
Robert Sedgewick (computer scientist):
- Robert Sedgewick is an American computer scientist.
- He is the founding chair and William O. Baker Professor in Computer Science at Princeton University.
- Sedgewick previously served on the faculty at Brown University and has held visiting research positions at Xerox PARC, Institute for Defense Analyses, and INRIA.
- His research expertise is in algorithm science, data structures, and analytic combinatorics.
- He is active in developing the college curriculum in computer science and in harnessing technology to make that curriculum available to anyone seeking the opportunity to learn from it.
- Sedgewick earned his Bachelor of Science and Master of Science degrees in applied mathematics from Brown University and his PhD in computer science from Stanford University.
- Sedgewick has developed red-black trees, ternary search trees, and pairing heaps.
- He is known for emphasizing a scientific approach to the analysis of algorithms based on validating mathematical models with experimental work using realistic data.
- Sedgewick is the author of twenty books, including Algorithms, which was first published in 1983 and is now in its fourth edition.
- He is a pioneer in the development of massive open online courses (MOOCs) and has offered six MOOCs.
- Sedgewick has received numerous awards, including the Leroy P. Steele Prize for mathematical exposition and the Karl V. Karlstrom Outstanding Educator Award.
- He lives in Princeton, New Jersey, with his wife and has four children.
Robert Sproull:
- Robert Lamb Sproull was an American educator, physicist, and US Department of Defense official.
- He was born in Lacon, Illinois, and graduated from Deep Springs College.
- Sproull studied English literature at Cornell University before obtaining a Ph.D. in Physics from the same university.
- He headed the Laboratory of Atomic and Solid State Physics (LASSP) and the Materials Science Center at Cornell University.
- Sproull left Cornell to become the director of the Advanced Research Projects Agency (ARPA).
- He served as provost and vice president of the University of Rochester, becoming its president in 1970.
- He retired as president and became a professor of physics at the university in 1985.
- Sproull was known by the nickname "Particle Bob" during his presidency at the University of Rochester.
- He was a member of the Roundtable Council of the National Academy of Sciences and the chairman of the Defense Science Board.
- In 2005, the University of Rochester named its Center for High Intensity Laser Research in his honor.
- Sproull, with his wife, donated $1 million to create the Robert L. and Mary L. Sproull Fund in 2006 to support the work of the Cornell Center for Materials Research (CCMR).
- He was awarded the Telluride Tech Festival Award of Technology in Telluride, Colorado, in 2006.
- Sproull authored a book titled "Modern Physics."
Robert Tappan Morris:
- Robert Tappan Morris is an American computer scientist and entrepreneur
- He is best known for creating the Morris worm in 1988, the first computer worm on the Internet
- Morris was prosecuted for releasing the worm and became the first person convicted under the then-new Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA)
- He later cofounded the online store Viaweb, one of the first web applications, and later the venture capital funding firm Y Combinator, both with Paul Graham
- Morris is currently a faculty member at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he received tenure in 2006
- He was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 2019
- Morris was indicted for violating the CFAA in 1989 and sentenced to three years of probation and a fine of $10,050 plus the costs of his supervision
- Morris' principal research interest is computer network architectures, including work on distributed hash tables and wireless mesh networks
- He graduated from Harvard University in 1987 and completed his Ph.D. at Harvard in 1999
- Morris was awarded the 2010 Special Interest Group in Operating Systems (SIGOPS) Mark Weiser award and was elected a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery in 2015.
Robert W. Floyd:
- Robert W Floyd was a computer scientist who made several contributions to the field.
- He designed the Floyd-Warshall algorithm for finding all shortest paths in a graph.
- Floyd also worked on parsing and introduced the concept of error diffusion for rendering images, known as Floyd-Steinberg dithering.
- He was a pioneer of program verification using logical assertions.
- Floyd received the Turing Award in 1978 for his contributions to computer science.
- He was an associate professor at Carnegie Mellon University and later became a full professor at Stanford University.
- Floyd worked closely with Donald Knuth and supervised seven Ph.D. graduates.
- He was an avid backgammon player and took the game seriously, studying its mathematics.
- Floyd suffered from Pick's disease in his last years and retired early in 1994.
Roberto Ierusalimschy:
- Roberto Ierusalimschy is a Brazilian computer scientist.
- He created the Lua programming language.
- He holds a PhD in Computer Science from the Pontifical Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro and is a full professor of informatics there.
- He did a post-doc at University of Waterloo in 1992 and was visiting professor at Stanford University in 2012.
- He is the author of Programming in Lua and the creator of LPeg, a Lua library for implementing parsing expression grammars.
- He created Building a Programming Language, a project-based learning program where students learn how to build a programming language from scratch.
- There are several online resources for Roberto Ierusalimschy's publications and bibliography.
Roberto Pieraccini:
- Roberto Pieraccini is an Italian and US electrical engineer working in speech recognition, natural language understanding, and spoken dialog systems.
- He is currently Director of Engineering at Google in Zurich, Switzerland, within the Google Assistant organization.
- He has worked in various research centers, including CSELT, Bell Labs, AT&T Labs, SpeechWorks International, IBM Research, Jibo, and the International Computer Science Institute.
- He has authored over 120 articles, book chapters, and conference publications in the fields of speech recognition, language modeling, optical character recognition, and dialog systems.
- He is the author of two books: The Voice in the Machine and AI Assistants.
- Pieraccini has received several honors and awards, including PrimiDieci USA 2016 and a Doctor in Science honorary degree from the Heriot Watt University of Edinburgh.
- He was elected Chair of the IEEE Speech and Language Technical Committee (SLTC) and is a Fellow of IEEE and ISCA.
Robin Milner:
- Robin Milner was a British computer scientist born in 1934 and died in 2010
- He was educated at Eton College and King's College, Cambridge
- He worked at Ferranti and various universities, including being a co-founder of the Laboratory for Foundations of Computer Science at the University of Edinburgh
- Milner made major contributions to computer science, including developing Logic for Computable Functions (LCF) and the language ML, and creating the calculus of communicating systems (CCS) and the π-calculus
- He was awarded numerous honors and awards, including the ACM Turing Award in 1991 and becoming a Fellow of the Royal Society
- Milner died of a heart attack in Cambridge in 2010
Rod Canion:
- Joseph Rodney "Rod" Canion co-founded Compaq Computer Corporation in 1982 and served as its first President and CEO.
- Canion, Jim Harris, and Bill Murto had been senior managers at Texas Instruments before starting Compaq.
- Canion built a culture at Compaq that attracted top talent, with a West Coast-style campus and high employee participation in meetings.
- During Canion's tenure as CEO, Compaq set records for first-year sales and reached the Fortune 500 and $1 billion in revenue faster than any other company.
- Canion was dismissed as CEO in 1991 after the company's first loss, and was succeeded by Eckhard Pfeiffer.
- After leaving Compaq, Canion founded Insource Technology Group and invested in Questia Media, Inc. He currently serves on multiple boards.
- Canion published a memoir in 2013 about his career at Compaq and the development of the IBM PC compatible industry.
Roger Moore (computer scientist):
- Roger D. Moore was awarded the Grace Murray Hopper Award in 1973 for his work in the design and implementation of APL\360, along with Larry Breed and Richard Lathwell.
- Before I. P. Sharp Associates, Moore contributed to the SUBALGOL compiler at Stanford University and wrote the ALGOL 60 compiler for the Ferranti-Packard 6000 and the ICT 1900.
- Moore was instrumental in the development of IPSANET, a private packet switching data network.
- After retirement, Moore became interested in opera and chamber music and funded the composing of many works.
- He has received several awards including the Roy Thomson Hall Award of Recognition and the University of Toronto Arbor Award.
Rohini Kesavan Srihari:
- Rohini Kesavan Srihari is a computer scientist and entrepreneur.
- She is the founder and CEO of Content Savvy Inc.
- Srihari also founded Cymfony Inc. and Cymfony Net Private Limited in India.
- She is a professor in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering at the University at Buffalo.
- Srihari received her education from various locations including Lansing, Michigan, Kanpur India, and Waterloo, Ontario.
- She has authored over 125 papers in Computer Science.
- Cymfony Inc., founded by Srihari, applied information extraction technology to monitor brand performance, creating the field of brand analytics.
- Srihari was named to the Women of Accomplishment Legacy Project.
Roland Carl Backhouse:
- Roland Carl Backhouse is a British computer scientist and mathematician.
- He is currently Emeritus Professor of Computing Science at the University of Nottingham.
- Backhouse was born and raised in Middlesbrough, England and went to Churchill College, Cambridge for his undergraduate degree and Imperial College London for his Ph.D.
- He has worked at various universities including Heriot-Watt University, University of Essex, University of Groningen, and Eindhoven University of Technology.
- Backhouse has a strong interest in the mathematics of program construction and algorithmic problem solving.
- He co-founded a biennial conference series on the Mathematics of Program Construction in 1989.
- Backhouse has authored and edited numerous books, and has published several selected papers.
- He is married to Hilary, and they have three sons. 
- Backhouse was a member of the International Federation for Information Processing IFIP working group which maintains the programming languages ALGOL 60 and ALGOL 68.
Ron Rivest:
- Ronald Linn Rivest is a cryptographer and an Institute Professor at MIT.
- He is a member of MIT's Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS) and a member of MIT's Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL).
- Rivest is one of the inventors of the RSA algorithm (along with Adi Shamir and Len Adleman).
- He is the inventor of the symmetric key encryption algorithms RC2, RC4, RC5, and co-inventor of RC6.
- Rivest also authored the MD2, MD4, MD5 and MD6 cryptographic hash functions.
- Rivest earned a Bachelor's degree in Mathematics from Yale University and a Ph.D. degree in Computer Science from Stanford University.
- At MIT, Rivest is a member of the Theory of Computation Group, and founder of MIT CSAIL's Cryptography and Information Security Group.
- Rivest is a co-author of the textbook Introduction to Algorithms, and his other contributions include the paper "Time Bounds for Selection."
- Rivest developed the ThreeBallot voting system, a voting system that incorporates the ability for the voter to discern that their vote was counted while still protecting their voter privacy.
- Rivest has research interests in algorithms, cryptography and voting, and his former doctoral students include Avrim Blum, Burt Kaliski, Anna Lysyanskaya, Ron Pinter, Robert Schapire, Alan Sherman, and Mona Singh.
- Rivest is a member of the National Academy of Engineering, the National Academy of Sciences, and is a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery, the International Association for Cryptologic Research, and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
- He has received several honors and awards, including the Turing Award and the MITX Lifetime Achievement Award.
Ronald Stamper:
- Ronald K. Stamper is a British computer scientist and emeritus professor at the University of Twente.
- He is known for his pioneering work in Organisational semiotics, a framework for designing and using computer-based information systems.
- Stamper obtained his MA in Mathematics and Statistics at Oxford University in 1959 and started his career in industry before moving to academia in 1969.
- In the 1970s, he joined the International Federation for Information Processing and contributed significantly to its 1998 publication of A Framework of Information System Concepts. The FRISCO Report.
- Stamper's work uses semiotics to discuss and prescribe practical and theoretical methods for the design and use of information systems.
- He created the MEASUR methodology and the SEDITA framework, which incorporate methods of problem articulation, semantic analysis, and norm analysis.
- Stamper's research into LEGOL (for LEGally Oriented Language) led him to develop the idea of Norms and Affordances and incorporate the Speech Acts of Austin and Searle into his work.
- Stamper's work has been published in various books, including Information, organisation and technology: Studies in organisational semiotics and Semiotic Methods for Enterprise Design and IT Applications.
- His published articles cover topics such as "Aspects of data semantics: names, species and complex physical objects" and "Organisational dynamics, social norms and information systems".
Rosemary Candlin:
- Rosemary Candlin is a crystallographer and computer scientist.
- She worked at the University of Edinburgh Computer Science Department from 1968 to 1995.
- Candlin helped design the department's curriculum and taught courses on real-time programming and parallel programming.
- She worked on physics software for CERN after leaving the University of Edinburgh.
- Candlin studied physics at the University of Cambridge and received a PhD in crystallography.
- She was married to physicist David Candlin and has four children.
- Candlin has published several papers on parallel programming and performance evaluation.
Rudolf Bayer:
- Rudolf Bayer is a German computer scientist
- He taught at the Technical University of Munich since 1972
- He is known for inventing the B-tree, UB-tree, and red-black tree
- He received the 2001 ACM SIGMOD Edgar F. Codd Innovations Award
- In 2005 he was elected a fellow of the Gesellschaft für Informatik
Rudy Rucker:
- Rudolf von Bitter Rucker is an American mathematician, computer scientist, and science-fiction author.
- He's one of the founders of the cyberpunk literary movement.
- Rucker is best known for his novels in the Ware Tetralogy, the first two of which won Philip K. Dick Awards.
- He edited the science fiction webzine Flurb until its closure in 2014.
- Rucker attended St. Xavier High School, then earned a BA in mathematics from Swarthmore College and MS and PhD degrees in mathematics from Rutgers University.
- He taught mathematics at the State University of New York at Geneseo, Ruprecht Karl University of Heidelberg, and Randolph-Macon Women's College before becoming a full-time author and then a computer science professor at San José State University.
- Rucker developed transrealism, a writing style that mixes science fiction with the author's own life experiences and perceptions.
- He often uses his novels to explore scientific and mathematical ideas.
- Rucker also wrote non-fiction books on mathematics, philosophy, and computer science.
- He suffered a cerebral hemorrhage in 2008, prompting him to write his autobiography Nested Scrolls.
- Rucker is a direct descendant of philosopher Georg Hegel.
- His bibliography includes novels, short fiction, non-fiction, and works he edited.
R\u00f3zsa P\u00e9ter:
- Rózsa Péter was a Hungarian mathematician and logician.
- She is known as the "founding mother of recursion theory".
- Péter attended Pázmány Péter University, initially studying chemistry before switching to mathematics.
- She worked with László Kalmár, who encouraged her to pursue mathematics.
- Péter presented her paper on recursive theory, "Rekursive Funktionen", to the International Congress of Mathematicians in 1932.
- She received her PhD summa cum laude in 1935 and presented a paper entitled "Über rekursive Funktionen der zweiten Stufe" to the International Congress of Mathematicians in Oslo in 1936.
- After the passage of Jewish Laws of 1939 in Hungary, Péter was briefly confined to a ghetto in Budapest.
- Péter wrote her book Playing with Infinity: Mathematical Explorations and Excursions during World War II.
- She was the first Hungarian woman to be made an Academic Doctor of Mathematics in 1952.
- Péter published her key work Rekursive Funktionen in 1951, the first book on modern logic by a female author.
- She applied recursive function theory to computers in the mid-1950s.
- Péter's final book, Rekursive Funktionen in der Komputer-Theorie, was published in 1976.
- Péter was awarded the Kossuth Prize in 1951 and became the first woman elected to the Hungarian Academy of Sciences in 1973.
Sally Floyd:
- Sally Jean Floyd was an American computer scientist specializing in computer networking.
- She was born on May 20, 1950, in Virginia and died on August 25, 2019, in Berkeley, California.
- Floyd received a sociology degree from the University of California - Berkeley and later received her MS and PhD in Computer Science from the same institution.
- She was associated with the International Computer Science Institute in Berkeley and is best known for her work on Internet congestion control, including the invention of the Random Early Detection (RED) scheme.
- Floyd was a co-author on several standard protocols including TCP Selective acknowledgement (SACK), Explicit Congestion Notification (ECN), Datagram Congestion Control Protocol (DCCP), and TCP Friendly Rate Control (TFRC).
- She won the 2005 IEEE Internet Award and the prestigious 2007 ACM SIGCOMM Award for her contributions to congestion control.
- Floyd was married to Carole Leita and died at the age of 69 from gallbladder cancer that had metastasized.
- Some of her notable papers include "Random Early Detection Gateways for Congestion Avoidance" and "Why We Don't Know How to Simulate the Internet".
- She received the IEEE Communications Society's William R. Bennett Prize Paper Award for the latter paper in 2001.
Salvatore Stolfo:
- Salvatore J. Stolfo is a professor of computer science at Columbia University specializing in computer security.
- He received a Bachelor of Science degree in Computer Science and Mathematics from Brooklyn College in 1974 and a Ph.D. from NYU Courant Institute in 1979.
- Stolfo has received close to $50M in funding for research that has broadly focused on Security, Intrusion Detection, Anomaly Detection, Machine Learning, including early work in parallel computing and artificial intelligence.
- He has published or co-authored over 250 papers and has over 21,000 citations with an H-index of 67.
- He proposed a project with DARPA in 1996 that applies machine learning to behavioral patterns to detect fraud or intrusion in networks.
- He founded Red Balloon Security in 2011, a cyber security company that developed a symbiote technology called FRAK as a host defense for embedded systems under the sponsorship of DARPA's Cyber Fast Track program.
- He also founded Allure Security Technologies using active behavioral authentication and decoy technology.
- Stolfo's company Electronic Digital Documents produced a “DataBlade” technology, which Informix marketed.
- System Detection was one of the companies founded by Prof. Stolfo to commercialize the Anomaly Detection technology developed in the IDS lab. The company ultimately reorganized and was rebranded as Trusted Computer Solutions. That company was recently acquired by Raytheon. 
- Stolfo was elevated to IEEE Fellow in 2018 and elected as an ACM Fellow in 2019 for his contributions to machine-learning-based cybersecurity and parallel hardware for database inference systems.
Samir Das:
- Samir R. Das is an Indian-American Stony Brook University professor.
- He attended Jadavpur University and Indian Institute of Science.
- He was associated with Indian Statistical Institute in Kolkata.
- He obtained his Ph.D. from the Georgia Institute of Technology.
- He was former faculty at University of Texas at San Antonio and University of Cincinnati.
- He conducted research in computer science particularly in wireless networking.
- His work Ad hoc on-demand distance vector (AODV) was cited over 26,000+ times.
- Many of his research works are highly cited, giving him an h-index of 54.
Samson Abramsky:
- Samson Abramsky is a Professor of Computer Science at University College London.
- He was previously the Christopher Strachey Professor of Computing at the University of Oxford from 2000 to 2021.
- Abramsky has made contributions to domain theory, lazy lambda calculus, strictness analysis, concurrency theory, interaction categories, geometry of interaction, game semantics, and quantum computing.
- He has applied methods from categorical semantics to finite model theory with applications to descriptive complexity.
- Abramsky was educated at Hasmonean Grammar School for Boys, Hendon, King's College, Cambridge, and Queen Mary, University of London.
- His research includes game semantics, domain theory in logical form, and categorical quantum mechanics.
- Abramsky has published over 200 publications, including co-editing six volumes of Handbook of Logic in Computer Science.
- He has won various awards such as the BCS Lovelace Medal in 2013 and the LiCS Test-of-Time award in 2007.
- Abramsky is a Fellow of the Royal Society, Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, and Member of Academia Europaea.
- His nomination for the Royal Society recognizes his contributions to the mathematical foundations of computation, particularly the development of game semantics and his generalization of Girard's geometry of interaction.
Sanjay Ghemawat:
- Sanjay Ghemawat is an Indian American computer scientist and software engineer.
- He is currently a Senior Fellow at Google in the Systems Infrastructure Group.
- Ghemawat's work at Google includes the development of MapReduce, the Google File System, and databases Bigtable and Spanner.
- He was elected as a member into the National Academy of Engineering in 2009.
- Ghemawat obtained a PhD from MIT in 1995, with a dissertation titled "The Modified Object Buffer: A Storage Management Technique for Object-Oriented Databases".
- Before joining Google, Ghemawat worked at the DEC Systems Research Center and collaborated with Jeff Dean.
- He and Dean received the ACM Prize in Computing for their work on internet infrastructure and the ACM SIGOPS Mark Weiser Award in 2012.
- Ghemawat has authored several publications on Google's systems, including MapReduce, the Google File System, and Bigtable.
Sanjeev Arora:
- Sanjeev Arora is an Indian American theoretical computer scientist.
- He was a visiting scholar at the Institute for Advanced Study in 2002-03 and was inducted as a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery in 2008.
- Arora was awarded the ACM Infosys Foundation Award in 2011 for mid-career researchers in Computer Science.
- He was awarded the Fulkerson Prize in 2012 for his work on improving the approximation ratio for graph separators and related problems jointly with Satish Rao and Umesh Vazirani.
- Arora became a Simons Investigator in 2012 and was elected to the National Academy of Sciences in 2018.
- He is a co-author of the book "Computational Complexity: A Modern Approach" with Boaz Barak.
- Arora is a founder and on the Executive Board of Princeton's Center for Computational Intractability.
- Arora and his co-authors have argued that certain financial products are associated with computational asymmetry, which may lead to market instability.
Sankar Pal:
- Sankar Kumar Pal is a computer scientist and the current President of the Indian Statistical Institute, Kolkata.
- He has a focus on fuzzy neural network, soft computing, and machine intelligence research.
- Pal founded the Machine Intelligence Unit in 1993 and the Center for Soft Computing Research: A National Facility in 2004, both at the ISI.
- He is the founder president of the Indian National Academy of Engineering, Kolkata Chapter.
- Pal has received numerous awards, including the Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Prize in 1990 and the Padma Shri award in 2013.
- He has authored over 21 books and 450 research publications, and his work has been cited over 35,000 times.
- Pal is an elected Fellow of multiple academies and societies, and currently, he is the President of Indian Statistical Institute.
Sargur Srihari:
- Sargur Narasimhamurthy Srihari was a computer scientist and educator.
- He contributed to the field of pattern recognition, especially in handwritten address reading and computer forensics.
- Srihari received his Master's and Doctoral degrees in Computer and Information Science from Ohio State University.
- He founded the Center of Excellence for Document Analysis and Recognition (CEDAR).
- CEDAR developed the first handwritten address interpretation system in the world, which was deployed by several postal services.
- Srihari's work on handwriting recognition also led to the first handwriting verification and identification system (CEDAR-FOX).
- He established international conferences on document analysis and recognition and computational forensics.
- Srihari published a landmark study in 2002 that established the individuality of handwriting and extended this research to shoe-print and fingerprint recognition.
- He served on the National Academy of Sciences Committee on Identifying the Needs of the Forensic Science Community, leading to a highly influential report published in 2009.
- Srihari died in 2022 at the age of 72 from complications of glioblastoma.
- He was an IEEE Fellow and an IAPR Fellow and received the Outstanding Achievements Award of IAPR/ICDAR in 2011.
Sarita Schoenebeck:
- Sarita Yardi Schoenebeck is a computer scientist and Director of the Living Online Lab at the University of Michigan.
- Her research focuses on human-computer interaction, social media, and social computing.
- She has studied ways to reduce online harassment and promote justice online, including the effectiveness of community-centered approaches.
- Schoenebeck has also explored what young people expect from their parents regarding social media use.
- In 2017, she was awarded the University of Michigan School of Information Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Award for her work on LGBTQ+ families and online communities.
- She has received several other awards, including the National Science Foundation CAREER award and the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation Fellowship.
- Schoenebeck has a son.
Schahram Dustdar:
• Schahram Dustdar is an Austrian computer scientist
• He is known for his work on distributed systems and elastic computing
• Dustdar is a professor of computer science at TU Wien
• He is also the head of the Distributed Systems Group at TU Wien
