• Dustdar was named Fellow of the IEEE in 2016 
• This was for contributions to elastic computing for cloud applications.
Scott Fahlman:
- Scott Elliott Fahlman is a computer scientist and Professor Emeritus at Carnegie Mellon University's Language Technologies Institute and Computer Science Department.
- He has notable work on automated planning and scheduling, semantic networks, neural networks, and the programming languages Dylan, and Common Lisp.
- He was one of the founders of Lucid Inc.
- From 2006 to 2015, Fahlman was engaged in developing a knowledge base named Scone.
- He is credited with coining the use of the emoticon :-).
- Fahlman received a Bachelor of Science (B.S.) and Master of Science (M.S.) degree in electrical engineering and computer science from MIT, and a Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D.) in artificial intelligence in 1977.
- He acted as thesis advisor for several individuals over the course of his career.
- Fahlman directed the Justsystem Pittsburgh Research Center from May 1996 to July 2001.
Scott Shenker:
- Scott J. Shenker is an American computer scientist and professor of computer science at the University of California, Berkeley.
- He is the leader of the Extensible Internet Group at the International Computer Science Institute in Berkeley, California.
- Shenker has made research contributions in energy-efficient processor scheduling, resource sharing, and software-defined networking.
- He received the SIGCOMM Award in 2002 in recognition of his contributions to Internet design and architecture, fostering research collaboration, and commitment to intellectual rigor in networking research. 
- Shenker is an ISI Highly Cited researcher, one of the five highest-ranked American computer scientists, with total citations exceeding 100,000.
- He received his Sc.B. in physics from Brown University in 1978, and his PhD in physics from University of Chicago in 1983, and an honorary doctorate from the same university in 2007.
- He is a Fellow of the ACM and IEEE and a member of the National Academy of Engineering.
- Shenker is a leader in the movement towards software-defined networking (SDN), co-founder of the Open Networking Foundation, and of Nicira Networks.
- Shenker and colleague Ion Stoica are among Berkeley's top benefactors, after donating $25 million towards computing and data science initiatives.
- Some of his notable publications include studies on distributed algorithmic mechanism design, fair queueing algorithms, and analysis of a scalable content-addressable network.
Sebastian Thrun:
- Sebastian Thrun is a German-American entrepreneur, educator, and computer scientist.
- He is currently the CEO of Kitty Hawk Corporation and the chairman and co-founder of Udacity.
- Thrun was previously a Google VP and Fellow and a Professor of Computer Science at Stanford University and Carnegie Mellon University.
- He is also an adjunct professor at Stanford University and Georgia Tech.
- Thrun led the development of the robotic vehicle Stanley, which won the 2005 DARPA Grand Challenge and is on exhibit at the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History.
- He also led the development of Google's self-driving car.
- Thrun is known for his work on probabilistic algorithms for robotics, specifically in robotic mapping.
- He was elected into the National Academy of Engineering and the Academy of Sciences Leopoldina in 2007.
- The Guardian recognized him as one of 20 "fighters for internet freedom."
- Thrun holds a Diplom and Ph.D. in computer science and statistics from the University of Bonn.
- He co-founded the Master's Program in Automated Learning and Discovery at Carnegie Mellon University and later became the Finmeccanica Associate Professor of Computer Science and Robotics.
- Thrun left CMU in 2003 to become an associate professor at Stanford University where he developed the robot Stanley, which won the DARPA Grand Challenge.
- In 2011, Thrun joined Google as a Google Fellow and co-founded Udacity.
- Thrun contributed to the area of probabilistic robotics, which uses statistics and robotics to make robots more accurate and efficient.
- He has received numerous awards, including the inaugural AAAI Ed Feigenbaum Prize and the 2012 Smithsonian American Ingenuity Award in the Education category.
Serge Abiteboul:
- Serge Joseph Abiteboul is a French computer scientist born in Paris in 1953.
- He studied at the Télécom Paris engineering school and received his PhD from the University of Southern California.
- Abiteboul is a senior researcher at the French national research institute INRIA and a professor at the Collège de France.
- He has made significant contributions in the areas of finite model theory, database theory, and data management.
- Abiteboul is the most highly cited researcher in the data management area who works in a European institution, according to Citeseer.
- He is also the author of two books and is a frequent contributor to French newspapers.
- Abiteboul has been critical of virtual assistants and an advocate for net neutrality.
- He was awarded several awards including the ACM SIGMOD Test of Time Award, the Prix EADS, and the ACM PODS Alberto O. Mendelzon Test-of-Time Award.
- Abiteboul was elected a member of the French Academy of Sciences, the European Academy of Sciences, and an ACM Fellow.
Sergiy Vilkomir:
- Sergiy A. Vilkomir was a Ukrainian-born computer scientist.
- He studied at Kharkov State University and Kharkov Polytechnic Institute in Ukraine before working at various institutes related to nuclear power plant safety.
- In 2000, he became a Research Fellow at the Centre for Applied Formal Methods at London South Bank University before moving to the University of Wollongong in Australia and then to the University of Limerick in Ireland.
- He joined the University of Tennessee as a Research Associate Professor in 2007 before becoming an associate professor at East Carolina University in 2008, where he achieved academic tenure in 2012 and was Head of the Software Testing Research Group (STRG).
- Vilkomir's main research contributions have been in the formalization of software testing, particularly in the development of reinforced condition/decision coverage (RC/DC).
- He was awarded the Google Faculty Research Award for 2010–11, the East Carolina University Scholar-Teacher Award in 2015, and the UNC Board of Governors Distinguished Professor of Teaching Award in 2017.
- He published several papers on software testing criteria, including "Formalization of software testing criteria using the Z notation" and "Reinforced condition/decision coverage (RC/DC): A new criterion for software testing".
- Vilkomir died on February 9, 2020. He was married to Tetyana Vilkomir.
Severo Ornstein:
- Severo M. Ornstein is a retired computer scientist and son of American composer Leo Ornstein.
- He joined MIT's Lincoln Laboratory in 1955 as a programmer and designer for the SAGE air-defense system.
- Ornstein joined the team that designed the LINC computer and became one of the principal designers of macromodules at Washington University in St. Louis.
- He joined Bolt, Beranek and Newman where he was responsible for the design of the communication interfaces and other special hardware for the Interface Message Processor of the ARPANET.
- Ornstein headed the first delegation of U.S. computer scientists to the People's Republic of China in 1972.
- He worked at Xerox PARC where he implemented a computer interface to an early laser printer and co-led the team that built the Dorado computer.
- Ornstein co-designed Mockingbird, the first interactive computer-based music-score editor.
- He was instrumental in starting Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility (CPSR) in 1980.
- Ornstein wrote an autobiography describing his experiences in computer science, published in 2002.
Seymour Ginsburg:
- Seymour Ginsburg was a pioneer of automata theory, formal language theory, and database theory in computer science. 
- He earned a Ph.D. in Mathematics from the University of Michigan in 1952. 
- Ginsburg established the computer science department at USC in 1968 and was awarded a Guggenheim Fellowship in 1974. 
- He made significant contributions to automata theory, formal language theory, and database theory, publishing over 100 papers and three books. 
- Ginsburg's work helped distinguish theoretical computer science from other disciplines like mathematics and electrical engineering. 
- He mentored and supported younger researchers, including Jonathan Goldstine, Sheila Greibach, Michael A. Harrison, Richard Hull, and Jeff Ullman. 
- His contributions to formal language theory included examining the relationships between grammar-based systems, acceptor-based systems, and algebraic characterizations of families of languages. 
- In the field of database theory, he worked on functional dependency, object histories, spreadsheet histories, Datalog, and data restructuring. 
- Ginsburg's work continues to serve as a standard for many computer scientists working in the field of formal languages and automata.
Shafi Goldwasser:
- Shafrira Goldwasser is an Israeli-American computer scientist and winner of the Turing Award in 2012.
- She is the RSA Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at MIT, a professor of mathematical sciences at the Weizmann Institute of Science, Israel, co-founder and chief scientist of Duality Technologies and the director of the Simons Institute for the Theory of Computing at the University of California, Berkeley.
- Goldwasser obtained her Bachelor of Science degree in 1979 in mathematics and science from Carnegie Mellon University and a PhD in computer science from the University of California, Berkeley in 1984.
- Her research areas include computational complexity theory, cryptography and computational number theory.
- Goldwasser is the co-inventor of probabilistic encryption and zero-knowledge proofs, and has made important contributions to complexity theory and secure computation.
- She has received numerous awards and honors, including the Turing Award, the Gödel Prize, the Franklin Institute's Benjamin Franklin Medal, and the L'Oréal-UNESCO for Women in Science Award.
- Goldwasser has also been elected to several prestigious academies, including the National Academy of Engineering, the National Academy of Sciences, and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
Shakuntala Atre:
- Shakuntala (Shaku) Atre is an Indian data scientist and American businesswoman.
- She worked for IBM for 14 years before starting her own firm.
- Atre published the book "Database: Structured Techniques for Design, Performance, and Management: With Case Studies" in 1980, which was one of the first books on managing databases.
- She also co-authored the book "Business Intelligence Roadmap: The Complete Project Lifecycle for Decision-Support Applications" with Larissa Moss in 2003.
- Atre has served as an adjunct professor of data science at the University of Pune and several institutions in the United States.
- Her works, including her books, have been used as university textbooks.
- Atre was born in 1940 in India and studied mathematics, statistics, and computer programming.
- She moved to the United States in 1971 with her husband and began working for IBM.
- Atre left IBM in 1981 to start her own consulting firm and later sold it to Computer Assistance, Inc. She then negotiated a joint-venture with Intec, Inc.
- Atre has published several other books and articles and has been a contributing editor to the journal DBMS.
Shang-Hua Teng:
- Shang-Hua Teng is a Chinese-American computer scientist.
- He is the Seeley G. Mudd Professor of Computer Science and Mathematics at the University of Southern California.
- Teng previously served as the chairman of the Computer Science Department at the Viterbi School of Engineering of the University of Southern California.
- Teng obtained his BA in electrical engineering and BS in computer science from Shanghai Jiao Tong University in 1985.
- He holds a Ph.D. in computer science from Carnegie Mellon University.
- Teng has worked at Xerox PARC, NASA Ames Research Center, Intel Corporation, IBM Almaden Research Center, Akamai Technologies, Microsoft Research Redmond, Microsoft Research New England and Microsoft Research Asia.
- Teng has won the Gödel Prize twice and the Fulkerson Prize.
- He is a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) and an Alfred P. Sloan Research Fellow.
- Teng was named a SIAM Fellow in the 2021 class of fellows.
- Teng married Diana Irene Williams, then a Ph.D. student of history at Harvard University in 2003.
Shashi Shekhar (scientist):
- Shashi Shekhar is a scholar of spatial computing, spatial data science, and Geographic Information Systems (GIS).
- His contributions include scalable roadmap storage methods and algorithms for eco-routing, evacuation route planning, and spatial pattern mining.
- He has authored an Encyclopedia of GIS, a Spatial Databases textbook, and a spatial computing book for professionals.
- Shekhar holds a B.Tech. in Computer Science from IIT Kanpur and a Ph.D. in Computer Science from UC Berkeley.
- His research aims to understand the structure of big spatial computations underlying societal grand challenges.
- Shekhar has served as a co-editor in chief of Geo-Informatica journal and as the President of the University Consortium for GIS (UCGIS).
- He has received numerous awards and honors, including the IEEE Computer Society's Technical Achievement Award and the UCGIS Education Award.
Sheila Greibach:
- Sheila Adele Greibach is a researcher in formal languages in computing, automata, compiler theory, and computer science.
- She is an Emeritus Professor of Computer Science at the University of California, Los Angeles.
- Her notable work includes working with Seymour Ginsburg and Michael A. Harrison in context-sensitive parsing using the stack automaton model.
- She established the normal form (Greibach normal form) for context-free grammars in 1965 and also investigated properties of W-grammars, pushdown automata, and decidability problems.
- Greibach earned an A.B. degree (summa cum laude) in Linguistics and Applied Mathematics from Radcliffe College in 1960.
- In 1963, she was awarded a PhD at Harvard University, advised by Anthony Oettinger, with a PhD thesis entitled "Inverses of Phrase Structure Generators".
- Among her students were Ronald V. Book and Michael J. Fischer.
- Her co-authored works include papers on multitape AFA, superdeterministic PDAs, and stack automata and compiling.
- Her work has been published in the ACM Digital Library and FOCS Bibliography by David M. Jones, among other journals and publications.
- She has also published a book, "Formal parsing systems", in August 1964, in Communications of the ACM, Volume 7 Issue 8.
- Greibach has contributed significantly to the field of formal languages and has established concepts such as the Greibach normal form, the abstract family of acceptors, and Greibach's theorem.
Shimon Even:
- Shimon Even was an Israeli computer science researcher.
- His main topics of interest were algorithms, graph theory and cryptography.
- He was a member of the Computer Science Department at the Technion since 1974.
- He wrote the books Algorithmic Combinatorics and Graph Algorithms.
- He was the PhD advisor of Oded Goldreich, a prominent cryptographer.
- He was associated with the concept of Oblivious Transfer.
- There is a memorial page and a bibliography of his work available online.
Shlomo Zilberstein:
- Shlomo Zilberstein is a computer scientist, Israeli-American.
- He is a Professor of Computer Science and Associate Dean for Research and Engagement in the College of Information and Computer Sciences at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.
- Zilberstein is known for his work in artificial intelligence, anytime algorithms, multi-agent systems, and automated planning and scheduling algorithms.
- He is the director of the Resource-Bounded Reasoning Laboratory at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.
- Together with other researchers, Zilberstein introduced the Decentralized POMDP model, which extends the single-agent POMDP model to a multi-agent scenario.
- Zilberstein has received several awards, including the RIA, CAREER, and ITR awards from the National Science Foundation and being elected as a fellow of the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence in 2011 and of the Association for Computing Machinery in 2021.
- He has published several papers on the topics of automated planning, decision theory, heuristic search, and reinforcement learning.
Shmuel Winograd:
- Shmuel Winograd was an Israeli-American computer scientist who contributed extensively to computational complexity.
- He proved major results in arithmetic computation, including the Coppersmith-Winograd algorithm and a fast Fourier transform algorithm.
- Winograd received his B.S. and M.S. degrees in Electrical Engineering from MIT and his Ph.D. from NYU's Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences.
- He worked at IBM from 1961 to 1994 and was director of the Mathematical Sciences Department there from 1970 to 1974 and 1980 to 1994.
- Winograd received numerous honors and awards during his career, including being made an IBM Fellow in 1972 and being elected as a member of the National Academy of Sciences in 1978.
- He authored a book called "Arithmetic complexity of computations" as part of the CBMS-NSF regional conference series in applied mathematics.
- References are included.
Silvio Micali:
- Silvio Micali is an Italian computer scientist and professor at MIT.
- He is the founder of Algorand, a blockchain cryptocurrency protocol.
- Micali's research focuses on cryptography and information security.
- He graduated from La Sapienza University of Rome and earned a PhD from UC Berkeley.
- Micali co-founded CoreStreet Ltd and Peppercoin in the early 2000s.
- He received multiple awards, including the Turing Award in 2012 and the Gödel Prize in 1993.
- Micali is a member of the National Academy of Sciences, the National Academy of Engineering, and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
Simon Peyton Jones:
- Simon Peyton Jones is a British computer scientist specializing in functional programming languages.
- He graduated from the University of Cambridge with a Bachelor of Science degree in Electrical Sciences in 1979 and completed the Cambridge Diploma in Computer Science in 1980.
- He worked as a lecturer at University College London and as a professor at the University of Glasgow before working as a researcher at Microsoft Research from 1998 to 2021 and as an engineering fellow at Epic Games since 2021.
- Peyton Jones is a lead developer of the Glasgow Haskell Compiler and a co-creator of the C-- programming language.
- He chairs the Computing At School group and was appointed chair of the UK National Centre for Computing Education in 2019.
- Peyton Jones has contributed to the development of new Microsoft Excel features since 2003.
- He has been honored with numerous awards and recognitions, including induction as a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery in 2004 and membership in the Academia Europaea in 2011.
- He was awarded honorary doctorates from the University of Glasgow in 2013 and the University of Kent in 2017.
- He was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 2016 and a Distinguished Fellow of the British Computer Society in 2017.
- In 2022, he was appointed Officer of the Order of the British Empire for services to education and computer science.
Sjaak Brinkkemper:
- Jacobus Nicolaas Brinkkemper is a Dutch computer scientist and full professor of organization and information at the Department of Information and Computing Sciences of Utrecht University.
- He received his BA from the University of Amsterdam and MSc from Radboud University Nijmegen in Mathematics.
- In 1990, he received his PhD from Radboud University Nijmegen for his thesis on Formalisation of information systems modelling, supervised by Eckhard Falkenberg and Alex Verrijn Stuart.
- Brinkkemper has been a member of the International Federation for Information Processing (IFIP) WG 8.1 working group on information systems design and evaluation since 1989.
- His research interests include methodology of product software development, software implementation, methods, requirements management, method engineering, information systems methodology, and system development tools.
- Brinkkemper has published books, papers, and articles related to his research interests, including Formalisation of information systems modelling, Metrics in Method Engineering, and Information systems engineering: state of the art and research themes.
- He is a member of the editorial boards of several journals, including Business Informatics and European Journal of Information Systems.
- Brinkkemper leads a group of approximately twenty researchers specialized in product software development and entrepreneurship at Utrecht University. 
- His work includes developing best practices for business and systems analysis in projects conforming to enterprise architecture. 
- Links to his staff and personal web pages at Utrecht University are provided.
Sophie Wilson:
- Sophie Mary Wilson is an English computer scientist born as Roger Wilson in June 1957.
- She designed a microcomputer during a break from studies at Selwyn College, Cambridge.
- Wilson joined Acorn Computers in 1978 and was instrumental in designing the BBC Micro and BBC BASIC programming language.
- She began designing the ARM reduced instruction set computer (RISC) in 1983, which became the most widely used processor architecture in smartphones.
- Wilson is currently a director at the technology conglomerate Broadcom Inc.
- She has received several awards including the Fellow Award by the Computer History Museum, the Lovie Lifetime Achievement Award and was made a Commander of the British Empire in 2019.
- Sophie Wilson underwent gender reassignment surgery and transitioned from male to female in 1994.
- She is involved in photography and local theater, and has acted in a number of productions.
Stanley Zdonik:
- Stanley Zdonik is a computer scientist specializing in database management systems.
- He is a tenured professor of computer science at Brown University.
- Zdonik completed multiple degrees from MIT including two bachelor's and two master's degrees.
- He has over 100 peer-reviewed papers in the database field and was named an ACM Fellow in 2006.
- Zdonik co-founded StreamBase and Vertica, and is a technical advisor for Attivio.
- He has been involved in the development of several notable database projects, including the Aurora and Borealis stream processing engines, the C-Store column store database, and the H-Store parallel, main memory OLTP system.
- Outside of academia, Zdonik taught novice automobile maintenance on an episode of Car Talk.
Stephen C. Johnson:
- Stephen Curtis Johnson, also known as Steve Johnson, is a computer scientist.
- Johnson worked at Bell Labs and AT&T for nearly 20 years, alongside prominent computer scientists like Jeffrey Ullman, Dennis Ritchie, and Alfred Aho.
- He is best known for developing Yacc, Lint, spell, and the Portable C Compiler.
- Johnson joined several startups after leaving Bell Labs and worked on compilers, 2D and 3D graphics, massively parallel computing, and embedded systems.
- Johnson served on the USENIX board for ten years and was president for four years in the early 1990s.
- He worked at MathWorks, where he helped maintain the front end of the MATLAB programming language and built a lint product called M-Lint.
- Johnson currently works on machine learning at Wave Computing.
Stephen Cole Kleene:
- Stephen Cole Kleene was an American mathematician and a student of Alonzo Church.
- Kleene is known as a founder of recursion theory, which helped to provide the foundations of theoretical computer science.
- He developed important concepts in recursive function theory, including the Kleene normal form theorem, the Kleene recursive theorem, and the Kleene-Post theory of degrees of unsolvability.
- Kleene also made significant contributions to the foundations of mathematical intuitionism and invented regular expressions in 1951.
- He received a bachelor's degree from Amherst College and a Ph.D. in mathematics from Princeton University.
- Kleene spent nearly his entire career at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, where he served as a professor, department chair, and Dean of the College of Letters and Science.
- He received the National Medal of Science in 1990 and is remembered through the Kleene award for the best student paper given at the Symposium on Logic in Computer Science.
- Kleene's publications include "Introduction to Metamathematics" and "Mathematical Logic", among others.
Stephen Cook:
- Stephen Cook is an American-Canadian computer scientist and mathematician who is a university professor at the University of Toronto, Department of Computer Science and Department of Mathematics.
- He received his bachelor's degree from the University of Michigan, and his master's degree and PhD from Harvard University, respectively in 1962 and 1966.
- Cook made significant contributions to the fields of complexity theory and proof complexity.
- Cook is considered one of the forefathers of computational complexity theory.
- Cook formalized the notions of polynomial-time reduction and NP-completeness and proved the existence of an NP-complete problem in his seminal 1971 paper "The Complexity of Theorem Proving Procedures."
- Cook conjectures that there are optimization problems that cannot be solved by efficient algorithms, i.e., P is not equal to NP, which has generated a great deal of research in computational complexity theory.
- Cook won the ACM Turing Award in 1982 and was granted the BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award 2015 in the Information and Communication Technologies category.
- He is a fellow of the Royal Society of London and Royal Society of Canada, and he was elected to membership in the National Academy of Sciences (United States) and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.
- Cook has supervised numerous MSc students, and 36 PhD students have completed their degrees under his supervision.
- Cook lives with his wife in Toronto and enjoys playing the violin and sailing.
Stephen Muggleton:
- Stephen H. Muggleton is a Professor of Machine Learning and Head of the Computational Bioinformatics Laboratory at Imperial College London.
- He received his Bachelor of Science degree in computer science and Doctor of Philosophy in artificial intelligence from the University of Edinburgh.
- Muggleton worked as a postdoctoral research associate at the Turing Institute in Glasgow and later an EPSRC Advanced Research Fellow at Oxford University Computing Laboratory, where he founded the Machine Learning Group.
- He is known for founding the field of Inductive logic programming and has made contributions to theory and systems development in this field.
- Muggleton worked on a Robot Scientist together with Ross D. King that is capable of combining Inductive Logic Programming with active learning.
- His present work focuses on developing Meta-Interpretive Learning, a new form of Inductive Logic Programming that supports predicate invention and learning of recursive programs.
Stephen R. Bourne:
- Stephen Richard "Steve" Bourne is an English computer scientist based in the United States.
- He is known for creating the Bourne shell (sh), which is the foundation for the standard command-line interfaces to Unix.
- He has a Bachelor of Science degree in mathematics and a Ph.D. in mathematics from Trinity College, Cambridge.
- Bourne worked on an ALGOL 68 compiler at the University of Cambridge Computer Laboratory and spent nine years at Bell Labs with the Seventh Edition Unix team.
- Besides the Bourne shell, he wrote the adb debugger and The Unix System.
- After Bell Labs, Bourne worked in senior engineering management positions at Silicon Graphics, Digital Equipment Corporation, Sun Microsystems, and Cisco Systems.
- He was involved with developing international standards in programming and informatics, as a member of the International Federation for Information Processing.
- Bourne was president of the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) from 2000 to 2002 and has received multiple awards from the ACM.
- He is also a Fellow of the Royal Astronomical Society and the chairperson of the editorial advisory board for ACM Queue.
Stephen Wolfram:
- Stephen Wolfram is a British-American computer scientist, physicist, and businessman.
- He is known for his work in computer science, mathematics, and theoretical physics, and was named a fellow of the American Mathematical Society in 2012.
- He is the founder and CEO of the software company Wolfram Research, where he works as chief designer of Mathematica and the Wolfram Alpha answer engine.
- Wolfram was born in London in 1959 to German Jewish refugees to the United Kingdom.
- He was educated at Eton College and St. John's College, Oxford, where he left prematurely in 1978 to attend Caltech, where he received a PhD in particle physics.
- Wolfram joined the faculty at Caltech and became the youngest recipient of a MacArthur Fellowship in 1981, at age 21.
- He started to develop the computer algebra system Mathematica in 1986, which was first released in 1988, and founded Wolfram Research the same year. 
- From 1992 to 2002, Wolfram worked on his controversial book A New Kind of Science, which presents an empirical study of simple computational systems.
- In 2009, Wolfram announced Wolfram Alpha, an answer engine, which launched later that year.
- In 2014, Wolfram officially announced the Wolfram Language as a new general multi-paradigm programming language, and in 2020, he announced the Wolfram Physics Project as an effort to reduce and explain all the laws of physics.
- Wolfram is involved in personal analytics and was a scientific consultant for the 2016 film Arrival.
- He has published several books and papers on various topics, including A New Kind of Science, Cellular Automata and Complexity, and Combinators: A Centennial View.
Steve Lawrence (computer scientist):
- Steve Lawrence is an Australian computer scientist
- He was part of the group at NEC Research that created CiteSeer
- He worked at Google and developed Google Desktop
- He is a co-founder and CTO at Xoo
- Lawrence received degrees from Queensland University of Technology and the University of Queensland
- He has served on program committees for conferences and is a reviewer for many journals
- His research interests include information retrieval, digital libraries, and machine learning
- He has published over 50 papers in these areas, including in Science, Nature, CACM, and IEEE Computer
- He has been interviewed by over 100 news organizations and has received several awards and honors
- External links include his bibliography server and the Internet Archive copy of his old NEC Research homepage
Steve Omohundro:
- Stephen Malvern Omohundro is an American computer scientist
- Areas of research include Hamiltonian physics, dynamical systems, programming languages, machine learning, machine vision, and the social implications of artificial intelligence
- Holds degrees in physics and mathematics from Stanford University (Phi Beta Kappa) and a Ph.D. in physics from the University of California, Berkeley
- Started the "Vision and Learning Group" at the University of Illinois and developed various learning algorithms
- Founded Self-Aware Systems in Palo Alto to research the technology and social implications of self-improving artificial intelligence 
- Advises the Machine Intelligence Research Institute on artificial intelligence safety 
- Co-developed Star Lisp, the first programming language for the Connection Machine, and led the development of the open source programming language Sather at ICSI 
- Described natural Hamiltonian symplectic structures for a wide range of physical models and showed that there exist smooth partial differential equations which stably perform universal computation by simulating arbitrary cellular automata
- Developed an extension to the game theoretic pirate puzzle featured in Scientific American
- Has warned about the "autonomous weapons arms race" due to the rapid development of autonomous systems driven by military and economic pressures.
Steve Schneider (computer scientist):
- Steve Schneider is an English computer scientist and Professor of Security.
- He studied at Oxford University and earned his Doctorate in CSP in 1989.
- Schneider was a lecturer at Royal Holloway, University of London and became a professor in 2002.
- In 2004, he joined the University of Surrey and later became the head of the Department of Computer Science until 2010.
- Schneider is an expert in formal methods, including CSP and the B-Method, and computer security.
- He has authored several books, including "Concurrent and Real Time Systems: the CSP Approach," "Modelling and Analysis of Security Protocols," and "The B-Method: An Introduction." 
- Schneider is the Director of the Surrey Centre for Cyber Security and Associate Dean (Research and Enterprise) at the University of Surrey.
Steve Ward (computer scientist):
- Steve Ward is a professor at MIT in the field of computer science and engineering.
- He holds three degrees from MIT, including a PhD in Computer Science.
- Ward's research includes work on microprocessor-based workstations and developing the TRIX operating system.
- He also invented a novel dynamic memory chip architecture and a real-time controller design.
- Ward was involved in the Curl project which aimed to create a new language for web documents.
- In the early 2000s, he worked on organic computing, exploring alternative ways to build computer systems.
Steve Whittaker:
- Steve Whittaker is a Professor in Human-Computer Interaction at the University of California Santa Cruz.
- He is known for his research on computer mediated communication and personal information management.
- He has worked in industry at Hewlett-Packard Labs, AT&T Labs, and IBM Research Labs.
- Whittaker was born in Liverpool and studied Natural Sciences at Cambridge before obtaining his PhD at St. Andrews.
- He is a Fellow of the ACM and a Member of the SIGCHI Academy.
- Whittaker has received several awards for his work in HCI, including the ACM SIGCHI Lifetime Research Award and the ACM CSCW Lasting Impact Award.
- He is also the Editor of the journal Human Computer Interaction.
- Some of his notable publications include "Email overload: exploring personal information management of email" and "The Science of Managing Our Digital Stuff".
Steven M. Bellovin:
- Steven M. Bellovin is a researcher on computer networking and security and a professor in the Computer Science department at Columbia University.
- He was previously a Fellow at AT&T Labs Research in Florham Park, New Jersey.
- Bellovin served as the Chief Technologist for the United States Federal Trade Commission from September 2012 to August 2013.
- He became the first technology scholar for the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board in February 2016.
- Bellovin was one of the originators of USENET and suggested creating the Phage mailing list as a response to the Morris Worm.
- He identified key security weaknesses in the Domain Name System and received the 2007 National Computer Systems Security Award and was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 2001.
- Bellovin is an active NetBSD user and developer, focusing on architectural, operational, and security issues.
- He is the author and co-author of several books, RFCs, and technical papers.
- As of October 21, 2020, his publications have been cited 19,578 times, and he has an h-index of 59.
Steven Rudich:
- Steven Rudich is a professor in the Carnegie Mellon School of Computer Science.
- He and Alexander Razborov were awarded the Gödel Prize in 2007 for their work on natural proofs.
- He co-authored a paper showing that all currently known NP-complete problems remain NP-complete under AC0 or NC0 reductions.
- Rudich teaches the class "Great Theoretical Ideas in Computer Science," considered one of the most difficult in the undergraduate computer science curriculum at Carnegie Mellon.
- He is an editor of the Journal of Cryptology and an accomplished magician.
- Rudich co-founded Leap@CMU, a summer enrichment program for high school students interested in computer science and robotics.
- To enroll in Leap@CMU, students must take the "Interesting Test" which measures problem-solving abilities.
- As of summer 2018, Leap@CMU has been discontinued.
Steven Spewak:
- Steven Howard Spewak was an American management consultant, author, and lecturer on enterprise architectures
- He is known for the development of Enterprise Architecture Planning (EAP)
- Spewak earned his B.A. and M.A. degrees at Case Western Reserve University and his Ph.D. in business administration at the University of Michigan in 1981
- In 1986, he became software editor at Continental Insurance, where he headed a data modeling project
- Spewak defined Enterprise Architecture Planning as "the process of defining architectures for the use of information in support of the business and the plan for implementing those architectures" in his 1992 book on the subject
- His approach prioritizes the business mission, followed by the data required to satisfy the mission, then applications, and finally technology to implement the applications
- Spewak was a founding partner of Enterprise Architects, Inc., and tutored several generations of Enterprise Architects while consulting for Fortune 500 clients and government organizations
- He authored and co-authored several books, papers, and articles on enterprise architecture and related topics
- Spewak died on April 26, 2004, at the age of 53.
Sue Black (computer scientist):
- Susan Elizabeth Black is a British computer scientist, academic and social entrepreneur.
- She is known for her Saving Bletchley Park campaign, which successfully secured funding for the restoration of the UK World War II code-breaking centre.
- Black has held positions at the University of Westminster, University College London, and is currently a Professor of Computer Science and Technology Evangelist at Durham University.
- She was the founding chair of the British Computer Society (BCS) Specialist Group BCSWomen, serving from 2001 until 2008, and is an advocate of women in computing.
- Black set up Techmums, which offers free training in digital security, social media, and programming language for mothers to increase their confidence in using technology and escape poverty.
- She was the Women's Equality Party candidate for Mayor of London in the 2020 election but withdrew due to health reasons.
- Black has won several awards, including the OBE in 2016 for services to technology, and the Social Impact Abie Award from the AnitaB.org in 2017.
Susan L. Graham:
- Susan Lois Graham is an American computer scientist.
- She is the Pehong Chen Distinguished Professor Emerita in the Computer Science Division of the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences at the University of California, Berkeley.
- Graham received her A.B. in mathematics from Harvard in 1964 and did her graduate work in computer science at Stanford, receiving her M.S. in 1966 and her Ph.D. in 1971.
- She is known for her research projects including Harmonia and Titanium.
- Graham was the founding editor of the ACM Transactions on Programming Languages and Systems and is a member of the United States President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology.
- She has received numerous honors and awards, including the IEEE John von Neumann Medal and the ACM-IEEE-CS Ken Kennedy Award.
- Graham is married to professor emeritus Michael A. Harrison of UC Berkeley.
- See also: List of computer scientists.
Susan Owicki:
- Susan Owicki is a computer scientist and licensed marriage and family therapist.
- She received her PhD in computer science from Cornell University in 1975.
- Owicki was a faculty member at Stanford University for 10 years and was recognized as an ACM Fellow in 1994 for her dissertation work.
- She worked at Digital Equipment Corporation and the Strategic Technologies and Architectural Research Laboratory.
- Owicki has published numerous articles and patents on her research in distributed systems, performance analysis, and trusted systems for electronic commerce.
- She is married and has two children.
- Owicki is also a licensed marriage and family therapist and has a private practice while serving on the staff of the Stanford University faculty and staff help center.
T. William Olle:
- T. William Olle (1933 – March 2019) was a British computer scientist and consultant.
- He received an M.Sc. and a Ph.D. in Astrophysics from the University of Manchester.
- Olle worked for a NATO organization in the Netherlands and for Control Data Corporation in the United States.
- In 1972, he established his own consultancy firm, T. William Olle Associates, specializing in database management applications and information systems methodologies.
- Olle was active in the CODASYL organization, represented the British Computer Society on IFIP TC8, and was chairman of the BSI standards committee for many years.
- He was awarded an honorary doctorate by Middlesex University in 2001.
- Olle’s research interests in computing included database applications, the history of computing, and professionalism in the computer field.
- He published numerous books and articles on information systems design methodologies and database management systems.
Ted Kaehler:
- Ted Kaehler is an American computer scientist known for his contributions to Smalltalk, Squeak, and Apple's HyperCard system.
- Kaehler built a computer while in high school and learned programming language Fortran during a summer job at Fairchild Industries.
- He studied physics at Stanford University, where he met Dan Ingalls.
- In Xerox PARC, Kaehler worked on virtual reality technology, briefed Steve Jobs on the Alto computer's graphical user interface, Smalltalk, and Ethernet network.
- Kaehler played a key role in the development of Smalltalk and co-authored a book, A Taste of Smalltalk.
- He joined Apple as a researcher and was involved in the development of Macintosh, but he was more noted for improving HyperCard system.
- Kaehler co-invented user interface intermittent on-demand halos around objects, which he received a US patent for in 1996.
- He also became part of the open-source software community-supported Squeak Central Team and played a significant role in the development of the Squeak platform's painting system, Squeak Paintbox, and other EToys pilot versions.
- Kaehler's wife Carol Nasby also worked at Apple and died in 1991 from complications of Type 1 diabetes.
- Kaehler married his second wife Cynthia and lived in Las Vegas until her death from cancer in 2020.
Terry Winograd:
- Terry Allen Winograd is a professor of computer science at Stanford University
- He is known for his work on natural language using the SHRDLU program
- Winograd built a blocks world for the program to accept and carry out natural language commands
- Winograd's approach shifted away from classical Artificial Intelligence after encountering criticism of cognitivism
- He worked with Fernando Flores on groupware based on conversation-for-action analysis
- Winograd was a founding member of Computer Professionals for Social Responsibility
- Winograd's work at Stanford focuses on software design informed by analysis, programming, and design practices in other professions
- He advised Larry Page on his research project involving web search, which led to the founding of Google
- Winograd has continued to research collaborative computing, including uses of ubiquitous computing in collaborative work
- He has received awards including Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery and the SIGCHI Lifetime Research Award
- Winograd has authored several books on natural language, software design, and usability.
Thomas E. Kurtz:
- Thomas Eugene Kurtz co-developed the BASIC programming language and the Dartmouth Time Sharing System with John G. Kemeny in 1963 to 1964.
- He was a professor of mathematics and computer science at Dartmouth College where he taught statistics and numerical analysis.
- Kurtz and Kemeny founded True BASIC, Inc. in 1983 to market an updated version of the language.
- He served as Council Chairman and Trustee of EDUCOM, as well as Trustee and Chairman of NERComP.
- Kurtz received numerous awards for his work on BASIC, including the IEEE Computer Pioneer Award in 1991 and being inducted as a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery in 1994.
- Kurtz composed his first computer program in 1951 while working with computers at UCLA in the institute of numerical analysis.
- BASIC was created to give students a simple programming language that was easy to learn and for the average computer user.
- BASIC was criticized for being unstructured and limited its use by larger companies.
- True BASIC was based on Dartmouth BASIC 7 and offered modern programming constructs such as “IF..THEN..ELSE, DO..LOOP, and EXIT DO”.
- Versions of True BASIC are available for DOS, macOS, Windows, Unix, and Linux systems.
Thomas Sterling (computing):
- Thomas Sterling is a professor at Indiana University
- He is the Director of the Artificial Intelligence Computing Systems Laboratory
- Sterling earned his Ph.D from MIT in 1984
- He pioneered the "Beowulf" clusters 
- He was Principal investigator for the HTMT project for high-performance computing systems
- Sterling currently leads research in non-von Neumann parallel architecture and HPX+ runtime system
- He is President and co-founder of Simultac LLC
- He co-authored eight books and holds seven patents
- Sterling is a Fellow of the AAAS and winner of the Gordon Bell Prize.
Tim Finin:
- Timothy Wilking Finin is a professor of Computer Science and Electrical Engineering at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County.
- His research focuses on artificial intelligence applications in information systems, including natural language processing, expert systems, multiagent systems, semantic web, and mobile computing.
- Finin earned an undergraduate degree in Electrical Engineering from MIT and a PhD in Computer Science from the University of Illinois.
- He has held positions at the Unisys Paoli Research Center, the University of Pennsylvania, and the MIT Artificial Intelligence Laboratory.
- Finin is the author of over 450 refereed publications and has received research grants and contracts from various sources.
- He has organized several major conferences, including the IEEE Conference on Artificial Intelligence for Applications and the International Semantic Web Conference.
- Finin has received awards such as the Technical Achievement Award and the Presidential Research Professor title from UMBC.
- He was named a fellow of the Association for the Advancement of Artificial Intelligence and an ACM Fellow for his contributions to knowledge sharing in distributed systems and the World Wide Web.
Tin Kam Ho:
- Tin Kam Ho is a computer scientist at IBM Research.
- She has contributed to machine learning, data mining, and classification.
- Ho introduced random decision forests in 1995, which became the foundation of the random forest method.
- She has also pioneered research in multiple classifier systems, ensemble learning, and data complexity analysis.
- Ho completed her undergraduate education at the Chinese University of Hong Kong in 1984 and received a Ph.D. in Computer Science from State University of New York at Buffalo in 1992.
- Her contributions were recognized by a Bell Labs President's Gold Award, two Bell Labs Teamwork Awards, and several other awards.
- Ho is an IEEE fellow and IAPR fellow.
Tom Gruber:
- Thomas Robert Gruber is an American computer scientist, inventor, and entrepreneur focused on knowledge sharing and collective intelligence systems.
- He did foundational work in ontology engineering and is known for his definition of ontologies in the context of artificial intelligence.
- Gruber co-founded Siri Inc. in 2007, which created the Siri intelligent personal assistant and knowledge navigator. 
- Siri was acquired by Apple in 2010 and is now an integral part of iOS.
- Gruber studied psychology and computer science and graduated summa cum laude from Loyola University New Orleans in 1981.
- He received his Ph.D. in Computer and Information Science from the University of Massachusetts Amherst in 1988 with a dissertation on knowledge acquisition. 
- Gruber has published several articles and books on the topics of ontology, knowledge acquisition, and computer-supported collaborative work.
- He spoke on the TED stage in 2017 about his vision for the future of "humanistic AI" and how it can augment human capacities. 
- Gruber was also responsible for the creation of hypermail, an email to web gateway software that saw extensive use after a rewrite by a different programmer.
Tom M. Mitchell:
- Tom Michael Mitchell is a computer scientist and the Founders University Professor at Carnegie Mellon University.
- He is a founder and former Chair of the Machine Learning Department at CMU.
- Mitchell is known for his contributions to the advancement of machine learning, artificial intelligence, and cognitive neuroscience and authored the textbook Machine Learning.
- He is a member of the United States National Academy of Engineering, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
- In October 2018, Mitchell was appointed as the Interim Dean of the School of Computer Science at Carnegie Mellon.
- Mitchell received his bachelor's degree in Electrical Engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a Ph.D. from Stanford University.
- He has held positions at Rutgers University and joined Carnegie Mellon University in 1986.
- Mitchell is a prolific author of scientific works on various topics in computer science.
- He has received several honors and awards, including the NSF Presidential Young Investigator Award and an Honorary Doctor of Laws degree from Dalhousie University.
- Mitchell is also a member of the Scientific Advisory Board of the Allen Institute for AI and the Science Board of the Santa Fe Institute.
Tom Maibaum:
- Thomas Stephen Edward Maibaum is a computer scientist and Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts.
- He has a Bachelor of Science in pure mathematics from the University of Toronto and a PhD in computer science from University of London.
- Maibaum has held academic positions at Imperial College London, King's College London, and McMaster University.
- His research interests focus on the theory of specification in the area of software engineering.
- From 1996 to 2005, he was involved in developing international standards in programming and informatics as a member of IFIP Working Group 2.1.
- He is a Fellow of the Institution of Engineering and Technology and the Royal Society of Arts.
Tracy Camp:
- Tracy Kay Camp is an American computer scientist.
- She is known for her research on wireless networking and leadership in broadening participation in computing.
- Camp received a B.A., M.S., and Ph.D. in Mathematics and Computer Science.
- She has held various positions at the University of Alabama and Colorado School of Mines, where she is currently the Head of the Department of Computer Science.
- Camp has received prestigious awards including being named a fellow of both ACM and IEEE.
- The source for more information is the Colorado School of Mines' Department of Computer Science website.
Tracy Chou:
- Tracy Chou is a software engineer and advocate for diversity in technology-related fields.
- She previously worked at Pinterest and Quora with internships at Rocket Fuel, Google, and Facebook.
- Chou is known for raising the profile of the issue of the low representation of women in technology companies and pressuring companies to reveal more statistics about the composition of their workforce.
- In 2016, she co-founded the advocacy group Project Include with seven other women from the industry.
- Chou is the CEO and founder of Block Party, a consumer app that tackles online harassment and puts users back in control.
- Chou's focus on the issue of diversity in technology companies is credited with pressuring larger companies such as Google, Facebook, and Microsoft to release diversity reports.
- Chou has identified possible reasons for the disparity in the representation of women in technology, including limited networking opportunities, condescending attitudes, and a lack of female role models.
- Chou has spoken at various conferences, including Stanford University's Entrepreneurial Thought Leaders Series and Vogue Australia's Vogue Codes.
Trygve Reenskaug:
- Trygve Mikkjel Heyerdahl Reenskaug is a Norwegian computer scientist and professor emeritus of the University of Oslo. 
- He formulated the model–view–controller (MVC) pattern for graphical user interface (GUI) software design in 1979 while visiting the Xerox Palo Alto Research Center. 
- Reenskaug's Autokon produced a successful computer-aided design – computer-aided manufacturing (CAD/CAM) program which was first used in 1963 and continued in use by shipyards worldwide for more than 30 years. 
- He has been extensively involved in research into object-oriented methods and developed the Object Oriented Role Analysis and Modeling (OOram) and founded the information technology company Taskon in 1986. 
- Reenskaug wrote the book Working With Objects: The OOram Software Engineering Method with co-authors Per Wold and Odd Arild Lehne. 
- He also wrote a virtual machine for Unified Modeling Language (UML). 
- As of 2005, he is a professor emeritus of informatics at the University of Oslo.
Ujjwal Maulik:
- Ujjwal Maulik is an Indian computer scientist and professor
- He was the former chair of the Department of Computer Science and Engineering at Jadavpur University and head of the Department of Computer Science and Engineering at Kalyani Government Engineering College
- He completed his education at University Of Calcutta and Jadavpur University in West Bengal, India and also did post-doctoral research at universities in Australia and the US
- He has worked at various universities and research institutions around the world
- His research interests include data science, machine learning, bioinformatics, and the Internet of things
- He is a Fellow of several academies and organizations including the Indian National Academy of Engineering, International Association for Pattern Recognition and the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers
- He has received several awards and distinctions for his work in the field of computer science
- He is also a sportsman, short story writer and passionate about mentoring young students and traveling around the world.
Umar Saif:
- Umar Saif is a Pakistani computer scientist and academic.
- He is CEO of SurveyAuto, Chief Digital Officer of the Jang Group and Chief Investment Officer of Khudi Ventures.
- He received his doctorate from the University of Cambridge at the age of 22 and did his postdoc at MIT.
- He founded Pakistan's first technology incubator, Plan 9, and established the Information Technology University.
- He was chairman of the Punjab Information Technology Board (PITB) between 2011 and 2018.
- He has received numerous awards and titles, including the Young Global Leader by the World Economic Forum, Google's Faculty Research Award, and Sitara-i-Imtiaz.
- He was named one of the top 35 young innovators in the world by the MIT Technology Review (TR35) and has been named among The 500 Most Influential Muslims.
- Saif is credited for being the brains behind digital governance of Punjab and one of the main driving forces behind the IT ecosystem in the country.
Umesh Vazirani:
- Umesh Virkumar Vazirani is an Indian-American academic and the Roger A. Strauch Professor of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science at the University of California, Berkeley.
- He is the director of the Berkeley Quantum Computation Center and his research interests lie primarily in quantum computing.
- Vazirani received a BS from MIT in 1981 and a Ph.D. from UC Berkeley in 1986.
- He is one of the founders of the field of quantum computing and co-authored a paper defining a model of quantum Turing machines for complexity-based analysis.
- He also co-authored a paper showing that quantum computers cannot solve black-box search problems faster than O(sqrt(N)).
- Vazirani and his brother, Vijay Vazirani, were inducted as Fellows of the Association for Computing Machinery in 2005.
- Vazirani was awarded the Fulkerson Prize for 2012 for his work on improving the approximation ratio for graph separators and related problems.
- He was elected to the National Academy of Sciences in 2018.
- Some of his notable publications include "Matching is as easy as matrix inversion," "Quantum complexity theory," and "Strengths and weaknesses of quantum computing."
Valerie Taylor (computer scientist):
- Valerie Elaine Taylor is the director of the Mathematics and Computer Science Division of Argonne National Laboratory in Illinois.
- Her research interests include performance analysis, power analysis, and resiliency.
- She is known for her work on "Prophesy," a database used to predict the performance of different applications on parallel systems.
- Taylor received her bachelor's and master's degrees in electrical engineering from Purdue University, and her PhD from the University of California, Berkeley in electrical engineering and computer science.
- She has a patent for her dissertation work on sparse matrices.
- Taylor has worked as a faculty member at Northwestern University and Texas A&M University.
- She is also the CEO and President of the Center for Minorities and People with Disabilities in IT (CMD-IT), which seeks to develop the participation of minorities and people with disabilities in the IT workforce.
- Taylor has received numerous awards for her research, leadership, and efforts to increase diversity in computing.
- She is a member of IEEE and has been elected a fellow of both IEEE and the Association for Computing Machinery.
- In 2019, she was named an Argonne Distinguished Fellow, an award which represents only three percent of research staff at the facility.
Victor Bahl:
- Victor Bahl is an Indian Technical Fellow and CTO of Azure for Operators at Microsoft
- He is known for his research contributions to white space radio data networks, radio signal-strength based indoor positioning systems, multi-radio wireless systems, and wireless network virtualization 
- He is also the founder of the international conference on Mobile Systems, Applications, and Services Conference (MobiSys) and the ACM Mobile Computing and Communications Review 
- Bahl has received multiple awards and holds over 100 US and international patents 
- He developed several groundbreaking technologies, including wireless hardware virtualization, multi-radio wireless systems, and mm-wave networking in data centers 
- He is a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery, IEEE, and American Association for the Advancement of Science 
- Bahl has made significant contributions to the
Vinod Dham:
- Vinod Dham is an Indian-American engineer, entrepreneur and venture capitalist, known as 'Father of the Pentium Chip' for his contribution to the development of Intel's Pentium microprocessor. 
- He has worked for various companies, including NCR Corporation and AMD, and was the CEO of Silicon Spice. 
- He is the founding managing director of the India-based fund, Indo-US Venture Partners, and co-founder and CEO of Acadgild, an online educational platform. 
- Vinod Dham is also involved in philanthropy and has been a trustee of the American India Foundation since 2001.
Vint Cerf:
- Vinton Gray Cerf is an American Internet pioneer and one of "the fathers of the Internet"
- He has received numerous honorary degrees and awards, including the National Medal of Technology, Turing Award, and Presidential Medal of Freedom
- Cerf attended Van Nuys High School with Jon Postel and Steve Crocker and worked at Rocketdyne on the Apollo program during high school
- He received a Bachelor of Science degree in mathematics from Stanford University and a PhD in 1972 from the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA), where he studied under Professor Gerald Estrin and worked in Professor Leonard Kleinrock's data packet networking group
- Cerf worked at the United States Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) from 1973 to 1982 and helped develop TCP/IP, packet radio, packet satellite, and packet security technology
- He helped develop MCI Mail, the first commercial email system to be connected to the Internet, and later joined the Corporation for National Research Initiatives
- Cerf founded the Internet Society in 1992 and served as its first president
- He has worked for Google as a vice president and Chief Internet Evangelist since 2005 and is active in various global humanitarian organizations and councils
- Cerf has received numerous awards and honors, including the Turing Award, Japan Prize, and IEEE Medal of Honor
- He has authored and co-authored numerous publications and writes a column called "CERF'S UP"
Vladimir Vapnik:
- Vladimir Naumovich Vapnik is a computer scientist, researcher, and academic.
- He is one of the main developers of the Vapnik-Chervonenkis theory of statistical learning.
- He is the co-inventor of the support-vector machine method and support-vector clustering algorithms.
- Vapnik was born to a Jewish family in the Soviet Union and received his Master's degree in mathematics from the Uzbek State University in 1958 and his Ph.D. in statistics at the Institute of Control Sciences, Moscow in 1964.
- He worked at the Institute of Control Sciences from 1961 to 1990 and became Head of the Computer Science Research Department.
- Vapnik joined the Adaptive Systems Research Department at AT&T Bell Labs in Holmdel, New Jersey in 1990, where he and his colleagues worked on the support-vector machine.
- Vapnik left AT&T in 2002 and joined NEC Laboratories in Princeton, New Jersey, where he worked in the Machine Learning group.
- Vapnik is a Professor of Computer Science and Statistics at Royal Holloway, University of London since 1995, and a Professor of Computer Science at Columbia University, New York City since 2003.
- He joined Facebook AI Research in 2014 and Vencore Labs in 2016.
- He has won numerous honors and awards, including the 2017 IEEE John von Neumann Medal and the 2019 BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award.
- His book on "The Nature of Statistical Learning Theory" has been cited over 91,650 times.
Volker Strassen:
- Volker Strassen is a German mathematician.
- He is a professor emeritus in the department of mathematics and statistics at the University of Konstanz.
- He has received several awards for his contributions to the analysis of algorithms.
- Strassen began his researches as a probabilist.
- He introduced Strassen's algorithm, the first algorithm for performing matrix multiplication faster than the O(n3) time bound that would result from a naive algorithm.
- Strassen is also known for his work on the Solovay–Strassen primality test.
- He has been awarded the Cantor medal, Konrad Zuse Medal, Paris Kanellakis Award, and the Knuth Prize.
- He became a fellow of the American Mathematical Society in 2012.
W. Bruce Croft:
- W. Bruce Croft is a distinguished professor of computer science at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.
- He is the founder of the Center for Intelligent Information Retrieval and served as the editor-in-chief of ACM Transactions on Information Systems from 1995 to 2002.
- He has made major contributions to most areas of information retrieval, including pioneering work in clustering, passage retrieval, sentence retrieval, and distributed search.
- Croft has led the development of one of the major approaches to modeling search: language modelling.
- Croft and his research group have developed a series of search engines: InQuery, the Lemur toolkit, Indri, and Galago.
- He is the Dean of the College of Information and Computer Sciences at the University of Massachusetts Amherst since 2015.
- Croft has received several prestigious awards, including ACM Fellow, American Society for Information Science and Technology Research Award and IEEE Computer Society Technical Achievement Award.
- He earned a bachelor's and a master's degree from Monash University and a Ph.D. from the University of Cambridge.
W. Richard Stevens:
-William Richard Stevens was a Northern Rhodesia-born American author who wrote books on computer science, especially on UNIX and TCP/IP. 

-He was born in 1951 in Luanshya, Northern Rhodesia, and died in 1999 at the age of 48.

-He received his bachelor's degree in Aerospace Engineering from the University of Michigan in 1973 and both a master's degree and PhD in Systems Engineering from the University of Arizona.

-He was Vice President of Computing Services at Health Systems International in New Haven, Connecticut, from 1982 to 1990.

-Stevens was an aviation enthusiast, an avid pilot, and a part-time flight instructor during the 1970s.

- He was posthumously awarded the Usenix Lifetime Achievement Award in 2000. 

-Stevens wrote many books on computer science, including UNIX Network Programming (1990), Advanced Programming in the UNIX Environment (1992), and TCP/IP Illustrated, Volume 1: The Protocols (1994), amongst others. 

-He co-authored several internet Request for Comments (RFC) documents for the Internet Engineering Task Force. 

-Stevens' RFCs covered updates to the Berkeley sockets API for IPv6, as well as a standard method of congestion control for TCP sessions.
Walter F. Tichy:
- Walter F. Tichy is a German computer scientist born in 1952.
- He was a professor of computer science at the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology until his retirement in April 2022.
- Tichy is known for his contribution to the development of the RCS revision control system.
- He has written extensively on experimental software engineering, the string-to-string correction problem, software configuration management, and extreme programming.
- His works are highly cited in the software development community.
- Tichy's website is available through the IPD Tichy department and his articles can be found online.
Walter Savitch:
- Walter John Savitch defined the complexity class NL, and established complexity classes that allow non-deterministic and probabilistic reasoning.
- Savitch's theorem, which he also formulated, establishes a relationship between the NSPACE and DSPACE complexity classes.
- Savitch did extensive work in natural language processing and mathematical linguistics, focusing on computational complexity as it applies to genetics and biology for over 10 years.
- He authored numerous textbooks for learning how to program in C/C++, Java, Ada, and Pascal, among others.
- Savitch received his PhD in mathematics from the University of California, Berkeley, in 1969 under the supervision of Stephen Cook, and went on to become a professor in the computer science department at the University of California, San Diego.
- A historical account on how Savitch's theorem was discovered can be found in Richard J. Lipton's article, "Savitch's Theorem."
Watts Humphrey:
- Watts S. Humphrey was an American pioneer in software engineering

- He was born in Battle Creek, Michigan on July 4, 1927 and graduated from high school in 1944

- He served in the United States Navy despite struggling with dyslexia

- Humphrey received a bachelor of science in physics from the University of Chicago, a master of science in physics from Illinois Institute of Technology physics department, and a master of business administration from the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business

- He worked at Sylvania Labs and IBM throughout his career

- In the late 1960s, Humphrey headed the IBM software team that introduced the first software license

- He founded the Software Process Program at the Software Engineering Institute (SEI) at Carnegie Mellon University in the 1980s and served as director of that program from 1986 until the early 1990s, resulting in the development of the Capability Maturity Model, PSP, and TSP concepts

- His contributions earned him an honorary doctor of software engineering from the Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University in 1998 and the National Medal of Technology in 2003

- Humphrey authored several books, including "Managing the Software Process" and "Introduction to the Personal Software Process"

- He passed away on October 28, 2010.
Wendy Hall:
- Dame Wendy Hall is a British computer scientist and Regius Professor of Computer Science at the University of Southampton.
- She studied for undergraduate and postgraduate degrees in mathematics at the University of Southampton.
- Hall returned to the University of Southampton in 1984 to join the computer science group there, where her team invented the Microcosm hypermedia system.
- Hall was appointed the University's first female professor of engineering in 1994 and served as Head of the School of Electronics and Computer Science from 2002–07.
- In 2006, along with Tim Berners-Lee, Nigel Shadbolt, and Daniel Weitzner, Hall became a founding director of the Web Science Research Initiative, now known as the Web Science Trust.
- Hall has served as President of the British Computer Society and the Association for Computing Machinery.
- She was appointed Regius Professor of Computer Science at the University of Southampton in 2017 and Chair of the Ada Lovelace Institute in 2020.
- Hall is a Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering, the British Computer Society, the Institution of Engineering and Technology, and the Royal Society.
- She has won numerous awards, including the ABIE Award for Technical Leadership and the Suffrage Science award.
- Hall has co-authored over 500 peer-reviewed journal articles and a book called Four Internets in 2021.
- She is married to Dr Peter Chandler, a plasma physicist.
Wil van der Aalst:
- Wil van der Aalst is a Dutch computer scientist and full professor at RWTH Aachen University.
- He is known for his work on information systems, workflow management, Petri nets, process mining, specification languages, and simulation.
- Van der Aalst received an MSc and PhD from the Technische Universiteit Eindhoven.
- He has held positions as an assistant professor, full professor, and head of various departments at TU/e.
- He is also a visiting professor at various universities and a member of several editorial boards and steering committees.
- Van der Aalst is a strong supporter of open-source software and has developed several tools, including the ProM framework and YAWL.
- His ideas have influenced industry standards and commercial software tools such as BPEL, BPMN, Flower, and ARIS.
- Van der Aalst has published over 400 books, journal papers, book chapters, conference papers, and reports.
- He is an ISI Highly Cited researcher and among the highest ranked computer scientists in the world according to Google Scholar.
Wilhelm Schickard:
- Wilhelm Schickard was a German professor of Hebrew and astronomy born in 1592 and died in 1635.
- He invented a calculating clock that was designed to assist in addition, subtraction, multiplication and division, with Napier's rods for multiplication and an adding machine for input/output.
- The machine was not complete and required additional wheels and springs, and it was designed around a single tooth carry mechanism that did not work properly when used in calculating clocks.
- Schickard is considered to be the father of the computer age and has been credited as the inventor of the mechanical calculator (although the priority of invention is contested).
- Schickard's machine had been published at least once per century starting from 1718, and later devices followed the same path pioneered by Schickard with his combination of Napier's rods and adding machine.
- Schickard was a professor of Hebrew and later astronomy at the University of Tübingen, and he made significant advances in mapmaking and machine invention.
- Schickard published a treatise in 1625 called "The King's Law" in which he analyzes ancient Hebrew political theory using the Talmud and rabbinical literature.
- The priority of invention between Schickard and Blaise Pascal's mechanical calculator is contested, but Pascal's design was slightly later but functioned more efficiently.
- A replica of Schickard's machine was built in 1960 by Bruno von Freytag-Löringhoff, who improved the design of the carry mechanism.
Willem van der Poel:
- Willem Louis van der Poel was a Dutch computer scientist who designed one of the first computers in the Netherlands, the ZEBRA.
- He earned an engineering degree in applied science at Delft University of Technology in 1950 and obtained his PhD from the University of Amsterdam in 1956.
- Van der Poel worked at the Dutch Posterijen, Telegrafie en Telefonie (PTT) until 1967, and was a part-time professor at Delft University of Technology from 1962 to 1988.
- He was a member of the International Federation for Information Processing (IFIP) and helped develop programming languages ALGOL 60 and ALGOL 68, as well as LISP for ZEBRA.
- Van der Poel was an elected member of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences and won the Visser-Neerlandia prize with H. Mol for their Braille translator in 1960.
- He designed several computers, including Testudo, PTERA, ZERO, and ZEBRA, and is known for originating the "zero one infinity" rule in software design.
- Selected publications include his PhD thesis, "SERA 69, definierend rapport" and "New Arithmetical Operators in the Theory of Combinators."
William H. Press:
- William Henry Press is an astrophysicist, theoretical physicist, computer scientist, and computational biologist.
- He is a member of the U.S. National Academy of Sciences, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and the Council on Foreign Relations.
- Other honors include the 1981 Helen B. Warner Prize for Astronomy.
- Press has been a member of the JASON defense advisory group since 1977 and is a past chair. 
- He served as vice-chair of President Obama's President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology (PCAST) from 2009 through 2016.
- In 2012–2013, he served as the 165th President of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
- In July 2016, he became the elected Treasurer of the U.S. National Academy of Sciences, and a member of its Council and Governing Board.
- He is best known for his work with Saul Teukolsky, establishing the dynamic stability of rotating black holes, and his discovery with Paul Schechter of the Press–Schechter formalism, which predicts the distribution of masses of galaxies in the Universe.
- Press is a co-author of the successful Numerical Recipes series of books on scientific computing.
- He was elected a Fellow of the American Physical Society in 1989.
William Kahan:
- William "Velvel" Morton Kahan is a Canadian mathematician and computer scientist.
- He received the Turing Award in 1989 for his contributions to numerical analysis.
- Kahan is the primary architect behind the IEEE 754-1985 standard for floating-point computation.
- He developed the program "paranoia", a benchmark that tests for potential floating-point bugs.
- Kahan coined the term "Table-maker's dilemma" for the unknown cost of correctly rounding transcendental functions.
- He is an outspoken advocate of better education on floating-point issues and denounces decisions impairing good floating-point computations.
- Kahan contributed substantially to the design of algorithms in the HP Voyager series.
- He was named an ACM Fellow in 1994 and inducted into the National Academy of Engineering in 2005.
William Wulf:
- William Allan Wulf is a computer scientist known for his work on programming languages and compilers.
- He obtained a B.S. in engineering physics and an M.S. in electrical engineering at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, and a Ph.D. in computer science from the University of Virginia.
- While at Carnegie Mellon University, he designed the BLISS programming language and an optimizing compiler for it.
- He also worked on an operating system microkernel named Hydra as part of CMUs C.mmp project.
- Wulf co-founded Tartan Laboratories, a compiler technology company, with his wife Anita K. Jones in 1981.
- He served as president of the National Academy of Engineering from 1996 to 2007 and chaired the Computer Science and Telecommunications Board of the National Research Council from 1992 to 1996.
- Wulf resigned from his position as the AT&T Professor of Engineering and Applied Sciences in the Department of Computer Science at the University of Virginia in protest of the forced resignation of former President Teresa A. Sullivan in 2012.
- He has published numerous papers on programming, systems languages, and computer architecture, among other topics.
Wim Ebbinkhuijsen:
- Wim Ebbinkhuijsen is a retired Dutch computer scientist.
- He is considered one of the "fathers of COBOL".
- In 1979, he initiated the International ISO COBOL Working Group.
- From 1967 to 2003, he was a member and chairman of the Dutch COBOL Committee.
- From 1998 to 2001, he was a member of the NCITS/ANSI COBOL committee X3J4.
- He has designed and rewritten many parts of the current COBOL standard.
- Ebbinkhuijsen has worked for many years with Exin, a Dutch examination institute.
- He has written many books about COBOL and wrote the first international standard for BASIC.
- In 2004, he left the COBOL world after 42 years of commitment.
- He received an IEEE award for his contribution to COBOL and was invested as a Knight of the Order of Orange-Nassau.
- A valedictory symposium for him was held at the Vrije Universiteit of Amsterdam. 
- An external link to the symposium is provided.
Winifred Asprey:
• Winifred "Tim" Alice Asprey was an American mathematician and computer scientist.
• She was one of only around 200 women to earn PhDs in mathematics during the 1940s.
• Asprey met Grace Hopper, the "First Lady of Computing," while studying at Vassar College.
• Asprey created the first computer science courses at Vassar and secured funds for the college's first computer.
• She was instrumental in the establishment of the first computer science lab at Vassar through her close contact with IBM.
• Asprey taught mathematics and computer science at Vassar for 38 years and was the chair of the mathematics department until her retirement in 1982.
• Asprey believed that computers would be an essential part of a liberal arts education.
• Asprey's contributions to Vassar's computer center in 1989 led to the center being renamed the Asprey Advanced Computation Laboratory.
Winston W. Royce:
- Winston Walker Royce was an American computer scientist and director at Lockheed Software Technology Center in Austin, Texas. 
- He received his BS in physics, his MS in aeronautical engineering and his PhD in aeronautical engineering from the California Institute of Technology. 
- Royce published an influential article in 1970 titled "Managing the Development of Large Software Systems" from which the Waterfall model for software development was mistakenly drawn. 
- Royce proposed an iterative approach and advocated that projects should pass through this at least twice.
