- Royce coined the term "software system engineering" (SwSE) in the 1980s. 
- In the 1991 article "Software Architecture: Integrating Process and Technology", Royce and his son Walker Royce described the connection between architecture and the software development process. 
- Royce published several books and articles.
Xiaoming Fu:
- Xiaoming Fu is a Chinese German computer scientist.
- He is a Full Professor of Computer Science at Universität Göttingen.
- His research interests include networked systems, mobile and cloud computing, network security, social computing, and big data.
- Fu received his bachelor and master degrees from Northeastern University (China) and PhD from Tsinghua University, Beijing, China.
- He worked at Technische Universität Berlin and joined Universität Göttingen in 2002 as assistant professor, becoming a professor in 2007 and head of the computer networks group.
- Fu has received multiple awards, including being a Fulbright Scholar at UCLA Department of Computer Science in 2009, an IEEE Communications Society Distinguished Lecturer in 2014-2015, and elected Fellow of the Institution of Engineering and Technology in 2017, Academia Europaea in 2018, IEEE in 2021, and ACM Distinguished Member in 2021.
Yale Patt:
- Yale Nance Patt is an American professor of electrical and computer engineering at The University of Texas at Austin.
- He introduced the WOS module, the first complex logic gate implemented on a single piece of silicon, in 1965.
- Patt has pursued aggressive ILP, out-of-order, and speculative computer architectures throughout his career. 
- Patt is a fellow of both the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers and the Association for Computing Machinery. 
- He is the co-author of the textbook Introduction to Computing Systems, currently published in its third edition by McGraw-Hill. 
- Patt received his bachelor's degree from Northeastern University and master's degree and doctorate  at Stanford University. 
- Patt has been awarded several honors, including the IEEE Emanuel R. Piore Award, IEEE/ACM Eckert-Mauchly Award, IEEE Wallace W. McDowell Award, IEEE Computer Society Charles Babbage Award, and the Benjamin Franklin Medal in Computer and Cognitive Science. 
- He was elected to the National Academy of Engineering in 2014 and received an honorary doctorate from the University of Belgrade in 2009.
Yanhong Annie Liu:
- Yanhong Annie Liu is a computer scientist and professor at Stony Brook University.
- Her work focuses on programming languages, software systems, algorithms, intelligent systems, distributed computing systems, and computer security.
- Liu earned a B.Sc. from Peking University, an M.Sc. in engineering from Tsinghua University, and a Ph.D. from Cornell University.
- She worked on language processing at Cornell University as a postdoctoral researcher before joining Indiana University as an assistant professor in 1996.
- Liu joined Stony Brook University in 2000 and was made professor in 2008.
- She leads the Design and Analysis Research Laboratory at Stony Brook University and is a member of the IFIP Working Group 2.1 on Algorithmic Languages and Calculi.
- Liu has authored books on systematic program design and declarative logic programming.
Yann LeCun:
- Yann André LeCun is a computer scientist from France, known for his work in fields such as machine learning, computer vision, mobile robotics and computational neuroscience.
 
- He is currently the Silver Professor of the Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences at New York University and Vice-President, Chief AI Scientist at Meta.
 
- LeCun is one of the main creators of the DjVu image compression technology and co-developed the Lush programming language with Léon Bottou.
 
- In collaboration with Yoshua Bengio and Geoffrey Hinton, he received the 2018 Turing Award for their work on deep learning, earning them the nickname 'Godfathers of AI' and 'Godfathers of Deep Learning'.
 
- LeCun received a Diplôme d'Ingénieur from the ESIEE Paris in 1983 and a PhD in Computer Science from Université Pierre et Marie Curie in 1987.
 
- He worked at AT&T Bell Laboratories and AT&T Labs-Research, becoming head of the Image Processing Research Department in 1996.
 
- He joined New York University in 2003 and became the founding director of the NYU Center for Data Science in 2012.
 
- LeCun is a member of the US National Academy of Sciences, National Academy of Engineering, and the French Académie des Sciences.
 
- In 2019, he won the Turing Award and the Golden Plate Award of the American Academy of Achievement.
 
- In 2022 he received the Princess of Asturias Award in the category "Scientific Research", along with Yoshua Bengio, Geoffrey Hinton and Demis Hassabis.
Yoav Freund:
- Yoav Freund is an Israeli professor of computer science at the University of California San Diego.
- His main areas of research are machine learning, probability theory, and related fields and applications.
- He is known for his work on the AdaBoost algorithm, which is used to combine many "weak" learning machines to create a more robust one.
- He and Robert Schapire received the Gödel prize in 2003 for their joint work on AdaBoost.
- Freund is an alumnus of the Talpiot program of the Israeli army.
- One of his selected works is a book titled "Boosting: Foundations and Algorithms" co-authored with Robert Schapire.
- His homepage is available on the UCSD website.
Yorick Wilks:
- Yorick Wilks is a British computer scientist and emeritus professor of artificial intelligence at the University of Sheffield.
- He pioneered meaning-based approaches to natural language content for computers in the 1970s with his contribution in "Preference Semantics".
- Wilks has received numerous awards, including the Lovelace Medal by the British Computer Society and the Zampolli Prize by ELRA.
- He is a member of several associations, including the Association for Computational Linguistics and the American Association for Artificial Intelligence.
- Wilks has authored several books, including "Artificial Intelligence: Modern Magic or Dangerous Future?" and "Machine Translation: its scope and limits".
- He has also worked on projects such as the Companions Project on creating long-term computer companions for people and has an interest in modelling human-computer dialogue.
- Wilks is a visiting professor of artificial intelligence at Gresham College and a senior research fellow at the Oxford Internet Institute.
- He was awarded the Fellowship of the Association for Computing Machinery and was elected a fellow of the American and European Associations for Artificial Intelligence and the British Computer Society.
- Wilks received a Doctor of Philosophy degree from Pembroke College, Cambridge, where he also joined the Epiphany Philosophers.
- He has published numerous papers and has designed advanced NLP architecture called GATE.
Yuri Matiyasevich:
- Yuri Vladimirovich Matiyasevich is a Russian mathematician and computer scientist.
- He is best known for his negative solution of Hilbert's tenth problem (Matiyasevich's theorem).
- He studied at Saint Petersburg Lyceum 239 and Kolmogorov School.
- In 1964, he won the gold medal at the International Mathematical Olympiad held in Moscow.
- He studied at the Mathematics & Mechanics Faculty of Leningrad State University and obtained a doctoral degree from LOMI in 1970.
- He was the head of Laboratory of mathematical logic at LOMI from 1980-2018.
- He has been a professor of Saint Petersburg State University since 1995.
- He has been elected as a corresponding member of Russian Academy of Sciences and as a full member in 2008.
- He received awards such as the Markov Prize of the Academy of Sciences of the USSR and the Humboldt Research Award.
- Notable students include: Eldar Musayev, Maxim Vsemirnov, Alexei Pastor, Dmitri Karpov.
- Some of his notable works include his book "Hilbert's 10th Problem" and papers such as "Real-time recognition of the inclusion relation" and "Reduction of an arbitrary Diophantine equation to one in 13 unknowns".
- A polynomial related to the colorings of a triangulation of a sphere was named after him (The Matiyasevich polynomial).
- He was a member of the American Mathematical Society and the Association for Symbolic Logic, and served on the editorial boards for the journals Discrete Mathematics and Applications and Computer Instruments in Education.
- He has a home page and results at International Mathematical Olympiad among other external links.
Zohar Manna:
- Zohar Manna was an Israeli-American computer scientist and professor of computer science at Stanford University.
- He earned his Bachelor of Science and Master of Science degrees from the Technion – Israel Institute of Technology and a PhD in computer science from Carnegie Mellon University.
- Manna authored nine books, including The Mathematical Theory of Computation and co-authored an unfinished trilogy of textbooks on temporal logic and verification of reactive systems.
- He received several awards, including induction as a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery and sharing the Herbrand Award with Richard Waldinger.
- He supervised 30 doctoral students, including Nachum Dershowitz, Adi Shamir, and Thomas Henzinger.
- Manna passed away on August 30, 2018.
Zoubin Ghahramani:
- Zoubin Ghahramani is a British-Iranian researcher and Professor of Information Engineering at the University of Cambridge.
- He has joint appointments at University College London and the Alan Turing Institute.
- Ghahramani was Associate Research Professor at Carnegie Mellon University School of Computer Science from 2003-2012 and was the Chief Scientist of Uber from 2016 until 2020.
- In 2020 he joined Google Brain as Senior Research Director.
- He is also Deputy Director of the Leverhulme Centre for the Future of Intelligence.
- Ghahramani was educated at the American School of Madrid and the University of Pennsylvania.
- He obtained his Ph.D. from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, supervised by Michael I. Jordan and Tomaso Poggio.
- Ghahramani has made significant contributions in the areas of Bayesian machine learning, graphical models, and computational neuroscience.
- He co-founded Geometric Intelligence in 2014, which was acquired by Uber in 2016.
- Ghahramani was elected Fellow of the Royal Society (FRS) in 2015.
- He was awarded the Royal Society Milner Award in 2021.
Zvi Galil:
- Zvi Galil is an Israeli-American computer scientist and mathematician.
- He served as the President of Tel Aviv University from 2007-2009 and the dean of the Georgia Institute of Technology College of Computing from 2010-2019.
- Galil's research interests include algorithm design and analysis, computational complexity, and cryptography.
- He coined the terms stringology and sparsification.
- Galil completed his B.Sc. and M.Sc. in applied mathematics at Tel Aviv University before earning his Ph.D. in Computer Science at Cornell University.
- Galil worked at Tel Aviv University and Columbia University before joining Georgia Tech.
- He is credited with developing several currently-fastest algorithms for string and graph matching.
- Galil has received many awards and honors, including induction as a Fellow of ACM and the National Academy of Engineering, and an honorary degree from the University of Waterloo.
- A program he helped conceive, the Online Master of Science in Computer Science (OMSCS), became the largest online master's program in computer science in the United States.
- Galil's work has been recognized by many organizations and he has published over 200 scientific papers.
\u00c9va Tardos:
- Éva Tardos is a well-known Hungarian mathematician.
- She is currently the Jacob Gould Schurman Professor of Computer Science at Cornell University.
- Tardos's research focuses on designing and analyzing efficient methods for combinatorial optimization problems on graphs or networks.
- Her recent work has delved into algorithmic game theory and simple auctions.
- Tardos received her Dipl. Math and Ph.D. degrees from the Faculty of Sciences of the Eötvös Loránd University in 1981 and 1984, respectively, under András Frank's guidance.
- She has won numerous honors and awards, including election to the National Academy of Engineering, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the National Academy of Sciences, and the American Philosophical Society.
- Tardos is an ACM Fellow, a Fellow of INFORMS, and a Fellow of the American Mathematical Society.
- She has received fellowships from Packard, Sloan Foundation, and Guggenheim.
- Tardos has won multiple prizes, including the Fulkerson Prize, the George B. Dantzig Prize, the Van Wijngaarden Award, the Gödel Prize, and the EATCS Award.
- Tardos is married to David Shmoys, and her younger brother is Gábor Tardos. 
- Tardos is also the author of the textbook Algorithm Design, co-written with Jon Kleinberg.
